line.tr: ... He saw the sorrowful assembly ... [76c]
... they perish [and] do not last ... [77b]
... (he recited before the assembly) the law [and] the four truths in detail ... [78a]
... having gone the almsround [and] having washed the hands [78d] ...
... having just emerged they fall .... [79c]
... kaum entstanden, fallen sie [scil. die Früchte des Baumes] ...
... [having] just emerged, they [i.e. the fruit of the tree] fall ...
... they die having just been born .... [80b]
... I am (young), I will not die yet ... [82b]
... they all fall as well, they have been ripped off. [83b] Therefore ...
... [83d] (the foolish beings) like (confused ones) they have passed into (the maws) of the monster of death ...
... firm. An when death suddenly comes to them, (it severs their bonds) [84d] ...
... (A Brahman named Jātiśroṇa) came (in the emerged, terrible doubt of his spirit) to the Omniscient: [85b] (O thou Severer) of all doubt, (o God, sever) ... [85c]
... with the beings.” [86a] To him recited the Omniscient ... [86b]
... 86 (When) the kings (out of insatiability)

comments.comment: Contains fragments of strophes 75d – 87a of the Anityavarga (I); the metre is 21, 21, 18, 13 syllables. The rhythm in a and b is 8/7/6, in c it is 9/9 (or 4/5, 4/5 respectively), in d it is 7/6. The content is partly the same as in , which ascertains important text supplements. Since this leaf directly preceded , it was leaf 12 of the manuscript.
The fragment is badly damaged. It is composed of two smaller fragments.
At the end of the line there is a remnant of an akṣara which can be interpreted as the lower part of the number 70 according to n. 1.

line.tr: ... is (not) one, that was immortal. [80d] Like ...
... (and [to] all) beings (born) death is always ... [81b]
... one [still] seen in the morning, [81a] in the morning also ...
... [those] of middle years [and] also [those] that are young [82a] ...
... the foolish being must have trust: “I am young. (I will not die yet)” ... [82c]
... like the ripe fruit these young ones great ... [83a]
... fall all also, they have been ripped off. [83b] Therefore ...
... (all) went into destruction. [83d] The foolish beings ...
... they laugh, they play, they trust: life [is] eternal ... [84b]
... sie [scil. die törichten Wesen] lachen, sie spielen, sie haben das Vertrauen: Ewig [ist] das Leben ...
... they [i.e. the foolish beings] laugh, they play, they trust: life [is] eternal ...
... (and when de)ath (suddenly comes to them), it severs their bonds. [84d] ...
... A brahmin named (Jāti)śroṇa (came) in the arisen ... [85b]
... o God, sever the doubt that has arisen (in) my spirit. [85c]
... in the countries and villages immorality has turned up (among) the beings. [86b]
... the brothers’ wives are being touched, the sisters, the daughters [86c] ...

... [86d] (When the kings) out of insatiability lead the army (into) other (countries) ... [87a]

line.tr: Wenn die Nāgas die verkehrten Leidenschaften sehen [und] die Länder (verlassen), trocknen die Wasser aus, an Hunger sterben die Wesen, [und] dieser Jambudvīpa geht zugrunde.
When the Nāgas see the wrong passions [and] (leave) the lands, the waters dry up, the beings die of hunger, [and] this Jambudvīpa perishes.

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 a7 a8 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7 b8

line.tr: [Just] (as) earthenware bowls, no matter how many the potter fashions, all [have] breaking [as their] end, …
(So wie der Hirt seine) Kühe mit dem Stock bedroht [und] sie je zu ihren Hürden führt, auf solche Weise bedrohen Alter [und] Tod das Leben der Wesen [und] führen es seinem Ziel zu.

(Just like the herdsman) threatens (his) cows with a stick [and] leads them each to their paddocks, in such a way, old age [and] death threaten the life of the beings [and] lead it to its [ultimate] destination.
Wie der Bergstrom ... (nicht) umkehrt, so gehen die Leben vorüber und kehren nicht wieder um.
Like the mountain stream ... (does not) turn back, just so the lives go past and do not turn back again.
Es fragte der Buddha die Mönche: "Bei welchem Gespräch saßet ihr?"
The Buddha asked the monks: "What conversation were you sitting in?"
Sie fraßen sich nicht gegenseitig.
They did not eat each other.
Übel [ist] jetzt das Leben der Menschen, [aber] sie bringen nicht Lebensüberdruss hervor.
Evil now [is] the life of humans, [but] they do not call forth life-.weariness.
Unter dem Nyagrodhabaum hielt er [scil. Araṇemi] sich ständig auf, dort trug er den Schülern das Gesetz vor.
Under the Nyagrodha-tree he [i.e. Araṇemi] always stayed, there he recited the law to the students.
Vertraut nicht auf das Leben!
Do not trust in life!
[Just] as the thread stretched here: as much as it is woven with the woof, so much smaller it becomes. (cf : ii, 7)

Wie hier der aufgezogene Faden, wie oft er mit dem Einschlag verwebt wird, (so oft gering[er] wird), so [ist] hier das Leben der Menschen, wieviele auch leben, im Vergehen der Tage und Monate wird es hinterher nur abgeschnitten.

Like the taut thread here, [that,] as often as it is interwoven with the plait, (gets less as often), just so [is] the life of humans here, how ever many [there] live, in the passing of days and months it is but cut off afterwards.

[Just] as a being here, being led to be killed: as many steps as it takes to the killing place [lit. cemetery], with so many it (approaches)301 death. So the life of humans (is destroyed). (cf : ii, 7)
Das Leben [der Menschen ist] schwierig [und] nur gering, und es ist mit Leid verbunden, aber die Wesen merken [es] nicht.
Life [of humans is] difficult [and] only [of] little [value(?)], and it is accompanied by suffering, but the beings do not realise [this].
Wie der Stockstreich im Wasser vergeht in einem Augenblick, so vergeht das Leben der Menschen.
Just like a blow with a stick fades in the water within a moment, so fades human life.
Und plötzlich kommt Leid [und] Armut, schneidet die Hoffnung der Angehörigen ab [und] vernichtet alle Wünsche.
And suddenly there comes suffering [and] poverty, cuts off the hope of the relatives [and] destroys all wishes.

Having seen (the sick one) and the dead one, I felt weariness [of life].
Again the Buddha stayed close to Śrāvastī with the community. As a driver then drove king Prasenajit. The axis of the cart broke and the spokes were scattered apart. (cf : ii, 9)

line.tr: Als Wagenfahrer fuhr der König Prasenajit. Da brach die Achse des Wagens, [und] die Speichen wurden auseinandergestreut.
As charioteer king Prasenajit was driving. Then the axle of the chariot broke, [and] the spokes were spread asunder.
Will I fall down from my great royal seat? Or will there be danger of my life?
If these were not there in the world, then the Buddha would not arise.
Um solche Nöte zu vertreiben, stehen hier die Alleswissenden auf.
In order to disperse such afflictions, here the omniscient ones rise.
Alt werden [auch] die Wagen des Königs, die sehr prachtvollen. Genau in derselben Weise (erreichen) auch die Körper das Alter.
[Even] the king's chariots, the very splendid ones, grow old. Exactly in the same way, the bodies also (reach) old age.
Wenn sie sorgfältig bewahrt [sind], bestehen die Wagen lange.
If they [are] carefully kept, the chariots exist [for a] long [time].
Er [scil. der Alleswissende] legte [sein] Obergewand ab [und] hielt [wtl. machte] [seinen] Rücken hoch zur Sonne [hin].
He [i.e. the Omniscient] took off [his] robe [and] held [lit. made] [his] back up to the sun.
Ananda saß auf den Knien, mit den beiden Handflächen streichelte(?) er den Körper des Buddha [und] rieb ihn.
Ananda sat on [his] knees, with both palms of [his] hands he stroked(?) the Buddha's body [and] rubbed it.

Es sprach zu dem Allwissenden Ānanda: "Es werden an dir gesehen [zeigen sich an dir], o Gott, das Anders-als-sonst-Sein [aller] fünf Sinnesorgane, Augen usw. Das Rissigsein der Haut [und] die Schlaffheit des Fleisches werden an dir gesehen [zeigen sich an dir]."

To the Omniscient Ānanda said: "On you, oh God, the being-different-than-usual of [all your] five sensory organs is seen, eyes etc. The crackedness of the skin [and] the limpness of the flesh is seen on you."
Shame be upon you, old age! You are of a mean kind [and] not noble.

line.tr: Das Feuer (der Sinneslust) glüht in [seinem] Geist, der ganze Körper brennt ihm wie ein Feuerbrand(?) vor Leidenschaft.
The fire (of sensual pleasure) glows in [his] mind, his whole body burns like a firebrand with passion.
Der Gott der (Götter), der Buddha, der Schutz [und] die Zuflucht, befand sich bei Śrāvastī. Dort rief er die Schüler ...
The god of (gods), the Buddha, the shelter [and] the protection, tarried near Śrāvastī. There he summoned the students ...
(In) diesem (Geist) wirken drei Vorstellungen: eine der Sinneslust, die zweite aber des Übelwollens, die dritte die des Leidzufügens.
(Within) this (spirit) three notions operate: one of sensuality, the second of ill will, the third the one of inflicting suffering.
... die üblen Fehler der Vorstellungen, vor denen hütet euch!
... the evil flaws of the imaginations, of these beware!
If he is (anxious for the smothering of the thoughts, however), constantly practices a disgust [at the body], [is] constantly mindful [and] controlling all six senses in, ...
[Wenn] er ... ständig das Abscheu-Empfinden [gegenüber dem Körper] übt, ständig bedachtsam [und] alle sechs Sinnesfunktionen im Zaum haltend[wtl. gezügelt habend] [ist], ...

[If] he ... at all times practices the feeling of disgust [with regard to the body], [when he is] at all times deliberate [and] keeping all six sensory functions in check [lit. having disciplined], ...

comments.comment: Uv 2 colophon-3.2

On the recto side down to line 7 this contains the ending of part 2 of the Kāmavarga (II), i.e. strophes 37d-40 in a 4x25 syllable-metre (rhythm: 5/5/8/7). In line 8 the Tṛṣṇāvarga (III) begins, strophes 1-7c, in a 4x18 metre (rhythm: 7/7/4).

The original manuscript is missing, but was a piece of leaf patched together from various fragments, about the left half of leaf 41. In places the writing was attrited strongly, particularly in the top part.

line.tr: ... von dem (Durst?) macht Abkehr!
... from the (thirst?) turn away!

(Überwindet dieses Verlangen, durch welches gebunden, Götter [und] Menschen) hier verlangend (stehen); der [rechte] Augenblick darf von euch nicht übergangen werden [oder: darf an euch nicht vorübergehen]. Die den [rechten] Augenblick übergangen haben, sind betrübt; in die Höllen [sind] sie (von) [ihren] Taten geführt.

(Overcome this desire, bound by which gods [and] humans stand) here, longing; the [right] moment must not be passed over by you [or: must not pass you]. Those [who] have passed over the [right] moment are deject; into the hells they [have been] led (by) [their] deeds.
Der [rechte] Augenblick darf von euch nicht übergangen werden. Die den [rechten] Augenblick übergangen haben, sind betrübt, in die Höllen [sind] sie (von) ]ihren] Taten geführt.
The [right] moment must not be missed by you. Those who have missed the [right] moment are sad, into hell they [are] brought (by) [their] deeds.
Wenn man die Liane, die nach Trinken Verlangen habende, in jeder Beziehung beseitigt hat, wendet sich dieses Leiden wieder [und] wieder ab.
If the liana, desiring to drink, has been removed in every respect, this suffering will turn away again [and] again.

Again he spoke another strophe: «[Just] as when the roots have not got damage a tree rises a second time if it is cut off … (so, if the roots of thirst) are not torn out with the consequences, the great wheel of sorrow of the beings turns again and again.» (cf : ii, 18)
(Wenn die Wurzeln des Durstes) mit den Konsequenzen nicht herausgerissen wurden, dreht sich das große Leidensrad der Wesen wieder [und] wieder.
(If the roots of thirst) were not torn out with the consequences, the big wheel of suffering of the beings turns again [and] again.
(Derartig) entstehen [wtl. erheben sich] viele Fehler der Wesen aus der Trübung Durst.
(In this way) many errors of the beings arise from the affliction [that is] thirst.
In Ursache [und] Wirkung täuscht (sie [scil. die Trübung Durst] hier) die Wesen, regt [sie] auf [und] macht ihnen Freude.
In cause [and] effect (here it [i.e. the defilement thirst]) deceives the beings, excites [them] [and] gladdens them.
Die alles tötende Trübung Durst erzeugt hier die Unersättlichkeit der Wesen.
The defilement of thirst, killing all, here creates the insatiability of the good beings.

If there is water in a pond, the animals there, the fishes, and so on, rejoice themselves. Likewise, in whose mind is the water of thirst … the kleśa animals feel happy in his thought and mind and do not leave him alone. (cf : ii, 19)

Wenn Wasser im Teich ist, finden dort Gefallen die Tiere, Fische, usw. So [auch] (in) wessen (Geist) das Wasser des Durstes ist ..., die (Trübungs)tiere fühlen sich in dessen Denken [und] Fühlen wohl, sie verlassen ihn nicht.

If there is water in the pond, the animals, fish, etc. enjoy it there. Thus [also] (in) whose (mind) there is the water of thirst ... , the animals (of defilement) feel good in his thought [and] feeling, they do not leave him.
... macht er des Gewinnes (wegen) ...
... he does (for the sake) of profit ...

line.tr: (diligence) is the beginning of all virtues. (diligence) in the practice ... diligence in the laws [16d]

line.tr: diligence in meditation and in good effort. (By) diligence ... oneself life-long. [17d] At another time the Buddha (was staying in the Jetavana) ...
was a mountain slope. There was the great sage directed towards a single goal, (Mahākāśyapa by) name. [18d] Unknown, separated, directed towards a single goal ...
avoiding, per(forming) his good meditation, in the ways of monks he was fulfilled. [19d] Him, the one being in a good way, (the Buddha with the divine glance) saw
(and he called) his pupils: Entering (with the) mind (I saw): Mahākāśyapa [is] in his good behavior. [20d] With regard to this (the Buddha) spoke the strophe: ....
“If the wise destroys (the negligence) by diligence, at what time [ever], ... afterwards he is (not) careless in virtues. [21d] Having climbed up to the palace of wisdom ...
If the wise one at whatever time kills the negligences with diligence, …
Wenn der Verständige (die Lässigkeiten) durch (Nicht)lässigkeit, zu welcher Zeit [auch immer], vernichtet, ... ist er danach (nicht) lässig in den Tugenden.
If the wise destroys (the negligences) with (non-)negligence, at [whatever] time, ... afterwards he is (not) negligent in the virtues.
(he sees), like he was standing on the mountain, as if they were on earth ... he sees all these”. [22d] Mahākāśyapa destroyed the negligences by diligence ...
.... (he sees) all four retinues ... [23] ... shelter and refuge [for him], who [is] his a man. (In the town?) Śrāvastī ...
... in the Kausala-countries the monks ... [24] (Without) effort in (manifold) ways. They ate alms ...
... slept like thehouseholders. [25] (The Buddha) saw ... the monks, all good behaviors and rules completely disappeared. From the Jetavana ...
they were. [26d] He himself wore rags, the earth ... that covered them the evil. [27b] Than he sat down on [his] seat [and] instructed them ...
Darauf setzte er sich [scil. der Buddha] auf einen Sitz und unterwies sie.
Thereupon he [i.e. the Buddha] sat down on a seat and instructed them.
[27d] Are you not saturated by the sufferings of the five birth, (you monks)? ... “Death is our (only certain) possession”. This you said in the great assembly amongst the community ...
There is here no community (of) monks (as long as) [he] continuously takes pleasure in idleness, he who has gone from the house. Even the virtues [already] obtained ...
Nicht gibt es hier solange eine Gemeinde (der) Mönche ..., (solange) an der Lässigkeit ständig Gefallen findet der aus dem Haus Gegangene.
There will not be a community (of) monks here ..., (as long as) the one having gone from the house finds pleasure in idleness.
might effect. [29d] Then the Omniscient said to them, in order to ... to evoke world weariness, to generate love of monkshood, ... (two strophes). ... [30d]
By (effort), by diligence, by self-control, the learned one ... [31b] such a being, the flood does not crush it. (He spoke the second) strophe ... [31d] ...
of the one who is aware, the being of pure thought, the one considerately living according to the law, the diligent one ...

comments.comment: Contains strophes 16b-32c of the first section of the Apramādavarga (IV) in a 14, 11, 11, 11 metre, the rhythm in a is 7/7, in b-d it is 7/4. The many gaps in the text require a lot of supplementing in the translation, but these supplements lack certainty, particularly in the case of larger gaps.

Two non-continuous fragments belonging to the same leaf. The first encompasses the left side of the leaf, slightly more damaged at the top, to the string hole. The second is a larger fragment from the center of the leaf, damaged on all sides.

comments.comment: Because of its scantiness this leaf fragment, belonging to part 2 of the Apramādavarga (IV), could not be translated. Since only one strophe number is preserved, recto and verso side cannot be established with certainty. The metre appears to be 4x12 syllables, in a 5/7 rhythm. It is certain, however, that line a4 “with a broken axle he is then (much) dejected” (most likely to be supplemented to give meṃ(ṣtr olyapotse :)) belongs to a translation of Uv IV 17 and renders chinnākṣaḥ śocate bhṛśam. This then also then gives us (spelkke) yāmi “(The sage) may (strive)” as the end of the translation of Uv IV 16 dhīraḥ parākramet.

internalComments.comment: What's up with the agreement on atākatte (instead of atākacce).

The translation is obviously wrong. It should be: "One should rather smite the stupa with his own hand than speak false blame against the good who behave morally." "The stupa" refers to the grave of the Buddha here.
Why is ainake translated as "worthy".

line.tr: Die gehörten Gesetze hatte ich erfasst, [aber] alles habe ich vergessen, es wird von mir (allein) nicht getragen die Last(?).
The laws heard I had grasped, [but] all I have forgotten; by me (alone), the burden(?) is not [to be] borne.
Wenn die Wesen [aus sich] selbst die Taten tun, genießen sie eben selbst die schreckliche Frucht davon in den Geburten.
If the beings do the deeds [on their] own [initiative], they themselves will savour the terrible fruit thereof in [their] incarnations.
Die unglücklichen Wesen machten sich selbst schlecht; sie hatten falsche Ansicht hervorgebracht und legten Tadel auf die Guten.
The unhappy beings blamed themselves; they had developed false views and laid reproach onto the good ones.
Die vielen Buddhas weisen schon, [wenn] sie in der Welt aufstehen, einer den anderen auf das unglücklich[ste] Höllenwesen hin.
The many Buddhas, [when] they arise in the world, already indicate one to another the [most] miserable creature of hell.
Den Eifer nimmt ein solcher den guten Wesen.
Such a one takes the diligence away from the good beings.
Mit solchem Pfeil des Tadelsprechens trifft er sie [scil. die guten] ins Herz.
With such an arrow of administering reproach he strikes them [i.e. the good ones] in the heart.
Die Mönche gehen hier (auf) [ihren] Wunsch aus dem Hause [und] werden Lehrer.
Here the monks leave the house (upon) [their own] wish [and] become teachers.

comments.comment: This leaf is severely damaged; it contains strophes 11d-19 of the Vācāvarga (VIII); , which is less damaged, contains strophes 12-18, all in a 4x25 syllable-metre (rhythm 5/5/8/7). Thus, both leaves supplement each other and cover the same content, i.e. part of the conversation between Buddha and Ānanda after Buddha’s first sickness; cf. also and . On the contents see , and , .
The original manuscript is missing, but consisted of three non-continuous fragments, in their turn composed of smaller fragments. Badly damaged, the writing frequently attrited.

This leaf immediately follows and and is the next but one after . It includes strophes 20b-28 and includes strophes 26-32, both of the Vācāvarga (VIII) in a 4x25 syllable–metre (rhythm 5/5/8/7). Thus both leaves are identical for strophes 26-28. The great gaps in strophe 20 – from the second line the beginning (11 syllables) is missing as is the entire line 3 – do not allow us to clearly see the connection to the following. However, verse Uv VIII 1, quoted in a4, is identical to Dhp 302, and the commentary to Dhp tells the story of the murder of the nun Sundarī, which was passed off by the Tīrthas as Buddha’s concubine and which they later had murdered in order to blame the killing on the Buddha and his community. Due to the king’s intervention, however, the real murderers are discovered and the Tīrthas are punished, while the reverence for the Buddha is even growing. For a translation and further references cf. , III: 189ff. The fact that also in our version this story is also associated with Uv VIII 1 is attested to by strophes 25ff., which apparently are dealing with the solving of the crime. The name Sundarī, too, seems to be preserved in the fragment.

line.tr: Die gehörten Gesetze hatte ich erfasst, [aber] alles habe ich vergessen, es wird von mir (allein) nicht getragen die Last(?).
The laws heard I had grasped, [but] all I have forgotten; by me (alone), the burden(?) is not [to be] borne.
Dieser große Unwille kam dem Buddha.
This great reluctance came over the Buddha.
If the beings do the deeds [out of] themselves, they receive themselves the terrible fruit of it in the [re]births. (cf : ii, 24–25)
Wenn die Wesen [aus sich] selbst die Taten tun, genießen sie eben selbst die schreckliche Frucht davon in den Geburten.
If the beings do the deeds [on their] own [initiative], they themselves will savour the terrible fruit thereof in [their] incarnations.
Die unglücklichen Wesen machten sich selbst schlecht; sie hatten falsche Ansicht hervorgebracht und legten Tadel auf die Guten.
The unhappy beings blamed themselves; they had developed false views and laid reproach onto the good ones.
I do not see another hell [that is] so large as when they put unfounded blame and evil rumour on the good. (cf : ii, 25)

If [someone] puts blame and evil rumour on him without reason [lit. deed], he dies because of that [and] is [re]born in hell, many times, [for] many [re]births, and he suffers [lit. sees] many sorrows. (cf : ii, 25)
Die vielen Buddhas weisen schon, [wenn] sie in der Welt aufstehen, einer den anderen auf das unglücklich[ste] Höllenwesen hin.
The many Buddhas, [when] they arise in the world, already indicate one to another the [most] miserable creature of hell.
Den Eifer nimmt ein solcher den guten Wesen.
Such a one takes the diligence away from the good beings.
Mit solchem Pfeil des Tadelsprechens trifft er sie [scil. die guten] ins Herz.
With such an arrow of administering reproach he strikes them [i.e. the good ones] in the heart.
Auf das Gesetz des Buddha streut er den Staub des Tadels.
Over the Law of the Buddha he sprinkles the dust of reproach.
Sie werden zweifelsvoll, gestört [und] scheelen Blickes auf ihn.
They grow doubtful, disturbed [and ] of [= throw] misgiving glances towards him
Nicht möchte er unbegründeten Tadel von Guten, die die [sittliche] Haltung bewahrt haben, [aus]sprechen.
May he not speak unfounded blame against the good ones, that have kept up the [moral] conduct.
Die Mönche gehen hier (auf) [ihren] Wunsch aus dem Hause [und] werden Lehrer.
Here the monks leave the house (upon) [their own] wish [and] become teachers.

The original manuscript is missing, but was complete in length with the top half of the left side missing as far as the schnurloch and slightly beyond. The top was generally more severely damaged.

line.tr: Höret das Gesetz mit Liebe [und] mit dem ganzen Selbst! Den das Gesetz Vortragenden sehet gut an [rufet] Glauben an ihn hervor!
Listen to the Law with love [and] with [your] entire self! The one proclaiming the Law, regard [him] well [, and] belief in him [you shall] call up!
... (wich er?) aus [und] machte sich eine Lüge zurecht. Er leugnete die gefassten Be-/Entschlüsse ab [mit den Worten]: "Nicht ich solche (Gespräche?) ..."
... (he talked?) around [it] [and] prepared a lie for himself. He disclaimed the decisions made [saying]: "Not I such (conversations?) ..."
Mag ein anderer Mensch täglich schon früh aufstehen, mag er [sich] mit Asche den Körper abreiben, ...
May another man get up early in the morning every day, may he rub [his] body down with ashes, ...
... (ohne) Opfer wurde ich von dem Übel erlöst [und] führte mich(?) [ging(?)] den Weg zur Brahmawelt.
... (without) sacrifice I was released from evil [and] led myself(?) [went(?) the way to the brahma-world.
It will have been uttered by fools. (cf : ii, 32)

(Und) [ein böses Wort], auch wenn [es] entlassen wurde, soll man (nicht) wieder von sich geben; der es Entlassende wird [dadurch] gebunden, denn die Edlen geben [es] nicht so von sich [in dem Gedanken]: "Es wird von Toren entlassen sein ...".

(And) [an evil] word, even when [it] has been released, one shall [no] more utter; the one releasing it is [thereby] bound, for the noble ones do not utter [it] in this way [thinking]: "It will be released by fools...".

comments.comment: Uv 9.8

Includes strophes 50 – 63 of the Karmavarga (IX) in a 4x12 syllable-metre (rhythm = 5/4/3). Between the two fragments on average 12-16 syllables are missing, while the top of the leaf, containing about 6-10 syllables is lost entirely.

The original manuscript is missing, but consisted of two non-continuous fragments, one being a piece from the centre of the leaf, beginning at the schnurloch, the other a remnant of the leaf's right side.

line.tr: (The king together) with [his] army will stay with his decision and [his] army will not come again towards you. (cf : ii, 36)
If their glory disappears, then others conquer him. (cf : ii, 36)
Er [scil. König Prasannaka] beschied den Śreṣṭhaka zu sich [und] lud ihn zu einem Wunsche ein/stellte ihm einen Wunsch frei [wtl. forderte ihn zu einem Wunsche auf]:
He [i.e. king Prasannaka] summoned Śreṣṭhaka to him [and] invited him to [utter] a wish/granted him a wish.

line.tr: Er selbst lud sieben Tage [lang] den Alleswissenden mit der Gemeinde ein.
He himself entertained the Omniscient with [his] community [for] seven days.

Er hegte den Wunsch [und] fiel dem Alleswissenden zu Füßen: Weil ich den Wesen sieben Tage hindurch unbekümmert gab und weil ich den Buddha (mit der Gemeinde sieben Tage (lang) einlud), durch diese gute Tat möchte ich die Würde eines Allwissenden erlangen.

He felt the wish [and] fell before the feet of the omniscient: As I have given to the beings unconcernedly [for] seven days, and as I have hosted the Buddha (with the community [for] seven days), by this good deed I want to attain the dignity of an omniscient
You did a great deed, you achieved your idea.57 You will later be a help and stay for all those of the five birth [forms]. (cf : ii, 37)
Die drei Ānantarya [Todsünden] insgesamt beging Devadatta und wurde in der Avīci-Hölle [wieder-]geboren.
The three Ānantarya [deadly sins] together Devadatta committed, and [he] was [re-]born in the Avīci-hell.
Die drei Todsünden insgesamt beging Devadatta, [und] er wurde in der Avīci-Hölle [wieder]geboren.
The three deadly sins together Devadatta committed, [and] he was [re]born in the Avīci-hell.
(Zwei Höllenwächter(?)) legten ihm den Körper auf Kies.
(Two guardians of hell(?)) laid his body onto gravel.
Mit einem eisernen Pfahl durchstachen sie ihm heftig den Scheitel: Auseinandergeschleudert wurde ihm [in] klein[en Stücken] der ganze Kopf.
With an iron stake the stabbed the crown of his head violently: in small [bits] his whole head was dashed apart.
(O Upati)sya, ich erdulde schreckliches Leid.
(Oh Upati)sya, I endure terrible suffering.
Dennoch erinnert sich meiner der Alleswissende mitleidig.
Still the Omniscient remembers me, full of compassion.

This leaf, immediately following , includes strophes 63d-76 of the Karmavarga (IX). 4x12 syllable-metre, rhythm = 5/7.

line.tr: Er [scil. der Gott Upoṣatha] kam des Abends zusammen mit diesen 500 Göttern.
He [i.e. the god Upoṣatha] at night came together with these 500 gods.

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 a7 a8 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7 b8

line.tr: Wer den Wunsch haben sollte, in der göttlichen Welt [wieder]geboren zu werden, der übe sich hier in den vier Gesetzen!
Who[ever] should have the wish to be [re]born in the divine world, let him exercise himself here in the four laws!
And if it (= faith) creates the thought of desire for these virtues, it gives up life, possession[s] [and] everything because of those virtues. (cf : ii, 38)
Und [wenn] er [scil. der Gläubige] dabei den Gedanken des Verlangens nach solchen Tugenden bewirkt, gibt er der Tugenden halber Leben, Besitz [und] alles hin.
And [if] he [i.e. the believer] thereby causes the thought of longing for such virtues, for the sake of [these] virtues he renounces life, possession[s] [and] all.
Der Gläubige begehrt stets die Guten zu sehen; mit allem Eifer das Gesetz zu hören [und] Gabe zu geben, [ist er] stets wünschend, um die Gesetzesjuwelen zu sammeln.
The believer at all times desires to see the good ones; [he is] always wishing to hear the Law with great zeal [and] give gifts, to gather the jewels of the law.
Der Buddha, der Lehrer, befand sich damals in Rājagṛha.
The Buddha, the teacher, was in Rājagṛha then.

line.n: b3 b4 b5 b6 b7 b8

line.tr: Von mir ist diese Ansicht fest gefasst: Es gibt nicht Gabe, auch nicht Opfer, gute Tat [und] böse Tat, beide gibt es nicht. Ihr aber, ihr Śākya-Anhänger, betrügt zahllose Wesen. Der in Gabe Reiche wird bei Göttern [und] Menschen [wieder]geboren, [so] tragt ihr zahllosen Wesen das Lob der Gabe vor. Ich werde nicht das Gift eurer Worte trinken, ich werde weder dir noch einem anderen eine Gabe geben. Dieses wisse gefälligst, geh fort aus meinem Hause!

By me this view is held strongly: there is no gift nor sacrifice, good deed [and] bad deed, neither exists. But you, you Śākya-followers, deceive numberless beings. The one rich in gift[s] will be [re]born among gods [and] men, [thus] you proclaim the praise of the gift to numberless beings. I shall not drink the poison of your words, neither to you nor to anyone else I shall give a gift. Know this, if you please, and leave my house!
Then Ānanda went to other houses for alms. [But] he went after eating [and] this he told to the Buddha. (cf : ii, 39)
Böses ist immer von Bösen zu erwarten, sei nicht verstört!
Evil is always to be expected from evil ones, do not be disturbed!

The original manuscript is partly missing, but consisted of several severely damaged fragments, that are partly unconnected. In all, the fragment preserved thus included the greater part of the left half of the leaf.
The original manuscript is found under press mark (Michaël Peyrot, 27 April 2019).

comments.comment: Includes strophes 58-66 of the Śraddhāvarga (X) in a 4x13+21 syllable-metre (rhythm = 5/8 and 8/8/5). The many gaps render a translation that is based on supplementation to a large extent extremely problematic, particularly in places where there are no parallels. To clarify the situation in a5ff, however, one may refer to the tale of Mahākāśyapa and the goddess, which is transmitted in the commentary to Dhp 118; cf. , II: 265ff.: a pious woman gave alms of rice to the Mahākāśyapa, but that same day was bitten by a venomous snake and died. As a reward for her meritorious deed she is immediately reborn as a goddess, and even as a goddess continues her meritorious work by caring for Mahākāśyapa. But when the latter realises that he is being taken attended to by a goddess, he prohibits her from doing so a second and a third time. The goddess refuses to be sent away. But the Buddha, who is staying in Jetavana, appears before the goddess and explains to her that Mahākāśyapa was only doing what is right by refusing her service. While the narrative frame in our text is different, the goddess’ continuous attendance to Mahākāśyapa appears to be a central feature of the tale here too, even though the text is very much fragmented and obscure, especially in lines b4-b5.

The original manuscript is missing, but consisted of a part of the left side (the beginning - about 1-3 syllables - being lost) as well as a remnant of the right side, in turn composed of five smaller fragments, and still very incomplete. The right margin was also missing.

line.tr: Deshalb sei du, o Ānanda, nicht unglücklich [und] auch nicht bekümmert!
Therefore, oh Ānanda, don't be unhappy [or] sorrowful either!
In a time to come there will be here, Ānanda, wandering monks … (cf : ii, 44)
Sie werden an Worten [und] Gesprächen bei Tag Gefallen finden [und] bei Nacht an Schlaf.
They will find pleasure in words [and] conversations during the day and in sleep during the night.

In words and talk they will find pleasure by day, and by night in sleep. But if by these word disputes (they will get into a fight with) each other … mutual enmity. They will destroy the monastic thought and mind, [and] among each other there will be disrespect. (cf : ii, 44)
Sie werden das mönchische Denken [und] Fühlen zugrunde richten, [und] untereinander wird Nichtachtung sein.
They will ruin monkish thinking [and] feeling, and there will be disrespect amongst themselves.
[Wenn] sie jedoch (aus) Hass viel[fach] Vergehen [und] Fehler sich gegenseitig vorwerfen, ....
[If], however, (out of) hate, they accuse each other many [times] of offences and demerits, ...
The thinkers that have descended [it] will drive away the kleśa fetters of Māra.
Ich verbarg weder etwas, noch auch verhüllte ich etwas, [und] nie tat ich eine Sache, welche euch (nicht zugänglich) gewesen wäre.
Neither have I hidden anything, nor even concealed anything, [and] never have I done anything that would (not) have been (accessible) to you.

line.tr: Dieses hörten sie, [und] vielfach spalteten sie darauf ihr Denken.
This they heard, [and] manifold then they divided their thinking.
Or isn't there any way here that makes sorrow disappear?

line.tr: Die unglücklichen (Wesen haben den Weg verfehlt), auch große Weise. Auf falschem Wege suchen sie die Erlösung, deshalb erlangen sie [sie] nicht.
The unhappy (beings have missed [their] way), even great sages. On the wrong path they seek redemption, therefore they do not obtain [it].

[Just as] the waters from the rivers, if they descend towards the Ganges, all become glorious and all go towards the ocean, so to the Brahma world … all are turned towards the nirvāṇa and leave the house. (cf : ii, 50)
Durch das Drehen des Gesetzesrades erlöste er [scil. der Buddha] die Wesen.
By turning the wheel of the law, he [i.e. the Buddha] has redeemed the beings.
... durch das Drehen des Gesetzesrades ...
... by turning the Wheel of the Law ...
"Gesetzesrad" [ist das], was darśanamārga [Weg der Erkenntnis] mit Namen genannt wird.
"Wheel of the Law" [this is], what is called darśanamārga [path of seeing] by name.
Up and down turn those spokes when the wheel turns: those which are down turn upwards, [and] from above again downwards. (cf : ii, 51)

Innerhalb von fünfzehn Augenblicken drehen sich die fünf Skandhas, - [daher] der Name Dharmacakra [Rad des Gesetzes] - oben [und] unten um. Die Speichen, welche, wenn das Rad sich dreht, [gerade] unten sind, die drehen sich nach oben um [und] von oben wiederum nach unten.

Within fifteen moments the five skandhas, - [hence] the name dharmacakra [wheel of the law] - turn around above [and] below. The spokes, which, when the wheel turns, are below, these turn upwards [and] from above downwards again.

Wenn hier ein Mönch das dreifache Wissen haben sollte, [daher] abgesondert bei Verehrung sich fernhaltend, den Tod zerschmetternd [und] von [sündigen] Einflüssen frei, so machen ihn [doch] die unwissenden Toren verächtlich, da sie wissen: "[Er ist nur] von wenigen gekannt."

If a monk here should have the threefold knowledge, keeping away, therefore, if venerated, shattering death [and] free from [sinful] influences, [still] the ignorant fools will ridicule him, for they know: "[He is] known [only} to few."
If a being is obtaining food and drink here, even if he is of bad nature, it is [worthy of] reverence for them.

line.n: a7 a8 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5
line.tr: This the Buddha let them know clearly: «Not even the famous and the [well] known is my pupil [40c], [but who] practices moral behaviour, [is] always self-controlled, [and is] going to only one goal [40d], who may have the threefold knowledge, who can recall [his] former births [41a], calls forth a divine pure view, [and] lets disappear [bad] influences. Only if he has called forth the threefold knowledge is he a pupil of the Buddha and becomes an arhat called “traividya” [41c]. If one treats him badly, one is besmirched with great hell [41d]. But if he who does not practice moral behaviour obtains food from elsewhere, he treats badly excellent ones that are excluded from it for this or that reason, including the great arhats [42b]. If someone always and always goes to see the householders, [and] really lets go off the monastic zeal, [42c] him they honour, [but] he causes damage to others [42d]. Through the honour of this [re]birth the fool is as if confused [and] considers life immortal [43a]. If he has to utter a lie, harsh speech, or senseless talk, for the glory of food he says everything [43b]. He does as if servant’s work for the householder, and if he guards their thought more than the teacher’s, and treats others badly, he goes to the hells afterwards.» (cf : ii, 52–53)

Fürwahr, nicht der Gekannte [und] Berühmte [wtl. der Gerußte] [ist] mein Schüler. Die [sittliche Haltung] muss er bewahrt haben, stets gezügelt nur auf ein Ziel gerichtet gehend, [und] das dreifache Wissen muss er haben, [d.h. einer sein], der sich [seiner] früheren Geburten erinnern kann, den göttlichen, klaren Blick hervorruft und alle [sündigen] Einflüsse schwinden macht.

Indeed, not the known one [and] the famous [lit. one known] [is] my student. The [moral conduct] he must have kept up, walking, always disciplined, oriented towards one goal only, [and] the threefold knowledge he must have, [i.e. he must be one], who remembers [his] earlier incarnations, [who] evokes the divine, clear gaze and makes all [sinful] influences fade.
Wenn diesen [scil. den Traividya genannten Arhat] einer verächtlich macht, wird er in die große Hölle geworfen.
If someone derides this one [i.e. the arhat named Traividya], he will be thrown into the great hell.
[Wenn] diesen[scil. den Traividya] einer verächtlich macht, so wird er in die große Hölle geworfen.
[If some]one ridicules this one [i.e. Traividya], he will be thrown into the great hell.
Durch die Verehrung [und] Schmeichelei dieser Existenz ist der Törichte förmlich verwirrt [und] hält das Leben für unsterblich.
Due to the reverence [and] flattery of this existence, the fool is positively confused and believes life to be immortal.
Durch die Verehrung [und] Schmeichelei dieser Existenz ist der Törichte förmlich verwirrt [und] vertraut auf ein ewiges Leben.
Due to the reverence [and] flattery of this existence, the fool is positively confused and trusts in eternal life.
Er [scil. der Törichte] wird aber, [wenn] er mehr als auf den Lehrer auf das Denken dieser achtet [und] die anderen verächtlich macht, hinterher in die Höllen gehen.
He [i.e. the foolish one], however, will, [if] he heeds more than the teacher the thinking of these ones [and] ridicules others, go into the hells afterwards.
Einige [von ihnen] riefen Zwietracht hervor [oder: riefen bei sich Neid hervor], einige zeigten böse Gesinnung aus Neid auf die Gabenherren, die Häuser [und] Besitztümer.
Some [of them] evoked strife [or: evoked envy in themselves], some displayed an ill disposition out of envy for donators, houses [and] possessions.

Es sahen solcher Art Mönche gar nicht auf die, welche das Saṃghāṭī-Gewand angezogen hatten. Einige [von ihnen] riefen Zwietracht hervor, einige zeigten böse Gesinnung aus Neid auf die Gabenherren, die Häuser und Besitztümer.

This kind of monks did not at all look at those who had donned the Saṃghāṭī-robe. Some [of them] evoked discord, some showed an evil disposition out of envy for the donators, the houses and possessions.

line.tr: Who lets go all clinging, gives up all things, cuts off all bonds, [his] mind turned away from all things, he can indeed clearly recognise the taste of monkhood. (cf : ii, 54)
Wer alle Haftungen löst, alle Dinge hinter sich lässt, alle Fesseln zerschneidet, [wer] den Geist von allen Dingen abgewendet(?) [hat], kann in der Tat den Geschmack des Mönchtums genau erkennen.
Who[ever] undoes all attachments, leaves all things behind him, severs all bonds, [whoever has] turned the mind away(?) from all things, [he] indeed can perceive clearly the taste of monkhood.
The lord, [or] the beloved takes this, the army may reduce [lit. make] that to a scent, [or] fire burns it, [or] water carries it off.
Die Tat nimmt den einen die Besitztümer, Diebe rauben sie den anderen. Der Herr, die Geliebte nimmt dieses [rest of translation missing in [[Schmidt 1974]].]
The deed takes away the possessions from some; thieves rob it from others. The lord, the lover takes this [rest of translation missing in Schmidt 1974.]
Das Karman nimmt den einen die Besitztümer, Diebe rauben sie auch den anderen. Der Herr, die Geliebte nimmt dieses, das Heer wird jenes zum [bloßen] Geruch machen.
The deed takes the possessions of some, thieves rob them off others. The lord, the lover takes this, the army will make that a [mere] smell.
Der Herr, die Geliebte nimmt dieses, das Heer wird jenes zum [bloßen] Geruch machen.
The lord, the lover takes this, the army will turn that into a [mere] smell.
If someone himself gives up [his] property [and] possessions out of faith [and] weariness of the world, he will not gather [possessions] for a second time. (cf : ii, 54–55)
Wenn einer [von] selbst Besitz [und] Vermögen aufgibt im Glauben [und] Weltüberdruss, wird er [sie] auch nicht zum zweitenmal sammeln.
If someone gives up possession[s] [and] wealth [of] his own [account], in faith [and] world-weariness, he will not gather [them] a second time.
But if he who has left the house, eating begging [alms], gathers possessions, he is besmirched with great blame. (cf : ii, 55)
Wenn aber der, welcher aus dem Hause gegangen und Bettelbrot essend ist, Besitztümer sammelt, wird er mit großem Makel beworfen.
If, however, he who has gone from the house and is eating food he has begged for gathers possessions, he will be pelted by great fault.

If you [pl.] had been concerned about reverence and flattery, [and] you [pl.] had yourselves further stayed in your [own] hous[es], then each of you would certainly have obtained reverence from his male and female slaves, [and] gathered possessions. (: ii, 55, slightly different)
Ihr seid jetzt in dem Wunsche nach Erlösung aus dem Hause gegangen, [aber dennoch] lasst ihr euch (durch) die Bande des Verlangens nach Verehrung [und] Schmeichelei binden.
Wishing for release, you have now gone from the house, [but still] you let yourselves be bound (by) the bond of desire for reverence [and] flattery.

[Just] as when a miserable dog is wormy, [then] worms eat from his wounds by day and by night, so when the worms of profit are born in the wound of insatiability, they eat his dharma body by day and by night [and] he gets no rest. (cf : ii, 55)

Wie wenn er ein elender Hund wäre, welcher Würmer hat - es fressen ihm bei Tag [und] Nacht die Würmer [an den] Wunden -, so fressen ihm die Würmer des Gewinns, wenn sie in der Wunde der Unersättlichkeit entstehen, [an] seinem Rechtskörper bei Tag [und] Nacht, er findet keine Ruhe.

As if he was a miserable dog that has [been infected with] maggots - the maggots eat away [at his] wounds by day [and] by night -, thus the maggots of profit, when they appear in the wound of insatiability, eat away [at] his body of law by day [and] by night, he finds no peace.
Die mönchische Zurückhaltung führt er Haus für Haus, gibt das Studium in den zwölf Arten auf, weist die Versenkung zurück, hält das Wissen fern; [nur] nach Ehre [und] Schmeichelei verlangt er.
Monkish reserve he leads from house to house, he gives up the study in the twelve ways, rejects meditation, keeps knowledge away; [only] reverence [and] flattery he desires.
Haushalter [und] aus dem Hause Gegangene sollten nur mir stets Verehrung machen, nicht vor einem anderen sollten sie sich zur Erde neigen.
Householders [and those who] have gone from the house at all times should make veneration only to me, before no other they should bow to the ground.
If he sees or hears the honour of somebody else, he is burnt by the fire of jealousy: «this should be put together with that!» (cf : ii, 55)
Wenn er von der Verehrung eines anderen sieht oder hört, wird er vom Feuer der Eifersucht verzehrt [wtl. verbrannt] [in dem Gedanken]: ""Der müsste sich mit diesem und jenem zusammen hinstellen."
If he sees or hears of reverence [paid] to another he is consumed [lit. burned] by the fire of jealousy [thinking]: "This one should be standing with this one and that one."
Ihr, denen hier die Neigung nach Verehrung [und] Schmeichelei entstanden [ist], lasset eure Gedanken sich [davon] abkehren wie von einer Kotgrube!
You, [in] whom [has] developed an inclination to reverence [and] flattery, let your thoughts turn away [from it] as if from a cesspit!

line.tr: Als sechzehn Erscheinungsformen habend wird diese Versenkung gelehrt.
As having sixteen forms of appearance this meditation is taught.
Das Zählen, das wird hier in fünf Erscheinungsformen gelehrt: [Richtig] zählen, weniger, mehr, Mischen und Reinhalten.
Counting is taught in five variants here: counting [correctly], less, more, mixing, and keeping pure.

Das Zählen wird hier in fünf Erscheinungsformen gelehrt: [Richtig] Zählen, weniger, mehr, Mischen und Reinhalten. ... Reinhalten ist: Fünf[mal] atmet er ein [und] zählt das [als] fünf, oder fünfmal atmet er aus [und] zählt das ebenfalls [als] fünf.

Counting is taught here in five forms of appearance: counting [correctly], less, more, mixing and keeping pure. ... Keeping pure [is this]: five [times] he inhales [and] counts this [as] five, or five times he exhales [and] also counts this [as] five.

Mehr zählen ferner [ist] hier: Wie oft er ausatmet, zählt er weniger als das als Ausatmen. Vermischen [ist]: Was er ausatmet, das fasst er [als] Einatmen auf, oder [was] er einatmet, zählt er [als] Ausatmen.

Counting more, furthermore, [is] here: As often as he exhales, he counts less than that as exhaling. Mixing [is]: What he exhales, he regards [as] inhaling, or [what] he inhales, he counts [as] exhaling.
Going after the wind is: when he inhales through the nose and the wind enters inside him, [then] it goes after it. (cf : ii, 61)

comments.comment: In b1 instead of 'five' one would expect 'seven', and 'less than that' should probably read 'more than that'.

This leaf, which, according to leaf number and content, belongs to the Smṛtivarga (XV), in strophes 9-22 contained in it deals with the ānāpānasmṛti, the meditation relating to breathing in and out. On this matter cf. Abhidh-k 6, p. 153ff. The metre is 14/11/11/11 syllables in the rhythm 7/7 and 7/4.
The original manuscript is missing, but, like and (alongside which it was found) was damaged only at the top edge and otherweise almost complete. Contained leaf number 220.

astarñe for astaräññe.

According to n. 1 the reading satāṣṣä should be corrected to satāṣṣä(ṃ) in the transcription, also yāmastär to yamastär.
astarñe for astaräññe.
According to n. 3 the verse interpunction is missing after ṣaṃṣträ and ṣiś should be corrected to piś.

line.tr: In fünfhundert Geburten tötet ihr euch gegenseitig.
In five hundred births you kill each other.
... als ein zu Buddha, dem Meister, aus dem Hause Gegangener, in der reinen Zucht Stehender, das Gute [und] Böse Erkennender, mach jetzt Abkehr von jener Schlange!
As one having left the house for the Buddha, the Master, [as one] standing in the pure discipline, [as one] knowing good [and] bad, turn away now from that snake!
With evil-minded spirit he came to the snake [and] and tore up the body of the snake. (Thus) the Arhat proclaimed: [22d] See, you venerable ones ...

Even the word of the whole community that one would not accept, he left my teaching. That snake desired with him the letting go of hate and enmity and lasting forgiveness. That one had gone from the house, [but] he could not ...
... (There)upon many monks there felt world weariness [and] let the thought be fulfilled: hate and enmity is (not) ...
... One must not let the (evil-minded) spirit go to another on, in whatever way. [23d] Through forgiveness of others ...

... he is in other births; in hell, among animals and hungry ghosts he sees countless terrible sufferings. [24d] Whatever is his [moral] conduct or whatever is [his] meditation, [his] fervour and [his] insight, all (is through hate and enmity) from him ...

... he reproaches, he urges (?). In many births he does a deed [that leads] to dissociation and vexation (?). Displeasure [and] misery without count he suffers here in the five kinds of existence. [25d] As (in) another time ...
In vielen Geburten tut er Tat zu Missmut(?) [und] Verdruss.
In many births he does deed [that leads] to discord(?) and vexation.
... In Śrāvastī a householder countlessly [often] was desirous of the birth of a son. Thereupon another being received birth in the womb of his wife. Immediately ...
In Śrāvastī a householder incessantly cherished the wish for the birth of a son. Then another being received birth in the womb of his wife. (cf : ii, 63)
In Śrāvastī hegte ein Haushalter (zahllos) [oft] den Wunsch nach der Geburt eines Sohnes.
In Śrāvastī, a householder (countlessly) [often] held the wish for the birth of a son.
Darauf empfing dann ein anderes Wesen in dem Leibe seiner Frau die Geburt.
Thereupon another being received birth in his wife's womb.
[26d] She only needed the chance to find a sewer, she wanted to spread out there [and] gladly then eat the dung from the palm of [her] hand (like) honey and sugar ...
Sie brauchte nur die Gelegenheit zu einer Kotgrube zu finden, [so] möchte sie sich dort hinstreuen [und] dann freudig den Kot auf [ihrer] Handfläche (wie) Honig und Zucker essen.
She only needed to find the opportunity of a cesspit, [and] she would spread herself out there [and] then happily eat the excrement[s] on the palm of [her] hand, (like) honey and sugar.
... step by step she, as it were, the whole house was filled by the bad smell. [27d] In this boy, too, the desire arose to be eating urine [and] dung. his ...
Auch in diesem Knaben erhob sich die Begierde nach dem Essen von Harn [und] Kot.
In this boy also the desire arose to eat urine [and] faeces.
... (They gave?) him in the evening (?) miye and paṣkārro. Everything rained in this house. [28d] For three times at night the filth rained there. They bathed, they washed him ...
... going the almsround. [29d] He acquired belief in the three jewels and evoked the wish: May I (achieve to go to the Buddha, from the house) ...
Er erlangte den Glauben an die drei Juwelen [und] rief den Wunsch hervor: Möchte ich (erlangen, zum Buddha aus dem Hause zu gehen.
He attained belief in the three jewels [and] induced the wish: may I (achieve [this:] to leave the house for the Buddha).

comments.comment: Judging from their content, this and would appear to be part of the Krodhavarga (XX). This text here includes strophes 18-30, while includes strophes 12-20, thus partly overlapping in content. The metre is 4x17 syllables (rhythm = 6/6/5).

The original manuscript is missing, but was a somewhat larger fragment restored out of a number of smaller pieces, about 4/5 of the full length of the leaf. Damaged at all edges and margins, beginning and end missing. Lines a2-a4 correspond to lines b4-b6 of (cf. ).
Emendation according to n. 3 based on b4.
According to n. 8 the Pāda is one syllable short.
According to n. 4 alleksa stands for allek ksa.

The meaning of miye is uncertain. The same is true for paṣkārro which also appears in the Klosterrechnungen in Otani I.5, which lists the purchase of 3 lb. of kewye ṣalywe ‘suet’ for 150 lb. of grain and one of 4 lb. of paṣkarroṣe ṣalywe for 80 lb. of grain. Presumably, therefore, miye and paṣkārro are oleiferous fruit, which the boy is being fed according to .

line.tr: He led him as a hunter, [and] into the forest they went to hunt. The amount of animals the hunter earlier could not have killed in ten days, this ... [49d] ...
... He made [her his] daughter [and] gave her to Kāḍika as a wife. Countless animals this one began to kill every day ... [50d] ...
... (The monks asked) about the disappearance of this Kāḍika. (The monk), who already had evoked the Naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñā-meditation ... [51d] ...
... the guilt in the hands ... bears, now kills animals in the forest; he who earlier had donned the Kaṣāya-[penitent’s]garb .... (very much). He, who not even ... [52d] ...
... Thereupon ... he made. Heavy to bear in the teaching here is monkhood ... many dangers there [are],
where fools act. [53d] ... of the evil ... dependent on judgements having [be]come ...
... and a suffering it is, (if) he, who has gathered much, for a second time ...
... [55d] ... (is) difficult. Difficult [it is] to bear for a whole life ...
... [56d] ... by force [56b] ... (energy). They do not carry the burden here ...
[57d] Six ... The imaginations do (not) let [anyone] hesitate here. ... With whoever he lay ...
the beings [58d] ... perceive the one hundred kleśas! [In] pain he lives, who (by the kleśas) ... in two ways ...
... [59d] Again at another time the Omniscient [was staying] in Rājagṛha on the Gṛdhrakūta ...
... Just after having gone from the good monkhood into his house. [60d] Having left the discipline, having dismissed monkhood entirely ...
... He saw the Ānanda [and] was slightly ashamed of it. [61d] [This one] returned from the almsround [and] (reported) the whole matter to the Omniscient ...
... Even earlier this one could not obey [the rules of] monkhood properly. [62d] He did not conduct himself according to the rules [and] did not [act] the good way and manner ...

comments.comment: The leaf includes the strophes 48-63b in a 4x13-syllable-metre (rhythm: 5/5/3 and 5/4/4) and deals with monks that gave up monkhood and returned to their civic lives. Due to the incompleteness of the text the translation frequently remains uncertain.

Most probably somehow belongs with THT 44.c, which contains no more than 4 lines and must be a part from the right side of the leaf, although the allocation is not beyond doubt. It is impossible to determine any specific Varga this text could belong to.

The original manuscript is partly missing, but consisted of three non-continuous fragments of probably one and the same leaf. The largest one was a remnant of the left side of the leaf, whose beginning was destroyed by fire. To this certainly belonged a small fragment of the beginning of the leaf which equally had scorch marks.

line.tr: (You, o shelter and refuge, must (?)) not go away, have all reasons stopped for you? I alone (have not left you), o shelter and refuge, why are you intending to leave me now? The young [ones?] ... [29d] ...
O Schutz [und] Zuflucht, warum willst du mich jetzt verlassen?
Oh shelter [and] protection, why would you leave me now?

line.tr: are the (venerable ones), shelter, who are going after this one always. I, miserable being [that I am], neglected all other things, having made your feet [my] shelter. If separation on me ... o god ...
(Zu wem ich jetzt) meine Zuflucht nehmen soll, verkünde mir, o Schutz [und] Zuflucht.
(With whom I now) shall take refuge, [this] proclaim to me, oh shelter [and] refuge.

(Who now I) should make [my] shelter, announce to me, o shelter and refuge. [30d] Thereupon the gods [and] men lamented much, suffering they looked upon the Omniscient without winking an eye. (With the water) of tears the beings at that time were sprinkling all the earth,
(Mit dem Wasser) des Mitgefühls besprengten die Wesen die ganze Erde zu der Zeit; (das Leben zu verlassen), schickten sie sich an.
(With the water) of compassion the beings bedewed the whole earth at that time; (to leave the[ir] life) they prepared.

they opted (to leave life). The suffering assembly saw the teacher of the three worlds, the Buddha. [And] to comfort the four assemblies, the Buddha proclaimed the good (law): [31d] Again and again I proclaim the law to you, (but you have) not made [it] your mark,

[it] does (not) oppress [your] thoughts. No-one lived eternally here earlier, nor will live after this, let (alone he, who) [is] present. (For) by day and night (the Rākṣara) will drink the waters of life of these being. Of death ...
No-one has lived immortally before here, and no-one will live [immortally] hereafter.

... [32d] (There is no exception), there is no place in any step in the Saṃsāra, where we did not die. In judgement (of conduct) we were born (in all places) of the members of the five (kinds of birth), all forms of existence we gave substance to ...
... we died ... (some) die, others [die] by being born. [35d] .... likewise hells, countless [and] without measure.
[is missing]
... Others ... earthly ... five hundred miles downwards ... (There) the born one (should be) solely (among) miserable ones ...

... are deep (?) below (this) earth the seven hells, which span the earth [for] a myriad and nine thousand miles [around], or (the Avīci-hell). Two myriads of miles down below it it [is]. [36d] These are the places in the beings'

existence, in forty places they dwell, on top [is] the highest existence, at the bottom the Avīcis. In all these places one after the other (death) demands the beings as a tribute, as it were. (The difference), however, [is] this: No sword, no hindrance death
Nicht Schwert, nicht Festung hemmt (diesen) Tod irgendwie [d.h. wehrt ihn von sich ab]: Allen den fünf Geburtsarten Angehörenden nimmt er die lieben Leben.
No sword, no fortress inhibits (this) death in any way [i.e. wards it off from itself]: From all the members of the five incarnations he [i.e. death] takes [away] [their] dear lives.

do hinder in any way. From the members of all five kinds of birth he takes away the dear lives. [37d] The merits of three Asaṃkhyeyas, the eighteen most excellent laws of the Omniscient in [his] sequence of births, all [this] death crushes [for] them; all
the Buddhas bodies, death destroys them. All Pratyekabuddhas he leads [away], also all Arhats, all great sages, all (good) beings, death kills them. [38d] Without (rests) are
Ohne (Ruhen) sind auch (alle Dinge) im Saṃsāra; diese weite Erde, die Berge bis zum Sumeru-Berg, die großen Ströme, Seen und die tiefen Ozeane dazwischen werden von der Sonne ausgetrocknet.

Without (rest) are (all things) in the saṃsāra; this wide earth, the mountains [all the way] to the Sumeru-mountain, the great rivers, lakes and the deep oceans between [them] are being dried up by the sun.

(all things), too, in the Saṃsāra; this wide earth, the mountains all the way to the Sumeru-mountain, the great rivers, lakes and the deep oceans in between are dried up by the sun ... sun, moon and all stars ...
all such things. [39d] [It is] (the view of these humans) in the world: “A thing that has risen high should not be let perish afterwards either.” ...

comments.comment: From its content this leaf belongs to the Anityavarga (I), and also has the same metre as , , and , i.e. 21/21/18/13 syllables (rhythm = ab: 8/7/6, c: 9/9, d: 7/6); the strophe number 29-40 is no obstacle either, since includes strophes 78-86. Therefore it should actually be Nr. 1 in the collection. On the situation cf. / (conversation between Buddha and Ānanda after the first sickness). Ānanda is the speaker in strophes 29 and 30.

The original manuscript is partly missing, but consisted of two non-continuous fragments, the larger of which being in turn restored out of two smaller pieces and making up about 2/3 in length of the left side of the leaf from the left margin on. The smaller fragment, in turn restored from three smaller pieces, was a badly damaged remnant of the last third of the right side. The leaf number was not preserved. Line a8 is lost.

The reading proposed in n. 6 as a -ṣṣe-adjective based on karuṃ 'compassion' does not hold because the vowel of the initial syllable is not reduced (cf. karūnäṣṣe et var.). It is safer to restore a -ṣṣe-adjective based on akrūna 'tears'. The phrase akrūnaṣṣe wär is attested in a3. One can restore, as per , (wars= ā)krūnaṣṣe with a metrically conditioned permutation of word order. At the end of this pāda n. 7 restored (rai)ttānte, which is at variance with the attested verb . Since the the akṣara containing <ttā> is partly destroyed, one can safely restore , which is attested from the root ārt(t)ā- The same phrase 'sprinkle the whole earth' is also attested in THT 17 a4 in the form of pärsnoṃ po keno Therefore, one may consider restoring wars= ākrūnaṣṣe in the preceding lacuna, which would also complete the meter.
Emendation according to n. 9.

line.tr: I let the rain of arrows flow without measure. I tortured ... (See) my body: strength and (force) ...
the dear life. [30d] That was my resolute power ... (The old fighters, the heroes) ... the countries (?), all full of possessions. But this is not shut/filled ...
[Being] smothered is my life [and] body (in the machine) of death. [31d] ... now I am being separated from [my] dear little sons, (from) the three excellent jewels ...
... jetzt werde ich getrennt von [meinen] lieben Söhnchen, (von) den drei herrlichen Kleinodien ...
... now I am being separated from [my] dear little sons, (from) the three marvellous treasures.

(I) unhappy one, and when will I get to see this [again]? (To rule the earth surrounded by) the ocean I praised myself, this [earth] I will leave. [32d] “Now give up all other imaginations, now (only) remember, (o king),
(Die vom) Ozean (umgebene Erde zu beherrschen?) rühmte ich mich selbst; diese [scil. Erde] verlasse ich [jetzt].
([As] ruling the earth surrounded by the) ocean I praised myself; this [i.e. earth] I am leaving [now].

[your] good deed. If you leave everyone now, [your] countries, villages, women, sons, (the queen, politics?), the countless (possessions), the kings at the borders, equally also the ministers, you will still, led by your deeds, now go (to the other world).

If you now give up all, [your] lands, villages, women, sons, queen, nay, [and your] countless possessions, [your] district kings and likewise [your] ministers, then you will now go, lead by your own deeds, to the other world. (cf : ii, 68–69)

[33d] Just like, if the animals [i.e. fireflies] keep together, the night glows, but if the animals keep apart, the wind scatters them in a moment, thus you [shall] judge your kinsmen. As long as you will be friendly ...
Wie, wenn die Tiere [i.e. Leuchtkäfer] sich zusammenhalten, die Nacht leuchtet, (wenn aber die Tiere sich) getrennt (halten), im Augenblick der Wind sie zerstreut, so beurteile du deine Angehörigen.
Just in the way, when the animals [i.e. glow-worms] keep together, the night glows, (but when they keep) separate, the wind scatters them in a moment, just so you shall judge your relatives.

[Just] as when the animals are dwelling together, the night will grow light, but, when (the animals) are dwelling apart, in an instant the wind scatters them, so pay attention to your relatives! As long as you will be friendly …, [but] as soon as life leaves your body, they will all be alien to you. (cf : ii, 69; 23–24)

... so soon as the life will leave this body, [so soon] they will all become strange[rs] to you.” [34d]. (Thus out of compassion to the king) the great teacher spoke [and] cast out the fear from him. Even from/by/of you ... (The attachment) to the kinsmen ...
[Have you] (forgotten) the way of the Saṃsāra? Should, because of sorrow, anyone’s life return a second time? ... one by one. [35d] Certainly you will all die. Already earlier the ...

somehow. Earlier this one lamented these others, now we lament him, (others will lament us (?). Whosoever you have seen), or of whoever you have heard, [in] nobody would likely have arisen an doubt, [that he,] who would be born here,
Presumably nobody has got doubts whether who is born here would die.

would not die. [36d] The threefold Saṃsāra burns away step by step in the fire of impermanence, nobody is left behind ... (no) medicine, no incantations [and magic] powers, nothing at all could hinder death. (No teacher (?), no)
Der dreifache Saṃsāra wird Schritt für Schritt durch das Feuer der Vergänglichkeit verbrannt, niemand bleibt übrig.
The three-fold Saṃsāra is being burned step by the step by the fire of transience, nobody remains.
Brahmans, no great kings, no heroes.” [37d] ... “(You dear little sons), sit down near (me). Alas, the dear possessions of the kinsmen, (hide them all?)
inside a cave. You I cannot yet together with ... by (death we all are ?) being struck on the head. [38d] Nobody is left behind, you ascend the king’s (chariot?) ...
different the shapes of existence (?). In divine shape, (in) human shape ... afterwards the drops of blood. Who lived in suffering ...
Wer im Leid lebte ... oder welche im Wunsche nach Söhnen lebten, den ...
Who[ever] lived in suffering ... or who[ever] lived desiring sons, him ...
[39d] Or who lived in desire for sons, him ... ([to] whom) a son should be [born] ...
in the terrible (suffering). To go [is] a duty, one must not be confident, not either in another one ... The kinsmen ...

comments.comment: The fragment part to right hand side of the missing portion is quite attrited, especially the lines b7 and b8. Here are some akṣaras that must have been readable at the previous transliteration, but which are not readable anymore.

Contains strophes 29b-41b in a 20/22/10/15-syllable-metre (rhythm = a: 5/5/5/5, b: 8/7/7, c: 5/5, d: 8/7 or 7/8). The text is partly identical to . On the situation cf. the commentary to Dhp 201, , III: 73. The king of the Kausala, Prasenajit (here: Prasannaka) has been defeated in battle three times by his nephew Ajātaśatru, king of Magadha; he is ashamed of this and wants to renounce life. On the back story, see also .

Two non-continuous fragments belonging to the same leaf; one is the left third of the leaf and bears unreadable remnants of a leaf number on the left verso margin. The other fragment is a badly damaged rest of the right half of the leaf, its right edge missing.

comments.comment: The 4 x 15-syllable-metre apparently used in this fragment is already known to us from the second part of the Mārgavarga (XII), cf. - . This fragment here, however, cannot be part of the latter, since the content here does not match with that of , which shows the same strophe numbers. The same metre, however, was also used in the chapter dealing with the Cittavarga (XXXI), see : A1-3, 72ff., and the agreement of b2 tek\ śarsa auspa : ñiś palkormeṃ with : A1b4 klyauṣa nande ñäś ṣarmmeṃ pudñäkte ślokanma weña is rather astounding. But in A1b4 this is already strophe 81, whereas a4 in this text has the strophe number 24. Due to the scantiness of the fragment, which, after all, has preserved only a single strophe number, not even recto and verso side can be identified with any certainty; and in the translation a lot of things remain doubtful.

comments.comment: The 4x12-syllable-metre (rhythm = 5/7), as is used in this leaf down to b4, is also used in Book 6 (Śīlavarga; cf. ); and the fact that the strophes 67ff. attested here are related to the group of strophes Uv 6.16-18 (= Dhp 64-56) is clearly shown in a7, which is an obvious translation of Uv 6.18. According to the commentary on Dhp 54-55, the Buddha answers Ānanda’s question “Are there odours that flow against the wind or odours that flow with the wind as well as against it?” with these strophes: “Yes, there are such odours. If one takes refuge with the Buddha, does the ten good deeds and avoids doing evil deeds, he emits odours that flow against the wind or both against the wind and with it” (see , II: 84f.). Thus the Buddha is likely to be the speaker and Ānanda the addressee in a1ff. – The new chapter beginning with b5 is in a 4x17-syllable-metre (rhythm = 6/6/5) and can with certainty be allocated to the 7th Book (i.e. the Sucaritavarga). Strophe 78 thus must close with päklyauṣso, and the following gap must originally have contained the colophon to the finished varga as well as the name of the metre used in the section to follow (presumably Niṣkramāntne). Additionally, (sucaritavargä \) śanmaṃ would nicely fill verse 78d.

Since matsi – piyoṃ makes a colon of six syllables, matsi has to be a complete form, i.e. it is the nom. or obl. noun 'headhair'. This makes it very unlikely that piyoṃ is a variant of the 3pl. Imp of piā- ‘± to make a sound like a trumpet’ (see most recently ). Therefore Malzahn now suggest to separate p iyoṃ, iyoṃ being the 3.pl. Imp of iyā- ‘to cause to go', while the lacuna may be restored to (ṣa)p. Since the text is praising the superiority of moonkhood, one may think of a sense like "they caused them to go shave their hair".

comments.comment: T III Š 64.16 and T III Š 75.52 are also labeled THT 73a and THT 73b, respectively. The original of the leftmost fragment is missing. In one frame with three other fragments.
The meaning of asāñcne as "buttocks" comes from s.v. asāṃ*. āsana-, the Sanskrit term, does not seem to have this meaning.

kerci cannot be the plural of kertte "sword". Sūryakānta-crystals were not used to make swords, but are used to decorate houses, cf. Śivapurāṇa 2.32.48 (page 606 in Shastri's edition). This would also fit better with the context, since the Buddha is said to be "illuminated from within", which would not be possible with swords.

s.v. mārgāṅk* translates mārgaṅkntaṣṣe "subsection of the way". This cannot be right. *mārgāṅga is not attested in Sanskrit, and it would not make sense in this context. What would be expected is a quality of the Buddha (like compassion, trustfulness vel sim.), cf. maiyttärṣṣe no warsa. However, the word still remains obscure.

This whole passage is rather peculiar in its imagery. It describes the "geography" of the Buddha: Five rivers of thoughts that flow into the ocean that is his belly, filled with the jewels that are his virtues. That is, the author is painting a "cosmos" of the qualities of the Buddha, mentioning its landmarks (islands, forests) and its inhabitants (Nāgas, Yakṣas, Gandharvas), all corresponding to some virtue of the Buddha.

comments.comment: Introduction of the Araṇemi-Jātaka. According to , the beginning of the text can at least partially be reconstructed as follows with the help of b 1-2: “Thereupon the two Tuṣita-gods, Jñānasthita [and] Guṇasaṃpada appear. Jñānasthita speaks: ...”.

The text is continued immediately by Pelliot Ouïgour I, 13-67 (). From the latter's line 42 on, there are two Tocharian versions available as well, yielding a somewhat longer piece of text: one in TA (), and one in TB ().
The translation basically follows .
Recto of the leaf; the verso is lost.

and again Thomas in restore s(nai nerke)nta "without hesitation" ("sinngemäß", i.e. "to that effect"), but we would not expect a plural form here (cf. sg. snai nerke in a 5). To be sure, the reading 〈nta〉 at the beginning of a4 is a more likely one in any case than 〈tta〉 (thus Sieg/Siegling), since there are very few TB words ending in -tta; snai, on the other hand, is certain because one can still see remains of the 〈n〉 below the 〈s〉.
This strophe of 10|11|10|11 syllables has an uneven cola division of 4/6 in 1a and 5/5 in 1c.

The reading [··]e and restoration to (āñmn)e by (followed by Schmidt) is impossible: the sign after the lacuna is surely an anusvara ṃ, the remains of part of a consonant speak in favor of n; ñ must likewise be excluded.

comments.comment: The translation follows .
Larger parts of the verso, including the leaf number, are missing.

The meter of the no doubt metrical passage is 10|19|10|19 (5/5) and (7/7/5), according to the "Bleistiftnotizen" of Emil Sieg (see Thomas in ). The spelling yärke is probably due to copying from an older manuscript. Sloppy copying also lies behind the misspelled täṅwaṃñeñcä in a 3.

. rightly argues that one should keep the reading täṅwaṃñeñcä (pace Sieg/Siegling, who wanted to correct into plural täṅwaṃñeñcaṃ) due to syntactical reasons. His translation of the sentence is given here. For the spelling cf. the 3sg. with enclitic pronoun klautkañ-cä in b 5.

mar-c no doubt belongs to a 1sg.mid. imperfect form with enclitic pronoun of the 2nd person. Thomas in correctly doubts the restoration kā(wo) "desire" and hence the metrical division 10|10|10|11 by Sieg/Siegling (followed by Schmidt, l.c.) because the phrase "my longing for you" would rather require an allative. Thomas' interpretation of kā as a particle ending pāda 1d has not only the advantage of yielding a more regular meter of 4 x 10 syllables (6/4), but the sentence also makes much more sense than "my longing for you was greater than my desire for food" (thus Schmidt, l.c.). One would indeed rather expect a joke at the end of the strophe from the mouth of the king's jester than another flattering remark. To be sure, it is just such a lengthening of the final -a of the particle ka that is not uncommon at a pāda end (see basically ). Finally, what looks like pāda 2d in a6 also has to be separated into 6/4: āñme no te= yśimar ; waike weskau. What is problematic here is only the next pāda 2a, since the lacuna does not seem large enough for the missing five syllables, even if one assumes that the pāda end sign and (possibly) number after kā was left out; the first 6-syllable colon certainly ended with the unclear 1sg. imperfect form in -ṣṣim. However, it is possible that an akṣara was left out (and later added) by the copyist, exactly as in päst in the same line.
Sieg/Siegling propose to restore the 1sg. we(skau), Schmidt (l.c.) prefers the infinitive we(ntsi). Both are possible.

Schmidt (l.c.) seems to interpret kā as the emphasizing particle ka and not as the interrogative pronoun kā (as is usually done), but since we do not seem to have a metrical passage, the long ā cannot be explained.

Very tentatively, the inf. l(a)ntsi "to go out" may be restored here. The remains of a 〈la〉 (not in Sieg/Siegling) as second part of an akṣara before the ntsi seem quite certain to me. Maybe one can also restore pä(st) "back, away" at the next lacuna "if you do not step/take back/away from the word vel sim.".
The meter has 4 x 18 (7/7/4) syllables (Sieg/Siegling).

Restoration according to Thomas in , who also tentatively proposes (te maṃt) pkārsa "Know this!" at the end of the pāda. Thomas' restoration seems to be followed by Schmidt, l.c., to judge from the latter's translation.

(mā mäntana)tär-ñ is restored by Schmidt on the basis of the TA parallel mäntā /// in a 1. The form must be a present because we have an inhibitive imperative: "Stop scolding me!" Pace , a 2pl.mid. Prs XII (mäntan)tär is not likely because one would have to assume a misspelling (mänta)tär. But note that mäntanatär would be the only Prs VI form with the meaning "to scold" (the only clear Prs VI attestation from this root means "to stir").

It is difficult to decide whether śle yärke is a bahuvrīhi ślé-yärke (cf. ., who only lists undecidable cases for TB śle and TA śla) or a mistake. The TA parallel has a prepositional rendering śla wäktasurñe "with deference".

Cf. the TA parallel a 3: tmäṣ (āmāśa)ñ kälycaṃ kāresyo tānaśolis yokmaṃc ṣtmoräṣ śla wäktasurñe lāntāc träṅk(iñc). The traditional translation [as per Sieg, followed by Schmidt, l.c.] is: "Thereupon (the ministers) standing with threatening (?) swords at the door of the Dānaśāla with deference spoke to the king". However, it is unlikely from the situation that the ministers here raise their weapons against the king; their rather deferential attitude is also clear from the Uyghur version. Therefore, both TB mälkā- oṅkor and TA kälycaṃ kāresyo must refer to hiding or sheathing their swords. Accordingly, TA kälyc is interpreted as either ‘sheath’ (thus Werner Winter) or ‘sleeve’ (G.-J. Pinault) apud . The same is actually true for TB oṅkor. Note that later in the story in b 5, when the king has refused their request, they "lean on their swords" when asking him again to expell the Brahmin, which apparently is meant as a stronger threat than in this line.
The end || ā no doubt must be restored to an (unknown) tune name of 4x12 (5/7) syllables, as per Sieg/Siegling.
The beginning tär-ñ no doubt belongs to a 2pl. middle Prs or Sub form with enclitic 1st person pronoun.

According to , it would appear that a leaf of an Uyghur version of the Araṇemi-Jātaka (= U 2293), remnants of which are preserved in an Uyghur manuscript collection of the Berlin Turfan collection, also belongs within this context; the translated text of this leaf is also given in Schmidt KT 2001 (op.cit). In English, the text runs as follows:

[“However it may] be, death will come! Separated from you I will be.” In this way he will continue to lament: “You will not be able to redeem m[e]! [Through] unnumbered, tens of thousands of existences I have been born, I have died. The useless body [I have] cast off. Now great benefit has come [to] me. Are you all of one mind with me! If you foster good thoughts towards me, let you not rise a bad thought against this my [ ... ] Brahmin! Provide for [country and] town, folk and people, have-nots and the poor, [miserable] and needy beggars! Without hope they shall not be! Since I have sat on the [throne] of the kingdom, so and so many beggars have come. What they have begged for I have given them. If I keep giving in this way, the goods and chattels (of the) seven treasure houses of my town Aruṇāvatī will remain entirely empty. Not one day you have shown me a grim face. My heart you have not hurt. If your hearts..., because out of [greed] for power and strength you have ..., punished, scolded or cursed, ... or have become negligent, [of] these sins acquitted [you may be].”
Little fragment from one side of a leaf, possibly the verso of . In one frame with und .
Schmidt seems to restore correctly to (araṇe)m(i).

tkästä certainly contains a 2sg. active verb form from a root ending in -tk. Schmidt seems to propose the restoration (wa)tkäst 'you command' from the kausativum of the root wätkā-. In any case, the preservation of the final -ä (if not an error) may be due to the demands of metre and verse; there are no other indications of metrical passages in this small fragment.
A reading ka[ṣ](·) is also possible.
