line.tr: May the teacher speak trustfully. (715)

Ein törichter König, [der] sogar sich selbst vergessen [hat], namens Araṇemi, hat mich verächtlich gemacht. Er hat mich aus seinem Lande vertrieben vor [seinem] Gefolge. Der Tod möchte von einem Weisen ... gesucht werden / Eher möchte von einem Weisen der Tod gesucht werden, als dass er sich der Schande beugte [wtl. nicht möchte er sich der Scham beugen]. Der also genannte König hat mich verächtlich gemacht. Und wie soll ich dies ertragen?

A foolish king, [who has] even forgotten himself, by the name of Araṇemi, treated me with contempt. He expelled me from his country in front of [his] followers. By a wise one ... death should be sought/ Rather would death be sought by a wise one, than that he would yield to shame [lit. he would not yield to shame]. The thus named king treated me with contempt. And how shall I bear this?
This king by that name has treated me badly: how will I bear that?
The brahmin says: «Therefore get going according to my command!» (cf 100; 310)
Now this king is giving away everything out of his wish for the Buddha rank [and] certainly he will give prince Uttara to you. (cf 100)
The sorrows he should undergo I will let undergo prince Uttara [instead]. (cf 100; 310)
If you [pl.] fulfil this wish of mine, then you [pl.] will obtain benefit from me in the manner of the śāstras.
In (diese) Stadt eingetreten, sprechen sie [scil. die Brahmanen] zueinander: ...
Having entered (this) city, the Brahmins say to each other: ...
O Herr! Ausländische Brahmanen stehen draußen; den Herrn zu sehen, begehren sie.
Oh lord! Foreign Brahmins are standing outside; to see the lord they desire.
Der König spricht: "Führe sie schnell herein! Wohltäter [sind] sie für mich!"
The king says: "Lead them in quickly! Benefactors they are for me!"

The restoration of the tune name to niṣkramāntne is based on the often attested TA form niṣkramāntaṃ "In [the tune] niṣkramānt".

According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has basically 4 x 17 syllables (6/6/5 or 5/7/5), while pāda 1b has one syllable to many. It is quite clear that it is the first colon to contain the additional syllable, because it is repeated as such in pāda 1d (where the seven syllables are correct) and, what is more, the sandhi-triggered gemination in ñiś proves that the internal ceasura cannot be restored after the pronoun.
Schmidt, l.c., translates: "Er hat mich von [seinem] Gefolge [...] fortgejagt", which is, most likely, a typo for "vor [seinem] Gefolge", since this is the meaning of enepre. Cf. also .

The traditional interpretation of pāda 1c is based on the restoration and correction (ri)toyt(a)r by Sieg/Siegling. Accordingly, translates: "Von einem Weisen dürfte eher der Tod gesucht werden, [als] daß ihm die Ehre genommen würde [wörtl. daß die Scham fortgebeugt würde]." Differently, doubts the restoration of the verbal form and reads [n](a)noyt(ä)r. A 2sg. indeed does not make any syntactical sense, and it has to be accepted that the copyist mistook a 〈ta〉 of the original for 〈ta〉 (the signs are somewhat similar as second part of an akṣara). As for the beginning of the verbal form, one would indeed expect to see some traces of an akṣara 〈ri〉 around the lacuna, and the rather small akṣara 〈na〉, as proposed by Schmidt, would certainly fit. Since there is no trace of an upper vowel sign, 〈a〉 does indeed seem to be the best reading. It is also true that the following akṣara is a 〈na〉 rather than a 〈ta〉. However, although is so far the only known verb forming a Sub V and ending in -n, Schmidt's interpretation is, in my opinion, not really convincing with respect to semantics, because the (intransitive) verb means "to appear" (not passive "hingenommen werden = "to be accepted", as Schmidt translates). The genitive aiśaumyepi is most certainly the agens of a passive construction, which means that the underlying verbal form has to be a passive and not an intransitive. So far, no root that fits all these requirements is known. A similar problem occurs with the second verbal form rmoytär, which is also intransitive and not passive (pace Thomas in ). Furthermore, pace Thomas in , päst (most likely with intensifying function) for syntactical reasons belongs to the first verbal form and not to rmoytär.
Sieg/Siegling read ñī yaitkorsa, but the original seems to be more damaged now. Only a part of the ī and 〈ya〉 is still visible, the ai is missing.

It is certain that kan(·) is a transitive 2pl. (most likely subjunctive) form of the root itr. "to come about", tr. "to fulfill"; Sieg/Siegling proposed to restore to kan(aścer), which subsequently has entered the handbooks as a 2pl. Prs IXb form (see s.v. kän-). This view was challenged with good reasons by . (followed by ), who proposed as alternative a 2pl. transitive Sub I kan(tär) based on the reading by K. T. Schmidt (p.c.). However, a close look at the original manuscript shows that the preserved remains of the second stroke of the akṣara in question can only belong to a 〈na〉 and not to the upper part of a 〈ta〉 or even 〈ta〉. Consequently, Sieg/Siegling's restoration is indeed the only philologically possible one; since the kausativium stem of kän- now in addition does show traces of A-character (see ), a 2pl. Prs IXb kan(aścer) = /känāścer/ with accent on the root is also morphologically supported. The further restoration by Sieg/Siegling to (ot) ṅke is supported by a 3.
The text is parallel to a 1-a 2.

The expression (tse)ññai uppāläṃ is proplematic from a semantic and morphological point of view: Usually, one does not construct uppāl "lotus" with the adjective "blue" in a pleonastic fashion; the normal construction is "something is blue like lotus"; second, (tse)ññai (or any other adjective in -ññe) is an obl. fem. singular, while uppāl is most likely an alternant (to be honest, only the plural uppalänta is certainly a feminine, but a plural in -nta should be an alternant). In any case, if the form referred to the eyes, we would expect a plural or dual. Therefore, one can either assume a gen.sg. uppāläṃ(ntse), or, more likely, the dot here marks virama and not anusvara (as, e.g., in line b 3). In that case one might consider an expression (tse)ññai uppāl(-yokäṃ) "the blue, lotus-colored xy (= fem.sg.)". A fitting feminine word would be āśce "head"; one may speculate that Araṇemi by bowing his head, the hair of which was blue-colored, made a further gesture of respect towards the Brahmins. This would also fill the missing number of at least 10 akṣaras before the text starts again in PK NS 35 a 3. See the commentary on : a 3.

kalma is most likely not a preterite form of kälm- "± to allow", but with rather a noun; syntactically, as a noun it can only be a nom.sg. In general, there are not many TB nom.sg. forms in -a, and usually they are derived feminine forms of the type oṅkolma "(female) elephant". Accordingly, the form in question here could also be a (female) animal name, perhaps a bird?
The meter has 4 x 11 syllables (5/6 or 6/5), according to Sieg/Siegling.

Fragment of one side of a leaf, probably the verso of the leaf directly following , so originally leaf 17 of the manuscript.

Sieg/Siegling propose to read and restore kä(r)py(eṃ) "common", cf. kärpye-saṃsār in b 4; but there is a trace of the vowel sign left that can only be ā, o, or au, cf. , who, nevertheless, accepts the correction to kä(r)py(eṃ). The middle Pt III form p(·)lyks(·)t(·) has to be restored to a zero-grade form p(a)lyks(a)t(ai); see with ref. At the end, Sieg/Siegling restored (twe no), (twe ṣek).
The meter has 4 x 17 (6/6/5) syllables.

also propose the word separation uppāll e, and even though words starting with le are rare (none fits here), such a gemination in sandhi is unusual. Sandhi gemination is usually found at morpheme boundaries, but, to my knowledge, not in compounds (the form may be one).
Note the tense alternation between present and preterite.

There is no trace of an anusvara on either autsate-ne (for auntsate) in line 3 or brāhmaṇets (for brāhmaṇeṃts) in line 5, so that Sieg/Siegling restore one in both cases; however, these are rather instances of genuine nasal loss in front of ts, which is a feauture of late and colloquial texts; see .

The reading sauśka for soṃśka is certain; a similar form sauśke is found on the following leaf b 6. Even though the graphemes oṃ and au look quite similar, the two spellings are most likely not simply due to copyist errors but are rather hypercorrect spellings, since in the late/colloquial language the sequence oṃś turns to auś; see .

At the beginning, propose to restore the m-Part. (miwama)ne "trembling". As for the restoration of the lacuna, Sieg/Siegling in propose the nom.pl. yākṣi (as attested in a 1), reading two completely missing akṣaras. In contrast, restore yakṣī based on a 3/4. Then Thomas in withdraws this interpretation, arguing for yākṣi again. However, there is a trace of the vowel sign left, which can only belong to a long ī, not to a short one.

Sieg/Siegling in edit yakṣa/āts with an uncertain second vowel, but the reading ā seems quite certain to me. In any case, one would expect yakṣeṃts (see also below).
Instead of unclear l(·)[o]cä, one should rather read l(·)[au]-cä, a 1sg. Prs or Sub with 2nd person pronoun from a root ending in -lC.

The reading and restoration (sau)śk(a) at the beginning by is no doubt correct, but his second reading and restoration at the end is less certain: ṣaiyyi[ṣ](ka) "Kindchen; Tierjunges" comparing a 3 ṣaiyyiśkaṃ [sic! not ṣaiyyiṣkaṃ as Schmidt quotes it]; to be sure, the remains of the last akṣara do belong to a 〈ṣa〉 rather than to a 〈ta〉 (as is proposed in Sieg/Siegling, who take ṣaiyi(t) for the 2.sg. Imp ṣait ‘you were', but such a spelling of the Imp seems quite unlikely to me); on the other hand, there is no trace of the geminate, but since the text has some late/colloquial features, degemination is not a problem. As for the word itself, one should follow in deriving it from śaiyye "sheep" with dissimilation; to be sure, "my little lamb" is a perfectly possible address in this context.
A 2sg. Opt or Imp of śāw- ‘to live' is the only conceivable restoration (the alternative root in -y soy- ‘to satiate' is more unlikely for semantic reasons).
According to Sieg/Siegling, we have a meter of 4 x 13 syllables (5/8).

. proposes to restore to a perlative päśne〈sa〉 due to haplography (followed by Schmidt), but Thomas in . is right in questioning the necessity for that; on the other hand, Thomas in a postscriptum (p. 287f.) argues that the form is not an oblique of direction, as proposed by , either, but a normal direct oblique form; in her book on local case forms now accepts the possibility of an oblique of direction in this passage and further notes in fn. 423 that according to a personal communication by Werner Winter, he himself later rather sided with Kölver. As for ālīn(e), Thomas in urther argues that it is a loc.sg. because of the long ā, followed by . However, the spelling with both long ā and ī is conspicuous, even though the same form is attested as loc.sg. in b 4. In the end, both interpretations remain possible, which means that both alternatives for päśne as normal oblique form and oblique of direction remain possible too.

comments.comment: Continues , continued on . The translation follows .

The mother’s lament. King Araṇemi surrenders his son to the Brahmins, who lead him away in spite of his wailing and resistance. Lines a2-b4 overlap with . At line b4 the parallel text commences. This latter text shows some minor deviations from our text here.
Note the monophthong -o in snai-kärsto for snai-kärstau; the same monophthongized form is attested in b 1, which belongs to the same manuscript, and there it is also at the end of a sentence.

Most recently, with fn. 66 favors the restoration of a PPt of Pt IV lalaupäṣṣusa from the root "to besmirch", but this, of course, remains uncertain, the more so since there is yet no other attestation of a kausativum from this root (although such a kausativum would be perfectly regular).

Thomas in proposes to restore pletksa su no ("sinngemäß") at the beginning; the preterite of the verb plätk- "to flow, develop" makes indeed sense, but the damaged akṣara cannot belong to a sign with e-vowel.
Maybe in arañcä the virama stroke is simply missing by error; since the passage is not metrical, preservation of -ä is unlikely.
The Paris parallel a 3 seems to offer a sligtly different text. See the discussion there.
For the interpretation and translation of tāsau, see .
For the restoration see the parallel a 4.

In contrast to Sieg/Siegling—who identify the meter as 20|22|10|15—, n. 70 rather proposes 19|19|10|19 (7/7/5 and 5/5). This seems to be correct, since it fits the restoration that can be achieved now by a new reading of the parallel fragment b 1.

n. 74 is right in refuting Sieg/Siegling's proposal to restore to (ṣañ ṣar)sa due to the "handschriftliche Befund", but he gives no alternative restoration. The remains of the preceeding akṣara speak in favor of (·)[ta]rsa, and this is now actually supported by the parallel b1, where [ṣṣ](·) [ś](·) (– –) [lyk](·)[śk](·) can be read; this can be restored to ṣṣe śas)tärsa ; lykaśke.
Due to new attestations from the root yärttā- “to drag”, the restoration yä(rt)t(amane) is the most likely, see .
The parallel b 4 has the obl.pl.masc. cenän from the demonstrative pronoun seṃ, which makes more sense with respect to its deixis as recognitional pronoun.
The direct speach of the Brahmins differs in a 4. At the end Sieg/Siegling restore i(ke-postäṃ ynemane).

prose.s:
[His] tongue was hanging [lit. going] out of his mouth.
k(a)ntwo koynameṃ parna lnaṣṣi-ne
Thereupon the Brahmin Durmukha jabs the boy Uttara sharply with a reed root. || tumeṃ durmukhe brāhmaṇe uttare«ṃ» śamaśkeṃ kärwāṣṣai witsakaisa räskare tsopaṃ-ne

After they had (put?) a ... [piece of] cloth (?) (onto his eyes/legs?), they began to chase him hard. siñcai ṣorpor ite
mormeṃ auntsante-ne ścīre makästsi •

Because of the boy Uttara’s [mis]treatment—collapsing from [his] feet he fell, when he had tripped over some forest root, onto his face tane ñake uttari śamaś(k)entse kālpsa painemeṃ ette kloyomane alyekä kca warttoṣṣe makūltsa tatrāppa
rmeṃ rūpsa klāya
—mud sputtered there from the ground märsāne ke«ṃ»ne mrakwe
[and] permeated it [= the face/cloth?]. yopsa-ne

Thereupon the Brahmin Rudraśarma grabbed the (pri)nce Utta(ra) by the ... [and] dragged him to and fro across the thorny ground. || tane rudraśarme brāhmaṇe • portsaisa utta(r)e(ṃ) (mñcu)ṣkeṃ eṅkormeṃ tsakatsai
keṃtsa orkäntai yärtta-ne
Having seen this, a Tree god spoke with sorrow to his wife: || tu lyelyakormeṃ vṛkṣavāsike ñakte śle māṃtsalyñe śanoś weṣṣäṃ

“[My] love! Behold the inconstancy of things [and their] non-lasting end!” lari(ya) (pā)lka nai mā-ṣekaṃñe
wäntarwats sparkālye ā(ke)
|| In [the tune] pañcagati || (||) p(a)ñcagatine ||

pada.s: Still [his] father, the king, is alive. ykāk cwi śamāne , pācer wlo ;
It is with difficulty [only] that he may be treated disdainfully, even by Viṣṇus. vipṇuntaṃts ra , amāskai ; yāmtsi sū erkatte •

[And] yet his tender little son those dastardly Brahmins drag [about] with furor. (ya)k no cwi soṃśke , lalaṃ
ṣkeṃ ; aināki caimp , brā(hmaṇi) ; (yä)rt(t)en-ne śle tremeṃ :
With a look begging for compassion that prince looks at them, full of love, as [he would look at] his dear father, pilko(s=) (ā)ñmālaṣkeṃ lkāṣṣän-me ; taṅsa sam mñcuṣke lareṃ pātär ramt :

but not a single one of them is to him protection in that s(uffering)! mā wa ksa ṣ cwimp ,
mäsketrä ; waste comp l(aklene)
In [every] (di)rection his father turns; (kä)lymi(ṃ) sportoträ , pācer cwimp ;
like a sea eagle he is keening incessantly. kurār lūwo tu yäknes(a) ; kwäsnāträ snai kärsto •

prose.s: The Goddess speaks: ś(a)na ñäkteñña weṣṣäṃ
“The father, the king, himself has brought to him this suffering: makte pācer walo cwi comp lakle śala
Why is he unhappy now?” kā ṣpä ñ(ake) (lä)klesu ste

The Tree-god speaks: || vṛkṣa
vāsike-ñäkte weṣṣäṃ
“Because of his wish for the dignity of a Buddha he has given him up. pañäktäṃñe perneṣṣe akālksa rinsāte-ne
Do not blame him! mā traṅko yamas-ne

Because of pain ... [his] heart is breaking com(pletely?). p(o) k· läkleñ arañce ni
ttaṃ
But [it is] for [all] our sakes he endures [lit. sees] such suffering.” wesäñ no pernesa sū toṃ läklenta lkāṣṣäṃ
Having said this, the two gods went away. || te weweñ(o)rmeṃ ltais ñaktene

There, however, the Brahmins, going step by step in the meantime, leading the prince Uttara, now brought him to the land of the king Candramukha. || om no ñake tott īke-postaṃ ynemane brāhmaṇi uttareṃ
mñcuṣkeṃ ākemane candramukhi lānte yapoyne klānte-ne •

Thereupon the pupils, having entered the Brahmin village, spok(e) to the Purohita Rudramukha: tumeṃ brāhmaṇagrāmne yaipormeṃ akalṣälyi rudramukheṃ purohiteṃ we(ñ)ā

line.tr: Dort jetzt durch des Knaben Uttara Verhalten(?) ihm unter die Füße fallend [und] an irgendeiner Waldwurzel hängengeblieben, fiel sie(?) auf das Gesicht; ein wenig(?) spritzte auf die Erde [und] drang in sie ein.

There now, because of the boy Uttara's behaviour(?) falling under his feet [and] having tripped over some forest root, she(?) fell onto [her?] face; a little spluttered onto the earth and permeated it.
O dear!, look at the impermanence of the things [and their] ultimate disappearance! (cf 102; 317)
With a pitiful look that prince looks at them with love, as at a dear father. Yet there is not any protection for him in his sorrow. (cf 102)
Er ruft ihn voll Liebe [und] schreit nach ihm, an den von ihm [scil. Uttara] betretenen Orten verweilt er ...
He calls [for] him, full of love, [and] cries for him, in the places entered by him [i.e. Uttara] he tarries ...
In [alle] Richtungen wendet sich sein Vater; [wie] ein Meeradler[tier] so wehklagt er ohne Unterlass. Er ruft ihn voll Liebe [und] schreit nach ihm.
Into [all] directions his father turns; like unto a sea-eagle[-creature] he laments without stopping. He calls him, full of love [and] cries for him.
If you see my little son, who is separated from me, console him on [his] awful road on my behalf [lit. in my stead]! (cf 102; 317–318)
Wenn ihr mein von mir getrenntes Söhnchen seht, [so] tröstet es an meiner Statt auf dem schrecklichen Weg!
If you see my little son, [who has been] separated from me, [then] comfort him in my stead on [his] terrible road!
Sein Vater, der König, selbst hat ihm jenes Leid gebracht.
His father, the king, himself, brought him that suffering.
Do not blame him!
Da aber jetzt brachten die Brahmanen, zunächst Schritt für Schritt gehend, den Prinzen Uttara führend, ihn in das Land des Königs Candramukha.
But there now the Brahmins, going step by step at first, leading prince Uttara, brought him into the land of king Candramukha.

comments.comment: Continues [[THT 87]], continued on after a gap the length of a leaf. The translation basically follows .

Some signs have been copied without diligence, e.g., märsā-ne for pärsāte in , sparkālye for spärkālye, śamāne for śāmane, and vipṇuntaṃts for vipṇuntaṃts in , lwāsāts for lwasāṃts in , ākemane for akemane in , etc.; often anusvāra is misssing, geminates are spelled with a single consonant or clusters are simplified (yamas-ne for yamast-ne in ). The meter is also often incorrect.

According to Sieg/Siegling, a nearly completely leaf. Today, however, the right-most part with the margin is missing, and perhaps some smaller pieces. The fragment THT 88 is the largest completed by THT 1924 to its left side. The leaf was carelessley restored before putting it under the current glas frame: a small piece at the beginning of line a 1 and line b 6, respectively, has been glued in the wrong way, so it has to be turned upside down; around the margins some folds are turned the wrong way.

There is now a lacuna in line between lnaṣṣi and m(·)eṃ, while Sieg/Siegling read clearly lnaṣṣine || tumeṃ, and it looks like part of the paper has been wrongly folded to the other side; the fragments join right in the middle of ‹du›; the attested fragment ends with si. In line the fragments join right in the middle of ‹ña›, the leaf ends with ‹wa›. In lines the fragments join somewhere in the middle of the string hole, the leaf ends with ‹utta›, while the upper part of a following vowel sign e is still visible. In line the left fragment reads up until ||, while the akṣara ‹tu› read by Sieg/Siegling is missing; the leaf ends with ‹lar[i]›. The left piece in line ends with ‹lye›, an edge from the verso side with part of the ‹la›-sign has been folded over the verso side; the right fragment starts with part of the ‹pa› and ends with the dot. In line the left piece ends with ‹brā›, the right starts with ‹rt(·)e›; in three places the paper has been wrongly folded so that the correct text is now to be seen on the photo of the verso side: the nn of r[t](·)enne, the middle of the akṣara ‹lkā› of lkāṣṣänme, and the lower part of the ‹ka› of mñcuṣke; the fragment ends with ‹rra›. In line the framents do not join, the left fragment ends before the lacuna, the beginning of the right fragment is the correct place to put the small fragment mentioned in line a6, right where one can still see traces of the ‹[ly]mi› and ‹so› read by Sieg/Siegling; over the ‹ka› of kärtso a small piece showing the lower part of a ‹ka› has been wrongly glued; the fragment ends with kwātärne. In line the left fragment ends with ‹wol[o]›, the right continues after the lacuna and ends with ‹ptsā›. In line the fraction falls into the string hole, the remains of a sign visible after ś(·) must belong to a different piece; the right fragment ends with ñ(·). In line the fraction again falls into the string hole, the right fragment ends with [p]·. In line the fragments join completely at the beginning of lkāṣṣäṃ, the right fragment ends with yne, but the e-sign is lost now. In line the u of mu from candramukhi seems to have been folded wrongly to the other side, the fragments join after lānte, the right fragment ends with ‹rudramu›.

A parallel passage now suggests a kind of textile or garment for the meaning of ṣorpor (not "bowl", which is the traditional interpretation triggered by ite "full"), see with fn. 93 and 94 and . Due to the broken context and due to the fact that the hapax siñcai is not clear, the passage is not entirely certain. (who then must have had access to the now lost piece) wants to read in[eś] (eṃṣ)[k](e yā)mormeṃ instead of i[t]e and translates "after they had (pul)led(?) down a ... hood (?) into [his] ey(es)". Whether this is correct can only be verified when the missing piece has been found; note that ‹na› and ‹ta› are usually kept clearly apart in this manuscript, so that Sieg/Siegling's reading i[t]e, should not be dismissed easily, even if the sign [t] was read with some uncertainty. Differently, . restores siñcai ṣorpor ite (cewsa yā)mormeṃ and translates "having put trousers on him completetly provided with thorns", refering to similar punishments known from Indic literatures.
kālp from Skt. kalpa- here means ‘(mis)treatment'. The reading ‹wa› in warttoṣṣe is clear, the form seems to be a mistake for wärttoṣṣe. There are many misspellings in this fragment.
The function of the dot after brāhmaṇe is unclear and probably just a mistake.

Here we seem to have a phrase vṛkṣavāsike ñakte (lit. "a god inhabiting a tree"), while in the Tree-god is a compound vṛkṣavāsike-ñäkte of the type kauṃ-ñäkte 'Sun-god'. But note that ñakte may also be simply a misspelling for ñäkte, since there are many errors in this text.
According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 21|21|18|13 syllables (a+b: 8/7/6; c: 9/9; d: 7/6). Very often the pādas have incorrect numbers of syllables.
Pāda 1c has one syllable too many.

Note the monophthong -o in snai kärsto for snai kärstau; the same monophthongized form is attested in a 1, which belongs to the same manuscript, and there it is also at the end of a sentence. Accordingly, the form rather attests to a real monothong and is not simply due to a misspelling.

The second colon of pāda 2a has one syllable too many; Thomas suggests to read tu-yknes(a). Sieg/Siegling read śauśaṃ-ne in pāda 2b; since the original fragment is missing, it is difficult to judge whether this is a typo for śauśäṃ-ne or a misspelling in the manuscript.

The verbal form wolo(kträ) has already been restored by . with fn. 100 claims that in the akṣara 〈mw〉 the 〈w〉 had been erased on purpose; he also reads and restores (tu)-maṃnte or (tu)-maṃnte "from there onwards"; however, this is impossible because the adverb mante in the meaning "from ... onwards" requires the ablativ, while the compound with the neuter te pronoun has the second member mant (te-mant "in this way"), never °mante. To be sure, the 〈w〉 may also simply be faint due to damage to the manuscript; as for the vowel above the akṣara, I also follow Sieg/Siegling in reading [e], because the sign as been attached on the left side over the 〈m〉, while an anusvāra ṃ would have been placed right in the middle over the sign. I follow the separation ente "where, if" propsoed by . °mw then can only be a sandhi form for °mu or °mu; Stumpf proposed yanmo "gehend" = "auf der Wanderung", while Thomas seems to propose an adverb "traurig".
Both cola of pāda 2c have one syllable too many.
The second colon of pāda 2d is one syllable too short, the missing syllable may be restored by restoring the sandhi form ytārine.

line.tr: “... the dignity of the Omniscient (has) been (given) to you, for the sake of which you have abandoned me, the innocent one. I, who have been brought up as a Kṣatriya [and] grown up in happiness, (endure ?) suffer(ing) ....

line.tr: The infernal sufferings I endure [lit. see] (already) among humans. In my disheveled hair curls everywhere animals have made nest[s] ...
me by day and night. 2. Dear ... creatures! If only you may see my misfortune and ill-usage! ....
Dear (forest?) beings!, may you see my misery and misfortune!
Forlorn I wander in the forest. T(here I lie (?)) on the ground, wrapped in feathers of the kotstse (or kautstse) bird, nobody’s kin. ....
O lord, father!” 3. Thereupon prince Uttara ... remember(ing (?)) .... like ....
(fal)len, (sprinkling) dust onto [his] head, he speaks: || (In) [the tune] bharyacin(tāk ||)
.... (not?) helpful, the life .... Life, oh you disgraceful one ....
without shelter [and] refuge. Oh god Karman, why do you (demonstrate ??) [your] power so much on me? .... restrained. (2.) ....
O Gott Karman, warum (zeig)st du so sehr [deine] Macht an mir?
Oh god Karman, why do you (sh)ow [your] power so greatly on me?
to see. (It is) [both] happiness [and] suffering to me to have partaken in this your domain. Yet I, having suffered now, ....
in (su)ffering. 3. Thereupon now merchants of Aruṇāvatī (having heard) the prince Uttara’s lamenting [and] wo(rds, speaking to one another:)
“Who is it that laments so pitifully [and] calls out the name of the lord, of king Araṇemi?” The merchant Dravyeśvara (speaks): “ ....
Who may be wailing so pitifully, calling the name of the lord, king Araṇemi? (cf 319)
Wer klagt da wohl [so] erbärmlich [wtl. mitleidig] und ruft den Namen des Herrn, des Königs Araṇemi?
Who [is it that] is crying here so pitifully and is calling the name of the lord, of king Araṇemi?
an (unhappy ??) creature.” The merchant Maṇīśvara speaks: “Some tender voice is heard [here]. Never ever before have I (heard) such [a voice] from a human.” ...
Der Kaufmann Maṇīśvara spricht: "Irgendeine zarte Stimme wird da gehört. Noch nie (habe ich) so etwas [wtl. jenes] von einem Menschen (gehört)."
The merchant Maṇīśvara speaks: "Some tender voice is heard here. Never before (have I heard) the like of it [lit. that] from a human."

comments.comment: Continues , continued on , after a gap of undeterminable length.
The lament of prince Uttara. The translation basically follows .

Between this and there is a gap of 18 leaves. Into this gap belongs fragment , which certainly does not follow immediately, as well as the Uyghur text Mainz 223, which is taken from a manuscript collection of the Berlin Turfan collection (cf. U 2293).

āklu is edited as ā[k]lu by Sieg/Siegling; the akṣara 〈klu〉 is preservered very clearly, but the shape of the upper sign 〈k〉, admittedly, is a bit odd, looking more like a 〈na〉; however, it is completely clear that āklu is meant and the sign is sloppily written rather than a genuine copying error.
According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 4x18 syllables (7/7/4).

The interpretation by Thomas . (followed by ) is certainly wrong ("In [ihren] ausgebreiteten Haaren gewährten mir die Tiere überall Unterkunft"); first, letse means "human head hair" or rather "curls" and in other passages even has attributes like ‘beautiful'; so it can hardly refer to animal fur. Secondly, the point of the passage is Uttara's miserable condition, entirely deprived of any help whatsoever. Accordingly, one should rather follow the interpretation by s.v. lesto and letse given here.

proposes to restore an adjective ‘forest' ("(Wald)wesen"); the visible top of the last akṣara may indeed belong to a 〈ṣa〉, but since the word cannot have more than two syllables, the form cannot be restored to wärttoṣṣi 'pertaining to the forest'.
Sieg/Siegling propose to restore t(ane ñiś \ lyakau). They also note that the damaged hapax k[o]tsts[e]ṃts may alternatively be read k[au]tsts[e]ṃts.
āptsa for āṣtsa 'onto the head' is a copying error.
According to Sieg/Siegling, this is the tune bharyacin(tāk) with a metre of 4x12 syllables (4/4/4).

One can actually read more on the manuscript than has been done before. However, word separation and metrical analysis of pāda 1c still remains uncertain, the more since the quite certain four-syllabic (e)kitatse is metrically imcompatible with the following six akṣaras. Thomas and with fn. 110) propose to separate śaulyñe ‘life', which would be an analogical form based on śail(y)ñe ‘life' (see ). A guess for the remaining akṣaras may be [c](ä)(ñ)c(aṃ)-m(e) ‘pleases them', but I cannot make much sense of this form here.

Both . and Thomas correctly argue that the old restoration (lkā)st(a)r is unlikely, because the grundverb has no causative meaning (at least in the present stem). The correct restoration of the verbal form remains uncertain.
The traditional restoration to an infinitive yā(mtsi) cannot be correct, because one sees the lower part of the sign, which belongs to a 〈ka〉 or 〈u〉-vowel. The PPt of yām- ist most likely.

I think läkā- 'to see' is here used like in the phrase läklenta läkā- 'to endure sufferings' and not to be taken literally (as, e.g., by "feindselig angesehen"). At the end of the line Thomas proposes the restoration re(kauna keklyauṣormeṃ ālyauceś weskeṃ.
Note the reverse spelling käryaurtto for käryorttau! In the following, ksa and tamp also show wrong vowels.
seems to restore (tallā)nt onolme "an unhappy creature" (obl.sg).

comments.comment: The translation basically follows .

Between and there is a gap of 18 leaves. Into this gap belongs this fragment, which might follow immediately (pace ), as well as the Uyghur text Mainz 223, which is taken from a manuscript collection of the Berlin Turfan collection (cf. U 2293). In the meantime, King Araṇemi has given everything that he has been asked for — not only his children, but also his wife and, eventually, himself also. As a result, Araṇemi has fallen into the hands of his vindictive arch enemy Rudramukha. The Mainz text is also translated in . In English, it runs as follows:

Onto [ ] he looked. Thus he suffered. But he did not let his mind desist from [torturing] this [king]. Continuing to drag (him) up and down on the unclean ground the tortured and tormented him. Sometimes he shamelessly kicked him against [his] head with [his] feet. The body of the noble one turned altogether black. (Yet still) the king looked with his eyes beautiful as purple-blue lotuses at the Brahmin. At this time the Brahmin Rudramukha’s wife saw the king [Araṇe]mi and spoke thus to her husband, the Brahmin: “As a very noble and mild man with good deeds he appears. Do not torment him more! If he is useless to you, sell him to someone else!” At this time the king Araṇemi entered into in such humiliation and bitter sufferings through the Brahmin, his heart and his mind, however, grew friendly and cheerful. Why? For through the Brahmin he had accomplished the pāramitā of patience. Then he let him don a very (?) bad, dingy gown fit for a slave, and they led him through the streets to sell him. When they reached the gate of Caṇḍālas a man holding a sword in [his] hand asked the Brahmin: “Are you selling this man?”
The storyline of this small fragment is less clear.
Fragment from the right side of a leaf, possibly directly following , in which case it was originally leaf 24 of the manuscript.
seem to restore ya〈ṃ〉.
It is unclear to what form the fem.sg. allonkä kca is referring to. The word-final -ä is preservered because of the following clitic.
Thomas proposes the restoration ā(rwa kärsnāmane), parallel to line a3.
Thomas correctly points out that Krauses's restoration (wā)ya-ne 'he went' in cannot be correct, because we would expect (wa)yā-ne.

nesta seems to stand for nestä with preservation of the word-final -ä; since such forms with preserved schwa usually stand at the end of a sentence/pāda/colon (see : esp. p. 75f.), it is likely that we also have a pāda/colon end here; note that inside one single colon the correct meter could also have been achieved by nest ñake.
Note the gemination in the pronoun ñisa ‘by me'.

correctly points out that the restoration (lare)-yok proposed in and again by Thomas in cannot be correct, because the damaged akṣara looks like either 〈ka〉 or 〈na〉. Schmidt himself thinks about an attribute meaning 'base, common', but no such form known yet fits here. Since the context is not so clear, I would rather propose ñäkte-yok ‘divine looking'.

The passage is metrical; according to Sieg/Siegling the meter has 4x18 (7/7/4) syllables. The metrical subdivision in line a 5 is not too certain; Thomas proposes yok ; ente nai kca nesta ñke ; ñissa, but if nesta is a genuine disyllabic form, it ought to stand at the end of a colon (see also below).
For the simile Thomas refers to the parallel b 2.

At the beginning of the line, proposes to restore [pru]kormeṃ 'after he had done (?) a leap', and while the remains of the upper part of the akṣara may belong to a 〈pa〉, the lower part is too edgy for a second-element 〈ra〉.

It is likely that the finite verbal form means ‘fainted', in which case it ought to be a middle (see wit ref.). Accordingly, traikane has to be corrected into traikate, as already proposed by Sieg/Siegling.
The personal name of the merchant already met in is restored by .
Word separation and interpretation of line b6 is completely unclear.

comments.comment: Often the nasal in gen.pl. endings is missing and incorrect vowels written: ā for a (klātsāt a2, tākāre-ñ b1), ä for a (krentä b3, amācäntä b6), a for ä (warporṣe a2, warpoṣäṃts b2), and ai for e (ke(r)cc(i)yainne b1). While the wrong interchange betwen the a-vowels is maybe simply due to sloppy copying, ai for e may rather be a hypercorrect.

Continues after a gap of indeterminate length, continued on . The translation basically follows . Araṇemi appears here as a gardener, who is sent to the palace of the king Candramukha with an errand from his master.

Two fragments from the same leaf with a more or less direct joint in line 1 and 6; in line 2 only one akṣaras is completetly missing, in lines 3 and 4 only one, and in line 5 four; the left margin is partly preserved but no leaf number. Large part of the upper layer on the verso side of the right fragment is lost. According to the content, this leaf directly preceds . Therefore, it was probably originally leaf 42 of the manuscript.

If satyakār is the correct word separation, one may derive it from a presupposed Sanskrit form *satyakāra- 'satya-making', which is, however, not attested; to be sure, the phrase satya kṛ- (e.g., satyakriyā- 'oath') means 'to make a pledge, conclude to an agreement'. Accordingly, suggests the translation "Pfand" with question mark.
On the construction war āṣtsiś yakne yamaṣṣäṃ, see and 153, note 4.

warporṣe seems to be a ṣṣe-derivative from the abstract warpor from the root wärpā- (Gv.) which has many different meanings: 'feel; enjoy; suffer; receive; consent'. Note that one would expect wärporṣe; if this is not simply a misspelling, the accent may be analogical to the initially accented abstract warpalñe beside derived warpalñeṣṣe. Note that the PPt warpoṣäṃts made from the same root in b2 also shows incorrect wa.

2.sg.act. klātsāt from kältsā- (Gv.) is a misspelling for either klātsat or klatsāt; but since the full grade in the root rather speaks in favor of an ablauting subjunctive V stem, initial accent in the active singular and accordingly klātsat ought to be the correct form (cf. ). Note that we have a similar misspelling tākāre-ñ for takāre-ñ in b1.

The sense no doubt is that nature mirrors the presence of Araṇemi such as "he kept seeing (blissfull signs) on the (lea)ves. For the sake of this one ... all trees (showed) divine (bloom/smell vel sim.)". Obl.pl. ñäkci(yeṃ) is also possible.
ke(r)cc(i)yainne for ke(r)cc(i)yenne (correct in a3) may be a hypercorrect form.

If the general calculation about the joint of the two fragments is correct, there is only space for one single missing akṣara (as per Sieg/Siegling). Thomas proposed restoration to s(kwamna) ‘fortune', followed by ; however, one would expect traces of the complex sign kw to be seen below the s, so this is unlikely even though it would fit the fem.pl. adjective very well. 2.pl. Imp pokkāk(a)s is also possible.

The adjective gen.pl. śpaluwenta(ṃ)ts "among the best" no doubt refers to the members of council, so that one would expect a masculine form, but a gen.pl.masc. from a u-adjective ought to be written śpaluwentäṃts (cf. ., § 243-4.)

The 3.sg.mid. Prs Xa klāsträ for källāsträ shows irregular syncope, a characteristics of informal speech. Note that the whole Araṇemi manuscript not so rarely shows informal style characteristics. The hypercorrect 〈ai〉 in b1 fits here as well. Furthermore, eṅwe for eṅkwe.
Thomas correctly points out that there is only space for one single missing akṣara in the lacuna between the two fragments, so only the restoration tswai(ññe) is possible.
eṅwe for eṅkwe.

comments.comment: The translation basically follows .
The text is sloppily written. Some akṣaras were omitted or spelled wrongly.

According to the content, these two fragments are from the leaf directly preceding , so originally leaf 43 of the manuscript. There is no direct joint between the fragments, the left one is from the middle, the right one from the right end of the leaf with the margin preserved.

The lower part of the sign before ste is most likely 〈wa〉; this apparently also the reading by since he proposes the translation "(Sch)utz" (?)", i.e. waste ‘shelter'. But there are many other possibilities such as (sas)w(e) ste "is the lord". The obl.sg. säsweṃ of saswe then seems to be proposed by Schmidt for the sä at the end of the line.

(·)trä at the beginning of the line no doubt belongs to a middle verbal form. There is more to be read before the double strokes: a double 〈ṣṣa〉 preceded by a complex akṣara with 〈la〉; I suggest to restore to (āk)läṣṣä(ṃ) 'teaches', although 'learn' would make more sense. Sieg/Siegling proposed two missing syllables between the fragments, and this calculation seems to be based on line a4.

ponts has to be an irregularly reduced gen.pl. pontaṃts; note further the degemination of aiṣṣi; the agreement of the alternans dual eśne with a fem.pl. adjective is quite regular since adjective dual forms are very rare.
According to Sieg/Siegling, we have a meter of 4 x 14 syllables (7/7).
The sense of pāda 2c is not so clear, but other restorations for pre(– –)nmu as proposed by Sieg/Siegling give no better sense. seems to accept preñca, but skips the second form.

The meaning of sauke here is completely unclear. Morphologically, it looks like a verbal abstract from suk- ‘to hang down’, but this form means ‘± garland, streamer’ in other passages and makes no good sense in this passage unless the point is that Araṇemi clings to his path even in his miserable condition. sauke may also be derived from the A-character root suk ā- ‘± to bring', but this does not help either. translates "stolz" with question mark but does not further comment on the form.
For the restoration św(ātsi śe)ś(w)orsa, see Thomas .

internalComments.comment: The translation is wrong. It should be "Whose wish it is to see the torments of hell", i.e. only someone who wants to go to hell would do this to you.

"This sage is the best of all. sam rṣāke posa śpālmeṃ ste •

prose.s: The venerable Bodhisattva accepted the rice porridge from Nandā [and] Nandabalā [as] alms. wärpāte aṣañike bodhisatve nāndai nandābalaimeṃ oṅkorñai pinwāt •
Thus having taken [it] he said to them: mant eṅkormeṃ weñā-meś
"Little sisters, is this jewel bowl given up by you or not?" ṣerśkana se nomiyeṣṣe bhājaṃ rerinu star-me epe mā •

They said: toy
weñāre
"Venerable one, it is left by us. aṣañika rerinu star-me :
The rice porridge, together with the jewel bowl, will be in precisely your possession! oṅkorño eṣe nomyeṣṣe bhājaṃmpa tañ ka ṣ ekalymi tākaṃ •

Thereupon the Bodhisattva accepted the rice porridge after having set [it] in front [of him] without having adhered to the thought in taste consecutively. tumeṃ aṣañike bodhisatve tāU oṅkarñai eneppre tättārmeṃ śukene mā tetreṅkoṣ palskosa yke
postäṃ wärpāte
After having given up [eating] he thought: ārskormeṃ palskone yamaṣṣate
"This will be my last accepting of alms at all in the state of the unenlightened. se ñi posa postanu präthagjaññene pinwāt warpalñe tākaṃ •
I will not accept (any) alms as long as I do not drive off false conception and kleśas. mā tot ñiś pintwāt warpalle nesau kossa wāsaṃ kleśanma mā wikäskau •
Thereupon ... tumeṃ :

line.tr: Bring [it] to him over there!
They prepared the porridge.
Cakra, Svastika [und] Nandikāvarta-Zeichen kamen darin [scil. im Brei] zum Vorschein.
Cakra, svastika and nandikāvarta-signs appeared in it [i.e. the porridge].
Auf der Erde [und] im Luftraum wurden glückverheißende Zeichen gesehen.
On the earth [and] in the airspace good omens were seen.
Den Brei ließen sie wallen; hoch in die Höhe ging er, jedoch auch nicht ein bisschen spritzte heraus.
The porridge they let seethe; high up it went, but not even a little splashed out [of the pot].

line.tr: Der Ājīvika Upaga, hin [und] her gehend, kam an den Ort, sah den kochenden Brei, wurde erstaunt und ging nicht fort. Er dachte [nach], verglich diese Zeichen mit dem Śāstra, [und] sogleich erkannte er: "Wer diesen Brei isst, der erlangt unübertreffliches Wissen."

The Ājīvika Upaga, going to [and] fro, came to the place, saw the boiling porridge, was astonished and did not go away. He thought, compared these signs with the Śāstra, [and] immediately he perceived: "Who[ever] eats this porridge, he obtains unsurpassable knowledge."

line.tr: A foreign sage who is trained in penance and best among the sages—to him we [will] give the porridge as alms.
Dem Upaga wurde sein Verlangen zerstört.
The desire of Upaga was destroyed for him.
Indra stieg herab [und] nahm das Aussehen eines Ṛṣis an [wtl. tauschte sich das Aussehen eines Ṛṣis ein].
Indra descended [and] took on the appearance of a Ṛṣi [lit. swapped for himself the appearance of a Ṛṣi].
Sie brachten ihm den Brei [und sprachen zu ihm]: "Nimm von uns Almosen entgegen, o Ṛṣi!"
They brought him the porridge [and said to him]: "Accept alms from us, oh Ṛṣi!"
Little sisters, do you give those alms to me, or do you give it to somebody who is better than me?
Who is better than you, to him we give it.
An uns mache liebende Gesinnung offenbar! Nimm dieses Almosen entgegen, weise uns doch, o Gott, nicht ab!
Make manifest a loving inclination in us! Accept these alms, do not reject us, god!
Do you offer it to me, or [to him] who is better than me?
I will not receive alms as long as I do not drive off false conception and kleśas.
This will be my last receiving of alms of all in the state of the unenlightened.
Nimm dieses Almosen entgegen, weise uns doch nicht ab, o Gott! [Dass] uns doch der lang gehegte Wunsch in Erfüllung gehe!
Accept this alms, do not reject us, oh god! May this wish, long harboured, be fulfilled for us!
If we can find somebody better than you, we will give it to him while we leave you [alone].
Darauf nahmen diese Schwestern den Brei, kamen zu den Śuddhāvāsa[-Göttern] [und] sprachen zu ihnen:
Thereupon these sisters took the porridge, came to the Śuddhāvāsa [gods] [and] said to them:
O great sages, if you are better than all, then receive this porridge! If you are not, tell us who is the sage that is better than all, so that to him indeed we bring it.
er wischte [sich] den Staub ab
he wiped the dust off [himself]
Inzwischen stieg der Bodhisattva in die Nairañjanā herab, badete sich, wischte [sich] den Staub [im Toch. Plural] ab; alles wusch er sich ab.
Meanwhile; the Bodhisattva stepped down into the Nairañjanā, bathed himself, wiped the dust [plural in Toch.] off [himself]; all he washed off himself.
Die Götter bogen ihm einen Arjuna-Baum zu; den ergriff er.
The gods bent an arjuna-tree towards him; this he grasped.
Er [scil. der Bodhisattva] stieg aus der Nairañjanā heraus [und] zog sich das Kāṣāya-Gewand an.
He [i.e. the Bodhisattva] stepped out of the Nairañjanā [and] put on the Kāṣāya garment.
You can/will not find anyone better and worthier of gifts than him there; bring him the porridge!
Bring that porridge to him over there!
May through these alms all benefits be realised for you, and may our cherished wish be fulfilled!

O du Askese übender großer Ṛṣi, nimm von uns diesen sechzehnfach verstärkten Brei entgegen! Durch dieses Almosen mögen die alle Heilsgüter zuteil werden! Möge auch uns der gehegte Wunsch in Erfüllung gehen!
Oh you great ascetic Ṛṣi, accept from us this sixteen times intensified porridge! Through these alms may all blessings be bestowed upon you! May our [own] wish, long cherished, come true also!
Der ehrwürdige Bodhisattva nahm von Nandā [und] Nandabalā den Brei als Almosen entgegen.
The venerable Bodhisattva accepted the porridge from Nandā and Nandabalā as alms.
Venerable one, it is left by us. The porridge, together with the jewel bowl, will be in precisely your possession!
Darauf genoss der ehrwürdige Bodhisattva den Brei, [ihn] vor [sich] gesetzt habend, mit nicht am Genuss hängendem Geist nacheinander.
Thereupon the venerable Bodhisattva enjoyed the porridge, having placed [it] in front [of himself], with a mind unattached to indulgence, consecutively.

Als er [scil. der Bodhisattva] [seine Mahlzeit] beendet hatte, dachte er bei sich: Dies soll mein allerletztes Almosengenießen im Pṛthagjana-Stande sein; solange werde ich nicht [mehr] Almosen genießen, bis ich die Vāsanā [falsche Vorstellung] [und] die Kleśas [Trübungen] beseitigt habe [wtl. wie ich nicht die V. [und] die K. entferne].

When he [i.e. the Bodhisattva] had finished [his meal], he thought to himself: This shall have been my very last enjoyment of alms in the Pṛthagjana rank; I will not enjoy alms [any more] as long as I have not discarded the vāsanā [false view] and the kleśas [defilements].

internalComments.comment: cau looks like a relative pronoun here.
Why is ce āktike nesem translated as a question?

ceynas ekmem is very weird. ceynas could be a late genitive plural distal pronoun. ekmem likely has something to do with the root käm- "come", as in kmem "we came". However, it is not clear what the initial e- is doing here. Couvreur 1952 (Indogermanische Forschungen 60, 35f - Not in the Bibliography!) argues that e- means "hither": He thinks that ekmem = skr. āgam-, and that toch. e "deckt sich genau mit" skr. ā. However, it is unclear whether Tocharian morphology would allow for such a form. Even if this was correct, it remains unclear why we find the very colloquial form ceynas in a literary text.

line.tr: If you, our help[er]s, recognise Mahāśramaṇa as your teacher [and] break [lit. give up] your own vow, why should we be amazed? (cf 394)
Wenn ihr, unser Beistand [im Toch. Plural] den Mahāśramaṇa als euren Lehrer anerkennt [und] euer eigenes Gelübde aufgebt, was sollten [wtl. sind] wir [da] verwundert sein?
If you, our helper[s], acknowledge Mahāśramaṇa as your master [and] give up your own vow, why should [lit. are] we be amazed?
Whoever may be praised by you as refuge, to which doctrine you bind yourself, to that we bind ourselves too.

Darauf machten sich die zwei verbrüderten Kāśyapas zusammen mit [ihren] Schülern auf, [und] zum Buddha, dem Lehrer, gekommen, sprachen sie: "O Mahāśramaṇa! Zusammen (mit) dem Gefolge von diesen sind wir herbeigekommen. Wir nehmen Zuflucht zur Behausung deiner Füße. Lass uns (aus dem Hause) hinausgehen [d.h. lass uns Mönche werden], erlöse uns (von dem Leid, lass uns) den Gesetzes-Nektar zuteil (werden)!"

Thereupon the two affiliated kāśyapas, together with [their] students, sallied forth, [and] having come to the Buddha, the teacher, they said: "Oh Mahāśramaṇa! Together with a retinue of these we have come here. We take refuge in the home of your feet. Let us go (out of the house) [i.e. let us become monks], redeem us (from suffering, let us partake) of the nectar of the law."
(Das Jaṭila-Gewand) ... verschwand ihnen, und nur Kaṣāyagewänder wurden an ihrem Körper gesehen.
(The Jaṭila-garb) ... disappeared from them, and only Kaṣāya-garments were seen on their body.
Ihr [herbei] gekommenen Mönche, übet Sittlichkeit!
Ye monks [that have] come [here], observe morality!
I will not teach that to you [pl.] now.
Der in Kunstfertigkeit [und] upāya geschickte Alleswissende, der Herr, führte die Flechtenträger-Gemeinde fort.
The Omniscient, skilled in artistry [and] upāya, the lord, led the community of plait-bearers away.

Es war ein Rājarṣi, Gaya [mit] Namen, sich dort aufhaltend. Nach dessen Namen ist der Hain Gayāśīrṣa [mit]Namen benannt worden. Dort pflegte der Buddha [seinen] Lieblingsaufenthalt zu nehmen. ODER (Thomas 1957): Mit dessen Namen hat er [scil. der Buddha] den Hain Gayāśīrṣa [mit]Namen benannt. Dort pflegte der Buddha [seinen] Lieblingsaufenthalt zu nehmen

A Rājarṣi, Gaya [by] name, was staying there. After his name the grove Gayāśīrṣa was called [by]name. There the Buddha was wont to stay [as his] favourite sojourn. OR (Thomas 1957): ...with his name he [i.e. the Buddha] has called the grove Gayāśīrṣa [by] name. There the Buddha was wont to stay [as his] favourite sojourn.
Die vier Körperbewegungen führte er vor: [wtl. machte er]: Er setzte sich, stellte sich [hin], ging hin und her [und] machte die Gebärde des Liegens.
The four bodily movements he made: he sat [down], stood, went to and fro [and] made the gesture of lying [down].

Nachdem er [scil. der Buddha] diese [scil. die Flechtenträgermönche] durch die Wunder zu Gläubigen bekehrt hatte, rief er sie in dem Wunsch [wtl. wünschend], [ihnen] mit Rücksicht darauf, dass sie eben Feuerverehrer waren, das ebenderselben Familie angehörige Gesetz [d.h. das ihnen gemäße Gesetz] vorzutragen, [und] sprach zu ihnen:

After he [i.e. the Buddha] had converted them [i.e. the monks wearing plaits] into believers with [the help of] miracles, he summoned them, wishing to proclaim [to them], with regard to [the fact that] they were venerators of the fire, the law pertaining to the same family [i.e. the law appropriate to them] [and] spoke to them:

internalComments.comment: Why should we translate this as "Buddha said" and not "Yaśodharā said"? It would give a much more natural translation: "Only one person (ever) managed to bewitch me with his charms." This strikes me as better than inventing a meaning "just once" for ṣe ka just for this passage. And even so, wouldn't we much rather expect ṣeme ka in that case? Also, in the Buddha legend, it is generally Yaśodharā who is obsessed with Siddhārtha, rather than the other way around.
What is sākäske? And tu ttu?

line.tr: 仏陀・先生は言った。
為すために君たちは励みなさい。輪廻にかかわる諸々の激情［と］執着を このように
諸々の食物、諸々の飲物、諸々の付属［の飲食］物を用意したのちに、金・銀の宝、真珠のを
ヤショーダラーは］塗りつけた (3.sg)。冠を［自分の］頭の上に［ヤショーダラーは］据え置いた (3.sg.)。諸々の真珠、諸々の真珠の首飾り、真珠のを
後宮の女性たちをともなってラーフラを見に行くという口実で、カピラヴァストゥ
ヤショーダラーは］アンジャリを両手に作り、車輪という特長によって飾られた聖なる柔らかい［両足を］
諸々の付属［の飲食］物を。［彼女は、］僧団ともども仏陀・先生に行ないを為した (3.sg.)
これを聞いたのちに、諸々の激情すべてを［ヤショーダラーは］取り除いた (3.sg.)。預流の位を得た (3.sg.)。
仏陀・先生は］言った。［かつて］一度だけ彼女（ヤショーダラー）が私を諸々の甘味によって魅了する ことができた。
仏陀は］ニャグローダーラーマ僧院 へ向かって行き始めた (3.sg.) 。ヤショーダラー王妃の
彼女の心の中に生じた (3.sg.) 。［彼女は］バルコニーからまさに自ら飛び降りた（←まさに自らを飛び落とした (3.sg.)）。まさにこの生において
比丘たちが仏陀・］先生に告げた (3.pl.)：「避難所［と］防護［である者］よ、ヤショーダラー王妃は十力を有する者（仏陀）に対する好意のゆえに
私のために［ヤショーダラーは生命を］捨てた (3.sg.)。以前の時にも私への執着ゆえに生命を捨てた。そのことを君たちは聞きなさい。
キンナラは、ぐっすり眠っていた。ヤシャスヴィニ［という名の］ キンナラ女は 、火に向かって目覚めて座っていた
［王は］全力で弓を一杯に張って［矢を］放った (3.sg.)。善良なキンナラを心臓
度（？）、近くに聖なる思考を［それらは］残している／留めている 。君はまさしくその間 私を解放しなさい 、間
そして、まさにその時（それをする時）私は彼女を見よう 。まさしく何らかの諸々の手振り・身振り（→振る舞い）を
迅速に行った (3.sg.)
Das Diadem setzte sie [scil. Yaśodharā] sich aufs Haupt
She [i.e. Yaśodharā] set the diadem upon her [own] head.
Nur einmal gelang es ihr [scil. Yaśodharā], mich mit süßen Genüssen zu betören.
Only once, she [i.e. Yaśodharā] was able to seduce me with sweet pleasures.
... hüpfte in ihrem Herzen, [und] sie stürzte sich vom Söller herab.
... leapt in her heart, [and] she cast herself from the balcony.
Schon in früherer Zeit hat sie aus Neigung zu mir [ihr] Leben hingegeben.
In earlier times already she gave [her] life out of affection for me.
Mit ganzer Kraft spannte er voll den Bogen [und] schoss.
With all [his] strength he drew the bow [and] shot.

line.tr: If he meets him, he is not glad and he hides the thing in secret.
Er lobt ihn vor Augen, anderswo [aber] spricht er Tadel über ihn ..., er lobt seine Feinde, sein Wissen leugnet er ab [und] freut sich nicht über [seinen] Besitz.
He praises him before [his] eyes, elsewhere he speaks censure over him ..., he praises his enemies, his knowledge he denies [and] is not pleased by [his] possessions.

line.tr: Liebe die rechte [wtl. wahre] Ansicht!
Love the proper [lit. true] notion!
Wenn du aber böse Tat tust, (wirst du) die Frucht davon ... (erfahren(?)).
If, however, you do a bad, the fruit of it ... (you will experience(?)).
If you, o great king, act according to my word, you will attain great glory and kingship among both gods and men.
Wer Herr ist, wird Knecht.
Who is lord becomes servant.
Kingship and rulership are not permanent: who is lord will become servant and who is servant (in this birth) will become lord (later).
Milch erbitten sie von (den) Wesen.
Milk they ask of the beings.

I will teach these causes to you, and this great compassion

line.tr: O du zum Heil aller Unermüdlicher, ich verehre deinen Glanz.
Oh you to the salvation of all unremitting ones, I venerate your splendour.
Was auch immer für glanzvolle Wesen [da sind], du hast diese in allem übertroffen.
Whatever splendid beings [there are], you have surpassed these in everything.

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 b1 b2 b3 b4

line.tr: Durch den Preis von Leben hast du diesen Glanz gesammelt.
For the price of life you have gathered this splendour.
Dich, den durch Glanz Geformten, den Allerglänzendsten, verehre ich.
You, the one formed by splendour, the most splendid one, I venerate.

With the thirty-seven cures you have mixed the sweet aṃrta-cure of the good law.

With the light of knowledge you light up the worlds.

You also let know all the (ones suffering the) Saṃsāra, because you were able to tell earlier [events] of the Saṃsāra.

line.tr: «I will be an omniscient [Buddha]», thus he roared the great lion roar …

«If I try to redeem myself from such sorrows, I will put them aside who made me … with the beings of the five births.» Thereupon he took the firm resolution with his mind: «[In] all [my] lives, (with) all [my] bodies, (I will strive) for the welfare of the beings (of the five births).» (cf 720; 1957: 227; 1997: 141; 342)
Darauf fasste er den festen Entschluss in seinem Denken.
Thereupon he made the firm decision in his thought.

Even if all beings crush my bones fine like to dust, or if they chop up my body …, or if I had to undergo sorrows of hell, or if because of the smallest thing I underwent sorrow[s] of hell, may the power of my mind not fail … (cf 725; 1997: 118; 466)

With the drum of the law you have summoned the [beings] of the five incarnations to the city of Nirvāṇa.

And also like the moon among the planets you appeared, [when] surrounded by monks.

line.tr: Zum Heile der Welt hat dein Geist niemals verzagt.
To the benefit of the world your spirit has never quailed.
Who else could have that ability?

If [when] you first left the body of [your] mother, you have roared friendship (maitrī) for the benefit of all, and if you have sought to understand the seed of the sorrows, then you have achieved happiness, the ultimate of the virtues.

Als du zuerst aus dem Leib der Mutter herausgegangen bist und [als] du freundschaftliche Gesinnung zum Heil aller gebrüllt hast und als du den Samen(?) der Leiden zu erkennen gesucht hast, [da] hast du dadurch das Glück, das Höchste [wtl. das Ende, Ziel] aller Tugenden, erwirkt.

When you first went forth from the body of [your] mother and [when] you roared fair-mindedness for the salvation of all and when you tried to perceive the seed(?) of suffering, [then] by this you effected happiness, the [ultimate] end of all virtue.
Du hast Leid ertragen, [aber] von [deinem] Entschluss, die Welt von den Leiden zu erlösen, hast du dich, wo auch immer, nicht [fort]bewegt [d.h. bist du nicht abgewichen].
You have borne suffering, [but] wherever [you have been], you have not moved [i.e. you have not turned away] from [your] decision to redeem the world from suffering.

line.tr: ... mit dem Pfeil (namens) ... besiegt habend, möchte ich diese Welt von den Kleśa-Feinden erlösen!
... with the arrow (named) ... having defeated, may I deliver the world from the kleśa-enemies!

O du alle Wünsche Gewährender, von dir erbitte ich einen Wunsch: Von dieser Geburt an bis zur Zeit des Erlöschens möchte ich nicht an die Schädigung des Herzens selbst tötender Feinde auch nur in Gedanken denken, geschweige denn mit Körper [und] Wort.
From this birth on until the time of extinction I do not want to think, even in thought, about the damage of the heart even of murdering enemies, let alone in body and word.

pada.s:
You (have gone?) into the nirvāṇa–
twe , nervāṃne ;
may you listen attentively to this! yneśne ram no , klyauṣit te
For these are Tuṣita gods who were your relatives. cai wa ñakti , toṣitṣṣi ; kUse tañ ṣeyeṃ , ṣañ śamna •

In the honoring of the good, through the power among the wealthy, in the vimāna of the Tuṣita gods, overflowing with glory, for the sake of the beings of five births, you were not obtaining pleasure. winālñene , krentantso ; yātalñesa , śateṃne •
pernerñesa , plätkweṣne ; tuṣitäṣṣe , wimāṃne •
piś cmelaṣṣeṃs , pernesa ; mā we wīna , kälpāṣṣit •

And for the sake of the law, you were renouncing it (pleasure?) quickly. pelaiknentse , pelki
ñ no ; ot ṣpä ramer , arṣit twe •
Without pity, the beings, ceaseless in their evil, were inflicting violent pain on you, the refuge and hope of the world. snai kkarūṃ cai , onolmi ; amaukacci , yolosa •

saim pärmaṅk cī , śaiṣṣentse ; lakle räskre ,
yāmṣiyeñ-c •
They were cutting of your hands and feet while they were piercing your eyes. ṣarne paine , kärsnoyeñ-c ; inte kc= eśne , tsaknoyeñ-c
They were cutting off the (=your) heads wearing dieadems, unconcerned. mahūrtstsana , āstäṃ toṃ ; empalkaicci , kärsnoyeñ-c :

They were torturing you,
tsarkanoyeñ-c ,
they wäre cooking you, päkṣiyeñ-c ;
they were finely crushing your bones. āsta lykaśke , kautanoñ-c •
They were burning your skin, yetse tsäkṣyeñ-c ,
they were cutting of all of your flesh. kektseñmeṃ ; latkanoyeñ-c , misa po •
You were not disturbed by them. mā twe ceṃne , krämpitar ;
Your mind was not falter. mā ra palsko , kulyitär-ś :
You were seeking with desire the excellent life in accordance with the law. pelaikneṣṣe , śaul śpālmeṃ ; cauk twe ñyāssa , ñäṣṣitar •

And further, lord, this matter is estimated as most wonderous by me: te ṣpä saswa , āktike ; posa ynāñm ñī , se
wäntre •
tu as pris part à toutes les choses accumulées avec tant de souffrance. tot laklesa , kakraupaṣ ; pontaṃts pāke , yāmṣasta •
You were consoling us, tsārwäṣṣitme ,
you were calling us śauśitme ;
you were making others feel aversion to the world. mrauskäṣṣitar , alyeṅkäṃ •

"Oh, my dears! Recieve this nectar of the law." yśe
lareñ nai , pūrpat tā ; pelaikneṣṣai , yokastai •
The manner of others, however, is this: alyeṅkäṃts no , se yakne ;

s.tr: if they find the jewel that they search with eagerness, they hide it secretly.

pada.s:
kwri cau kallaṃ , naumiye ;
tukäskenträ , enestai •
More than all, over all, and from all, this manner of yours distinguishes itself. posa auṣap , pos= olypo ; pomeṃ wākṣtär-ś , seṃ yakne •

That is why deep [lit. broad] love to you, o help and stay, has come to me. tesa ykū ñī , saim wästa ; cīne aurtse ,
larauññe •
That is your power of omniscience. sāU tañ maiyyo , poyśiña ;
and this is our ability: se ṣpä wesäñ , cimpamñe •
Compared with the enemy of inconstancy, you, we are lacking. anityātṣṣe , sanaṃmpa ; eṣe cimpa , mäṅkāmo •
Truly, you were... auspa ṣait

line.tr: You (have gone?) into the nirvāṇa—may you listen attentively to this! For these are Tuṣita gods who were your relatives. (cf 74)

Dir, dem Schutz [und] der Hoffnung der Welt, taten sie [scil. die Wesen] bitteres Leid: Hände [und] Füße schnitten sie dir ab; wo [bzw. wann] auch immer stachen sie dir die Augen aus; die diademgeschmückten Häupter schnitten dir die Rücksichtslosen ab; sie quälten dich [und] kochten dich; die Knochen spalteten sie dir klein; die Haut zogen sie dir vom Körper ab und schnitten dir alles Fleisch ab: Du [aber] warst nie ärgerlich [wtl. gestört, verstört] auf sie, auch ließ dein Denken nie nach. Nach den Leben des Gesetzes als dem besten, nach dem eben begehrtest du [immer wieder] mit Verlangen.

On you, the shelter [and] hope of the world, they [i.e. the beings] inflicted bitter suffering: hands [and] feet they cut from you; where [when?] ever they stung out your eyes; your heads adorned with diadems the ruthless ones cut off; they tortured you [and] cooked you; your bones they cracked to small bits; [your] skin they drew from your body and all the flesh [they] cut from you: [but] you were never vexed with them, also your thinking never declined. [It was] for the life of the law as the best [possible life], for this exactly you [always] longed with desire.
Du tröstestest sie [scil. die Wesen] [und] riefst sie [und] machtest andere [welt]überdrüssig [mit den Worten]: "O, [ihr] Lieben, genießt doch nur diesen Gesetzestrank!"
You comforted them [i.e. the beings] [and] called them [and] made others [world-]weary [saying]: "Oh, [you] dear ones, do savour this potion of the law!"
Wenn sie das Juwel, nach dem sie da sehnsüchtig [wtl. mit Verlangen] suchen, finden, verstecken sie es insgeheim.
When they find the jewel that they are seeking with longing, they will hide it secretly.

The manner of others, however, is this: if they find the jewel that they search with eagerness, they hide it secretly. More than all, over all, and from all, this manner of yours distinguishes itself. That is why deep [lit. broad] love to you, o help and stay, has come to me.
Mehr als alles, über alles hinaus, von allem unterscheidet sich diese deine Art.
More than everything, above everything, from everything this your manner differs.

Das [ist] deine Allerkenner-Kraft und dies unser Vermögen: [Im Vergleich] mit dem Feind der anityatā [Unbeständigkeit], [nämlich] mit dir, werden wir unterliegen. ODER: Das [ist] deine Allerkenner-Kraft und dies unser Vermögen, [das im Vergleich] mit dem Feind der anityatā, [nämlich] mit dir, unterlegen [ist].

This [is] your omniscient power and this our ability: [in comparison] with the enemy of the anityatā [inconstancy], [that is], with you, we will succumb. OR: This [is] your omniscient power and this our ability, [which, in comparison] with the enemy of the anityatā, [that is], with you, [is] inferior.

line.tr: O [du] Beherzter [und] Mutiger, die maireya-trunkene Truppe(?) (des) Māra [und] die ganze Karawane hast du ihm mit dem Helden [deines] Herzens in die Flucht geschlagen [wtl. schwinden gemacht].
Oh [you] stout-hearted [and] brave one, Māra's host(?), drunk on maireya, [and] the entire caravan you have turned to flight on him [lit. made disappear] with the hero [in/of your] heart.
Du hast ihn [scil. Māra] (mitsamt dem) Kleśa-Heer ins Herz getroffen.
You have struck him [i.e. Māra] (with [all] [his] kleśa-host) into the heart.
Wie [dein] Leben hast du sorgfältig die Richtlinien des sittlichen Verhaltens gehütet.
Like [your] life, you have carefully kept the rules of moral behaviour.
Mit Leben hast du die Leben der Leben-Besitzenden erkauft.
With life you have bought the lives of the ones [who] have life.
As often as I think of your heart made without … by compassion, so often I go into your protection, o god, up to the marrow in the bones.
Meine Sünden [wtl meine Sündenpunkte] bekenne ich zu deinen Füßen: in dem Entschluss, [mich] zu beherrschen, erbitte ich von dir Verzeihung.
My sins [lit. my sin-points] I confess at your feet: determined to restrain [myself], I crave forgiveness from you.
Weil ich, auf Gläubigkeit gestützt, dich gepriesen habe, o [du] zu Preisender, möchten mir durch diese Tat [meine] Zungensünden abgewaschen werden.
Since, relying on faith, I have praised you, oh [you person] to be praised, may, through this deed, the sins of [my] tongue be washed off me.

line.tr: Glück mit Leid [ist] miteinander nicht nach Wunsch erlangbar.
Bliss with suffering [is] not obtainable together as per wish.
Einer, der wie du [wtl. zusammen mit dir] in Liebe [Glück und Leid] fernhält, wird nicht gefunden [d.h. einen, der ... fernhält, gibt es nicht].
[Some]one who like you [lit. together with you] in love keeps [bliss and suffering] away is not found [i.e. one, who ... keeps away does not exist].

Even when those who love have come to one another, if the mind hurts … (love?) turns (away?) … You are fit to protect the mind of the whole world. … (mind) … and you love [beyond] the love there is to you. (cf 739)
Nur dann (haben) die Menschen dieser Zeit Liebe, nur um Dinge zu (erlangen), lieben sie. Hört [aber] das Ding auf, [so] (wendet sich) auch die Liebe ab.
Only then (do) the people of this time (have) love, only to (obtain) things do they love. If [however] the thing ceases, love (turns away) also.
Only then have the people of this time love, if they love to obtain things. If the thing ceases [to exist], [their] love turns away too. Your love to all is enduring without a thing.

line.tr: Everytime I saw you going through lands and villages, my mind and heart leapt for joy, or everytime you entered the community the gods bowed their knees with añjali hands. (cf 69, 213)

Oder aber, [immer wenn] du in die Versammlung eintratest, neigten sich die Götter mit zusammengelegten Händen vor mir zu Erde [mit den Worten:] "Die Mutter des Buddha ist gekommen, Sie, die Leuchtende, [ist] auf der Stirn zu tragen."

Or else, [whenever] you entered the assembly, the gods would bow to the ground before me with folded hands [saying:] "The mother of the Buddha has arrived, she, the radiant one, [must be] borne on the forehead."
Jetzt ist mir die Hoffnung ganz zerstört worden, [denn] ich habe dich, die Sohnesperle, verloren, ich habe alle meine Glücksgüter [wtl. alle Glücksgüter des Selbstes] verloren.
Now my hope has been entirely destroyed, [for] I have lost you, pearl of sons, I have lost all my blessings [lit. all blessings of the self].
Warum (nimmst(?)) du mir nicht (das Leben) fort? Streue meinen Körper auseinander!
Why do you not (take [my] life) from me? Scatter my body about!

[skt:] if [fools] contemn your teaching [tb:] if they blame the law (cf 168)
s'étant souvenu de cela.

Freiheit [wtl. das Nach-seinem-eigenen-Selbst-Sein], (das Glück der) [vollkommenen] Erkennt(nis [d.h. der Erleuchtung], die Verehrung deiner Tugenden), Weisheit: all dies - eine erfreuliche Vierheit - wird aus deiner Lehre erreicht.

Independence [lit. being-according-to-your-own-self], (the joy of) [complete] percept(ion [i.e. enlightenment], praise of your virtues), wisdom: all this - four pleasant things - is gained from your teaching.

Dass sie [scil. die Menschen] nicht zu dieser deiner Lehre, [die] so voll von guten Eigenschaften [ist], Zuflucht nehmen, o du Vorzüglichster [wtl. Stier] unter den Weisen, (was [ist] verderblicher als das?)
That they [i.e. the humans] do not take refuge with this your teaching, so full of good qualities, oh you most excellent [lit. bull] among the wise, (what [is] more ruinous than this?)

line.tr: Die Bedrückung geben sie anderen [und] vertrauen auf ein glückliches eigenes Selbst.
Despondency they give to others [and] trust in an own, happy self.
(Besitztümern) [und] Glücksgütern wendet sich die Welt sehr zu.
(Possessions) [and] blessings the world very [much] inclines to.
Sie vertrauen auf ein glückliches eigenes Selbst.
They trust in [their] own happy self.
Ihr [scil. der Welt] folgen die Leiden nach wie ein Schatten.
Suffering follows it [i.e. the world] like a shadow.
Den Glücksgütern folgt die Welt, wie das Wasser [Im Toch. Plural] bei Wassersucht [folgt]. Ihr [scil. der Welt] folgen die Leiden nach wie der Schatten.
The world follows the blessings, [just] like the water [follows in cases of] dropsy. Suffering follows it [i.e. the world] like a shadow.
Die in Leid Gefallenen erträgt das Glück nicht in [seiner] Nähe. Wie ein undankbarer Mensch lässt es sich in der Not nicht blicken [wtl. wird es nicht gesehen].
Happiness does not tolerate the ones fallen into suffering near itself; Like an ungrateful human, it is not seen in [times of] need.
Wer keine eigenen Glücksgüter hat, der erbittet [sie] von einem anderen [d.h. ist von dem Verlangen danach erfüllt und gibt dem Ausdruck].
He who has got no goods and blessings of his own asks them of another [i.e. is filled with desire for them and expresses this feeling].
Wenn eine Hütte die Verkehrtheit eines Betruges(?) bedeckt, [so] wird sie [scil. die Hütte; oder das?] als verkehrt empfunden [wtl. aufgefasst].
If a hut covers the wrongness of deception(?), it [the hut?] will be conceived as wrong.
Ein rauhes Denken erhebt stets Zweifel, für Glück ist kein Augenblick [da].
Rough thinking always raises doubt, for happiness [there] is no moment.
This [is] the blindness of the world, a terrible enemy for oneself; in the dark hells the deed takes hold of oneself.
The earth does not support the evil one, but it always covers him if it decides [so].
Die Erde erträgt nicht den Bösewicht(?): stets verhüllt sie sich(?), wenn er entscheidet(?).
The Earth does not bear the villain(?): at all times it veils itself(?) when he decides(?).
Die ganze Person(?) [wtl. das ganze Fleisch] ist nicht vertrauenswürdig, deren Art nicht gelobt wird.
The entire person(?) [lit. the entire flesh] is not trustworthy, whose manner is not praised.
Wer das Denken nicht erfreut, der ist ein hölzernes Eisen.
He who does not please thought, [this one] is wooden iron
He who is alive takes the deed into account [only] when he dies.
[Selbst] im Fieber des Denkens erlangt er (keine) Hitze.
[Even] in the fever of thought he gets (no) heat.
He who fathers fifty-two distinguished children does not know them if he does not see them, [and] they do not give him their own power.
Wer sich zweiundfünfzig ausgezeichnete Söhne erzeugt, [der] kennt sie nicht, wenn er sie nicht sieht.
[He] who generates fifty-two excellent sons for himself will not know them if he does not see them.
If from the five discordance arises, having made the lie their refuge they blame the good ones and tell lies about their companions.
Would they ward off this world and will they bow for distress and shame?
Diese fünf [Mächte] sollen [zwar] die Welt fernhalten, sollen sich aber der Not und Scham beugen.
These five [powers] shall ward off the world, but [at the same time they] shall submit to misery and shame.

According to , this press mark consists of two fragments that do not touch. This is correct in itself, but the right hand fragment consists in turn of three smaller fragments that are not well assembled. All four fragments are in one frame, but recto and verso of the largest right hand fragment (here numbered "3") are reversed. In other words, the recto of the frame shows the recto of the left hand fragment and two smaller pieces (here numbered "1" and "2") of the right hand fragment, but the verso of the largest piece of the right hand fragment. A digital reconstruction is given directly below; the original images follow. (Instead of a detail of the recto of the left hand fragment, IDP gives a detail of .)

tsäṅkowa agrees with krentauna, which then has the adjectival suffix -ṣṣe, so it must be read as "pertaining to the virtues that have arisen". It is unclear what this is supposed to mean in the context. Maybe the segmentation is wrong and we should read krentaunaṣṣe naṣtsi (or rather taṣtsi?).

This world, which lacks the water consisting of [in?] a good friend and furthermore [lacks] the virtues, dries up, and the sun of wrong ideas burns it.
If miserable … without feathers [the young bird] rises from its nest and falls down on earth, then it misses wiñcaññe120 because of pride. Like the mind … (cf 601)

Likewise, someone who sees the purity of his mind, but not having trained his wisdom leaves the [right] way and puts his trust in love and the … (of) compassion—having deceived his own mind he misses the object.

... wer [zwar] die Reinheit des eigenen Denkens sieht, [aber], [weil] er den Verstand nicht geläutert [hat], von der rechten Weise abgeht [und] [nur] auf Liebe [und] Mitleid vertraut [wtl. vertrauensvoll macht] ..., (der) ... verfehlt das Ziel.

... who[ever] sees the purity of [his] own thinking, [but], [since] he [has] not cleansed the mind, turns away from the [right] manner [and] [only] trusts in love [and] compassion [lit. makes trusting] ..., (he) ... misses [his] destination.
If because of this the good beings …, and they cause to do good to the other without wisdom and with a faitful mind they put their trust [in] the good, then afterwards, (however, they repent it).

line.tr: If someone is hardly even born, certainly he dies afterwards.
Ist einer kaum geboren, [so] stirbt er gewiss späterhin.
One who has just been born will certainly die later on.

Having to be separated from the dear; reunion with the unpleasant; eventually not being able to obtain a thing [long] cherished; [the fact that] things achieved are certainly to perish afterwards—these sorrows are here because of the [re]births.
Wären die Körper nicht für die Menschen in der Welt...
If the bodies were not in the world for the humans...
If the beings in the world had no bodies, they would not undergo bodily pains at all. If there were no mind, pains of the mind would not be there at all in the world either.
Hätten die Menschen in der Welt keine Körper, [so] würden sie gar keine körperlichen Leiden erdulden.
If humans had no bodies in [this] world, they would not undergo any physical suffering at all.

internalComments.comment: Why is "mā walke" translated as "within long"?
The translation is wrong. First, it should be "who is whose relative?"; second "If they go bound to eachother by causes..."

I think it would be best to translate these lines as two questions: "Who would, after having gone away, be in thought about them? Who would, regarding this truth as fleeting as a bubble, in deceptive carelessness and out of a wish for relatives (?) chase after him who swallowed the bait of desire?" It is still not entirely clear what pälycä-pälyc ra weru ramt refers to - maybe it rather belongs to the "him who swallowed the bait of desire" than the "truth".
What's up with the agreement on añmlāṣkai?
