line.tr: Who is in the turning saṃsāra the relative of someone else? If they are bound by causes, they go together with each other, [but] when the causes have disappeared they go separate ways again and have no eye for the clinging of their relatives [anymore]. (cf 274)
Wer in trügerischem Leichtsinn aus Selbstsucht den Köder Durst verschlungen [hat], dürfte d[ies]em nachlaufen.
Who, in fallacious carelessness [and] out of selfishness, [has] swallowed the bait [that is] thirst, might follow [this] one.

Und zu dem alle Leiden auslöschenden, zu dem nehmt Zuflucht, ihr beiden, zu dem von dem mitleidigen Lehrer verkündeten guten Gesetz, damit ihr auch nicht verbrannt werdet (in eben solchem Feuer) der Trennung in dem sich wieder [und] wieder drehenden schrecklichen (Saṃsāra).

And with the one extinguishing all suffering, with him take refuge, both of you, with the good law proclaimed by the compassionate teacher, so that you are not burnt (in just such a fire) of separation in the ever [and] ever turning, terrible (Saṃsāra).
Niemand ist in der Welt, der da etwa aus dieser (Not) erlöst werden könnte.
There is nobody in the world that may be released from this (plight).
You should keep to the morals, so that you get out of sorrow.

comments.comment: The language of the fragment is archaic, i.e. archaic-I in the sense of . /ə/ is mostly written ‹ä›, irrespective of the accent, and ‹ā› for /a/ is found in unaccented position as well as ‹a› in accented position. For statistics, see the tables in –36. Other late features, such as ṣc for śc or the diphthong eu are not found.

A striking peculiarity of this fragment is the spelling ‹ṅ› for ‹ṅk› before vowel: a3 eṅalyñesā; a3 eṅäläññe; a5 eṅälyñe; b8 ṅe (cf. –179). Although this phenomenon is rare, it is not unique and clearly confined to archaic texts, compare a5, b4, and b4.
Mobile -o is found once, b3 pontäṃntso, against eight times final -ä: a3 (arä)ñcä, a3 pärskoṣä, a5 pestä, a7 nukowä, a9 krentä, b3 ptesä, b5 keśä, b6 yamästä.

Unexpected gemination is often found: a2 kwaṣṣaine, a3 tsetsärkkoṣ, a9 pyamttsait (probably not to be read pyamntsait in this archaic text, cf. –157), a9 lläklenta, b2 weñña; and perhaps a9 keṣṣeñcai (cf. –568). On the other hand, the spelling of n before t as ‹ṃn› seems to be regular and need not indicate gemination: a5 śāmnāṃnts, b2 ñäkteṃnts, b3 pontäṃntso, b4 mäṃnt. Remarkably, no gemination is found in a4, a8 sportomāne for sporttomane.
"Stretching" with unusual ä-epenthesis is found in the following cases: a2 saṃsāräṣṣai, a2 tsrelläññeṣṣe, a3 eṅäläññe, b4–5 saṃsāräntse.

Instead of a verbal noun a gerund is found two times: a10 tsrelyeṣṣe, b3 srukālleṣṣe. Also b2 tsrelle could syntactically be interpreted as a verbal noun. However, correct verbal nouns are more frequent: a1 srukalyñentse, a2 tsrelläññeṣṣe, a3 eṅalyñesā, a3 eṅäläññe, a5 eṅälyñe, b2 śmälñe, b5 yänmalyñe.

The scribe seems to have had no opposition between o and au, as the two are mixed up in writing. Most frequent is o for au: a1 potkn(e) (for pautke), a2 potke, a2 śoläṣṣe, a4 śomo, b3 kärstoca. The reverse spelling au for o is also found: b4 tsälpauyträ. There is only one case of au for archaic au: a4 nanauta(r)meṃ. Also, the scribe does not seem to have had the archaic diphthong ew other than in ce_u, since au is found for archaic ew in a4 alyaucempa.
Unlike o and au, e and ai are distinguished regularly. Two exceptions are a2 empelye for empelyai and a9 añmalāṣkai for añmalāṣkeṃ, both perhaps morphological rather than phonological mistakes.
The word mant is spelled mäṃ in b2, b3, but mäṃnt in b4.
Anusvāra has to be added against the manuscript in the following instances: a7, b4 nesä〈ṃ〉, b4 cenme〈ṃ〉.

The script of the fragment has archaic features: ‹_ṣ_a› is open; ‹_m_a› has a cross; ‹_n_a› is a triangle with one angle down (pace , ‹_m_a› and ‹_n_a› are clearly distinct). However, ‹ma› is mostly closed and ‹ka› and ‹a› are not archaic; ‹o› has a short stroke up. All in all, the script is archaic, but of a relatively late type.
‹pa› is mostly closed on top, but still distinct from ‹ṣa›, whose horizontal closing bar is lower than the top of the vertical strokes.
‹v› for ‹w› is found three times: a7 śvāl, b5, b6 tve.

Both poems are in a rather regular 4 x 7 ¦ 7 metre, apparently without indication of the tune name. In view of the irregular writing, it is striking that the metre is regular almost throughout. Small irregularities are a3 ente mā eṅäläññe with 3+4 instead of 4+3 and b2 nemcek postäṃ tsrelle ake with 4+4 instead 4+3, probably to be read as nemcek postäṃ tsrell= āke (see also the text notes above). Although the leaf is damaged on all edges, it is virtually complete. Unlike in –186, the edges are not indicated with "///" if there are no akṣaras missing. No leaf number is preserved. Possibly, it is a independent leaf, as it contains exactly one poem of 6 strophes on one side (here side a) and exactly one poem of 4 strophes on the other side (here side b). The interline and character spacing is irregular, obviously as a consequence of the scribe's effort to fit the poems nicely on one side each. There seems to be no way to decide which sides were originally to be the recto and verso.
, beginning: the restoration (sportomāne saṃsārne) of is excluded by the manuscript.
potkne: almost certainly a mistake for potke, i.e. pautke.
s(e): the restoration s(u) of is excluded by the manuscript.
tset_s[ä]rkko_ṣ\: read tset_s_arkko_ṣ\.

: especially the first two pādas of the fourth strophe are difficult. It is clear that pälycä-pälyc ra weru ramt is a quote or the content of a thought. According to the punctuation in (where no translation is given), their interpretation is approximately 'Might he who has gone away [from] them be with this thought: "[it is] fleeting like a bubble", also having paid true attention to this?' However, it is questionable whether śle pälsko can be interpreted that way; one would rather have expected kete tako_ī se pälsko. Therefore, śle-pälsko is more likely to be a compound with the meaning 'intelligent' (see ). In my translation, I have assumed a rather free word order in the relevant line, taking pälycä-pälyc weru ramt as the content of the following empreṃ (alternatively, it could be te, i.e. 'having paid true attention to this: ...'), and ra 'also' with the second half of the pāda.
: perhaps an alternative translation could be: '[Only] who out of the selfish wish for deceptive easiness has swallowed ...'.
_t_attārmeṃ :: the dots are placed not to the right, but on top of and under the akṣara ‹rmeṃ›.
yene: the dual is remarkable. Perhaps it refers to the two types of persion described in strophe 4.
pyamttsait\: sic, with regular final ‹t›.

(k_use): the restoration is uncertain. Ink traces can be discerned, but the manuscript is very abraded here. restore mā, which would give something like: 'There is (not) any coming together at all – having to be separated afterwards is certainly the end.' I find this interpretation a little less logical.

tsrelle ake: the reading ‹lle› is not obvious, since there is also an ā-stroke, and the akṣara ‹a› has been added later. Therefore, the original text was probably tsrell= āke, which would also make the metre fit.

t(e tve): this restoration is uncertain. The akṣara trace actually remaining is much smaller than is needed for ‹tv›, but perhaps the manuscript is abraded. In any case, the restoration t(usa) in is excluded by the manuscript.
(r)e(kisa): restoration according to . The restoration is uncertain because an element under the ‹ñ› can be discerned that would perhaps rather point to ‹ñ[ñ]e› than ‹ñ[r]e›.

line.tr: Erfreue unsere Gedanken!
Please our thoughts!
Du hast ihn [scil. den Buddha] sieben Tage lang mit einem Śloka gepriesen.
For seven days you praised him [i.e. the Buddha] with a śloka.
You are skilful as a boatman on the Ganges; I am zealous on the saṃsāra lake. Let [me] cross the stream with [your] boat on the Ganges [and] I will pull you out of the saṃsāra lake. (cf 487)

Du bist geschickt [als] Schiffer auf der Gaṅgā, ich bin auf dem Saṃsāra-See erfahren. Lass [du] auf der Gaṅgā das Schiff [wtl. mit dem Schiff] die Flut überschreiten, [so] werde ich dich aus dem Saṃsāra-See herausziehen.
You are skilled [as] a boatman on the Gaṅgā, I am experienced on the Saṃsāra-lake. [You] let the ship [lit. on the ship] cross the surge on the Gaṅgā, [then] I will pull you out of the Saṃsāra-lake.

, s.v. āmpär interprets śliye as belonging to ṣale. This is not too far fetched, since Tiṣya is written as tiṣyeṃ in this manuscript.

Interpreting wane as waṃne, which might belong to Sanskrit vana- "woods". s.v. gu, reads it as gune. It is true that gu and wa look similar, however, gu usually has a kind of "curl" that differentiates it from wa, which is not visible here.
With s.v. wänt-, this is to be read as paryariṣṣeṃ.

all have to die, pontas srukelle ;
why would I alone fear you? kā ñiś ṣeske , tañ prāskau

for you will bring me to the hells, including the Avīci! twe ṅke kalatarñ ; apiś wärñai , nreyentane :

line.tr: O Tod, ... [wenn] ich mich vor dir fürchte allezeit, wirst du aber mich in die Höllen, bis hin zur Avīci, bringen.
Oh death, ... [if] I fear you at all times, you, however, will bring me into the hells, all the way to the Avīci.
O Tod, ..., du aber wirst mich in die Höllen, bis hin zur Avīci, bringen.
Oh death, ... you, however, will bring me to the Hells, [all the way] down to the Avīci.

O death, I do not fear anything but you: all have to die, why would I alone fear you? Oh, this is my idea: «I am fearing because of you at all times, for you will bring me to the hells, including the Avīci!» (18)

line.tr: Ebenso ist, nachdem (er sich) vom Gesetz (abgewandt) und (der Gesetzlosigkeit) zugewandt hat, der Tor, (wenn er in die Gewalt des Todes gelangt ist), betrübt wie einer [scil. ein Fuhrmann], dessen Achse gebrochen ist.
In the same way, the fool, after (he has turned away) from the law and has turned towards (lawlessness), is sad like someone [i.e. a carter] whose axle has broken.
Das Nichtzutuende wird wiederum getan.
What is not to be done, on the other hand, is done.
(Der aber ist Träger des Gesetzes), der im Gesetz nicht nachlässig ist.
(He, however, is the bearer of the Law), who is not negligent in the Law.

line.tr: Nicht soll man einen schlechten Freund lieben, (nicht soll) man einen gemeinen Menschen (lieben); lieben soll man einen guten Freund, (lieben) soll man den besten Menschen.
One shall not love a bad friend, one (shall not love) a mean human; one shall love a good friend, (one shall love) the best human.
... soll man hier den Besten lieben.
... here, one shall love the best.
(Wenn man) stinkende Fische an die Spitze von Kuśagras (bindet), [so] riechen auch die Kuśagräser stinkig.
(If you tie) stinking fish to the top of kuśa-grass, the kuśa-grasses themselves will smell rotten.
(Wenn man [wtl. welcher Mensch] aber) Tagara [ein wohlriechendes Pulver] in ein Palāśa-Blatt einwickelt [wtl. einbindet], [so werden] auch die Blätter wohlriechend.
(If one [lit. which[ever] human], however,) wraps [lit. ties] tagara [a fragrant powder] into a palāśa-leaf, [then] also the leaves [will become] fragrant.
[Wenn] einer, auch wenn er nicht Böses [im Toch. Plural] tut, an einem Gefallen findet, (der [Böses] tut), [so] wird er des Bösen verdächtig.
[If] one, even if he does not do evil [pl. in Toch.], takes a fancy to someone (who does [evil]), he will be suspected of evil.

line.tr: (Verehrung sei dem Hochherzigen), dessen (Tugenden) nicht (durch Folgerungen und nicht durch Vergleiche), nicht durch Hören [wtl. pl.] ([und] nicht durch Nachdenken erschöpfend) erreicht werden [wtl. das Ende, Ausmaß von dessen Tugenden nicht ... erlangt wird].
(Honour be to the high-hearted), whose (virtues) are not (exhaustively) reached (by conclusions nor by comparisons), nor by listening [lit. pl.] ([and] not by thinking).

line.tr: He is to be dissuaded [lit. kept away] for a (second and a) third time. If he turns away [from his heretic viewpoint], it is good; if he does not turn away, it is a pātayantika offence.
Which monk consciously profits from a being who has spoken in that way and who he has not given up his wrong view—pātayantika [offence]. [5]6

Which monk takes up jewels with his own hand—(pātayantika). If it is within the boundary [of the monastery], he may take it up ([thinking], «whose) it may be, he is to take it back». This (here is the arrangement, pātayantika [5]8).

line.tr: ... together with a woman indicating the way ...
Wenn ein Mönch den Weg nicht kennt [und] eine Frau in der Eigenschaft eines Wegweisers mit ihm geht, [so liegt] kein Vergehen [vor].
If a monk does not know the way [and] a woman goes with him as a guide, [this is ] no offence.
If a monk has lost his way, … [and] he does not find a guide [and] he cannot but go on that road, [and] except for the woman he has no other guide, she … [may guide him].
(If a monk) ordains a person (under twenty), he commits a pātayantika offence. This [person] is not ordained.

If he thinks [lit. if his idea is] «I am not yet twenty years old» or if he is uncertain about it, … and he is not … close to twenty years, and in his mind he decisively has [the idea] «I am twenty years old», and he has nobody to remind him, …

line.tr: … if (he re)moves … (or) if (he) pulls out a shell or a vessel that has sunk into a mudhole, (but) pours back its contents, all [this amounts to a] duṣkṛta [offence]. If, however, by him walking along without a specific purpose the dust of the (good) soil is disturbed (or) if unintentionally the dust on heaps of wood and stone(s) is disturbed, this does not constitute an offence. The pātayantika [rule] concerned with violation of the soil has come to an end. (7)3. (121 and passim)

Wenn aber der Pflug im [Dahin]gehen ohne Vorstellung von der Erde sie [von sich aus] verletzt [oder wenn] der Pflug sie, für Holz [oder] Stein halten(d), ... (un)absichtlich [von sich aus] verletzt, [so] liegt kein Vergehen vor.

If, however, the plough, in going [along], without a notion of the earth, injures it [of its – the plough’s – own accord] [or if] the plough, keep(ing) it [viz. the earth] for wood [or] stone, ... injures it [of its own accord] and (without) purpose, [then] this is no offence.

Wenn aber der Pflug im Dahingehen von sich aus ohne Vorstellung von der Erde sie [scil. die Erde] verletzt [oder] wenn der Pflug sie , für Holz [oder] Stein haltend, unbeabsichtigt von sich aus verletzt, [so] ist [das] kein Vergehen.

If, however, the plough in passing along by its own accord without any idea of the earth hurts it [i.e. the earth] [or] if the plough, unintentionally hurts it of its own accord, taking it to be wood or stone, [then this] is no offence.

line.tr: A monk is to accept an invitation for four months only. If he pläkk· (accepts?) more than that, (even?) if it is not his intention, he has a pātayantika offence.
O Mönch, durch dich habe ich [wtl. ist mir] keine Last, und wonach [dir] der Wunsch gewesen ist, [das] wird nicht übergangen.
Oh monk, you are no burden to me [lit. due to you there is no burden [upon] me], and what[ever] [you] wished far shall not be passed over.

If the benefactor has invited [the monk] explicitly life-long, [or] if the benefactor invites him again and again, [saying] «monk, I have no trouble because of you and what you wish will not be passed over», or he calls on him in particular, [saying] «if we cannot, I call on others as representatives», or by himself he says with all his mind to him «monk, I tell you something good, please accept more from me»—if such grounds are not there, then the monk has no way to stay longer than four months by invitation.

Wenn der Gabenherr ausdrücklich lebenslänglich eingeladen haben sollte, [wenn] der Gabenherr ihn [scil. den Mönch] wieder [und] wieder einlädt ... oder [wenn] er ihn besonders einlädt [und sagt]: "Wenn wir nicht können, lade ich andere [als] Stellvertreter ein". ... liegen derartige Gründe nicht vor, [so] besteht für den Mönch auch keine [rechte] Art, mehr als vier Monate bei einer Einladung zu sitzen.

If the benefactor should emphatically have invited for a lifetime, [if] the benefactor invites him [i.e. the monk] again [and] again ... or [if] he invites him especially [and says]: "If we cannot [make it], I [shall] invite others as replacements". ... [If] there are no such reasons, [then] it is no [right] manner for a monk to sit in an invitation [for] more than four months.

«In the rainy season you have stayed among the householders», because of that they urged, «the four months are over». The monk, without being invited, asks the [householder] for still more than that. If then precisely he still stays by intimidation, he has a pātayantika offence. The monk should not be the one who requests.234 If he is insistently asking again and again and upsets (?) the mind of the benefactor, he is guilty [of the offence].

[Wenn] er [scil. der Mönch] darüber hinaus [d.h. über die Frist von vier Monaten hinaus], ohne eingeladen zu sein, diesen [scil. den Gabenherrn] noch bittet [und] kraft dessen noch bleibt [wtl. sitzt], [so] ist [das] für ihn ein Pātayantika-Vergehen. Der Mönch soll nicht Bittender sein. [Wenn] er wieder [und] wieder sehr bitten sollte, [so] ist der Sinn des Gabenherrn beunruhigt(?), [und] er [scil. der Mönch] wird schuldig.

[If] beyond that [i.e. the limit of four months], without being invited, he [i.e. the monk] still asks this one [i.e. the donator] [and] because of that still stays [lit. sits], [then] this is a pātayantika-offence for him. The monk shall not be one begging. [If] he should again[and] again very much beg, [then] the mind of the donator is troubled(?), [and] he [i.e. the monk] becomes guilty.

[Wenn] ein Gabenherr einen Mönch zum Essen einlädt [und] [zu]gleich sagt: "Ācārya, ... und bestimme [wtl. lass wissen] nur selbst den Zeit[punkt]!" - [wenn] er noch Derartiges dazu(?) gesagt haben sollte, auch dann geziemt es sich für den Mönch, so zu gehen.

[If] a benefactor invites a monk to a meal [and] [at the] same [time] says: "Ācārya, ... and only define [lit. let know] the time yourself!" - [if] he should have said the like also(?), even then it behoves a monk to leave thus.

If a benefactor invites a monk for dinner and at the same time says to him, «monk, I am alone, I am obliged (?) to go off (?), but I cannot—know your own time and come [back?] here»—if he has spoken like this, then it is proper that the monk should go.235 If he has not spoken like that [and] the messenger does not allow him a second day, [saying] «haven't we made us ready?», [the monk] should not go. If he goes, he is guilty [of an offence]. If he is [there] by invitation of a benefactor, it is not proper to say «bring this here», «bring that here». But if the time has completely come to an end, then it is proper to say «stop the treatment—time is up». It is certainly (?) not proper to do more urging (?) than that.

Wenn er [scil. der dānapati] auf diese Weise nicht gesprochen haben sollte [und] ihn [scil. den Mönch] nicht unter Ankündigung eines zweiten Tages entlässt [mit den Worten:] "Bereit haben wir uns gemacht" oder "nicht", [so] ist nicht zu gehen.

If he [i.e. the dānapati]should not have spoken in this manner [and should] not [have] released him [i.e. the monk], announcing a second day [and saying:] Ready we have made ourselves" or "not", leaving is not done.
[Wenn] er bei einer Einladung von Gabenherren ist, ziemt es sich nicht zu sagen: "Bringt [auch] dies noch! Bringt [auch] jenes noch!"
[If] he is at an invitation by donators, it is unfitting to say: "Bring this [also]! Bring that [also]!"

line.tr: Which [monk] thinks, «I will tell a lie», [and] telling it he knows, «I am telling a lie»

line.n: b1 first part and PK NS 58 a5 second part
line.tr: … «I will tell a lie», [and while] speaking he knows, «(I am telling) a lie», [but] afterwards he does not know it [anymore], then it was no lie.
[If] beforehand he does not intend to tell a lie, [and] suddenly he tells [one while] speaking, …
… [if] speaking he knows, «I am telling a lie», [and] indeed he says that thing, then that thing is not a lie.
Which monk says this, «I will give this to you», [but] does not give it;
or, «I will go with you», [but] he does not go;
… (which monk) says, «I will not eat anymore», [but] eats again;

line.tr: Der Buddha befand sich in Rājagṛha. Die Ṣaḍvārgikas nahmen Kauf, Verkauf [und] In-Tausch-Geben vor. Den Haushaltern war ein Handel mit Besitz nicht möglich. Daher waren die Haushalter übelgesinnt [und] tadelten [es]. Der Buddha hörte [und] tadelte [es]: "Welcher Mönch einen Edelstein/ein Wertobjekt für einen anderen Edelstein/Wertobjekt tauscht im Gedanken an einen Gewinn, der soll den Edelstein zurückgeben."

The Buddha was sojourning in Rājagṛha.. The Ṣaḍvārgikas conducted buying, selling [and] bartering. For the householders, trading with possessions was not possible. Therefore, the householders were evil-minded [and] scolded. The Buddha heard [this] and rebuked [it]: "Whichever monk exchanges a jewel/object of value for another jewel/object of value thinking of profit, he shall return the jewel."

Zu Upananda kam ein Ājīvika. Er trug einen roten Mantel [wtl. hatte einen r.M. angezogen]. Upananda erbat von ihm den Mantel; er [aber] gab ihn nicht [her]. Darauf tauschte er ihn gegen einen schlecht[er]en ein.
An Ājīvika came to Upananda. He wore a red coat [lit. had put on a red coat]. Upananda asked him for the coat; [but] he didi not give it [away]. Then he traded it for bad [i.e. worse] one.
Sie fragten ihn: "Hast du [deinen] Mantel weggegeben [wtl. weggetan]?"
They asked him: "Have you given [lit. put] away your cloak?"
Darauf tadelten ihn die Hausgenossen [und] schalten ihn [mit den Worten]: "[Wenn] du den Mantel nicht zurückbringst, werden wir dich infolgedessen vertreiben."
Thereupon the housemates rebuked him [and] scolded him [saying]: "If you do not bring back the coat, we will drive you away because of this."
If you don't give away the mantle, then we will drive you away because of that.
[Wenn] du den Mantel nicht zurückbringst, werden wir dich infolgedessen vertreiben.
[If] you do not bring back the cloak, we will therefore expel you.
Darauf erbat er den Mantel von Upananda zurück.
Thereupon he requested [to get] the coat back from Upananda.
Wenn ein Mönch [wtl. welcher Mönch] Kauf [und] Verkauf vornimmt, billig(?) einkauft [und] teuer verkauft um des Gewinnes willen, [so] soll das von ihm zurückgegeben werden.
Whichever monk undertakes [to] buy [and] sell, buys cheaply(?) [and] sells dearly for the sake of profit, this shall be given back by him.
Die Ṣaḍvārgikas sammelten viele Almosenschalen, legten [sie] weg [beiseite] [und] machten keinen Gebrauch [davon].
The Ṣaḍvārgikas gathered many alms bowls, put [them] away [and] made no use [of them].
Die Mönche sahen das [und] tadelten [es] [d.h. wurden ungehalten und gaben dem Ausdruck]
The monks saw this [and] reproached [it] [i.e. became indignant and spoke accordingly]

comments.comment: Bhikṣu-Prātimokṣasūtra, Toch B 337

There can be little doubt that pärkāwse is a variant of (see line a3), which is derived from via the adjectival suffix -ṣṣe. While an alternation between ṣ and s is certainly unexpected in this position, simply attributing this variant to a scribal error is also problematic, since the characters for <ṣ> and <s> look nothing alike.

The form kwāts constitutes one of the three possible readings kwāts, kwats or kwātsä depending on whether the arc above the first of the two akṣaras represents <ā> a virāma stroke, or both, respectively.

line.tr: ... having shaken off ..., he [= the Boddhisattva] entered into the thick thicket, ... in isolation the jewel-like ...
... in order to honor ... out of love for everything. The (beings?) of the mountain, of the forest, of the sky, of the earth, of the water ...
... this very ... Whenever the tigress (nom.) ... the two miserable cubs (obl.) ...
... (55.) With energy [the Boddhisattva] climbed step by step onto the mountain top. He we(nt) ...
... This [~ the Boddhisattva's plan to sacrifice himself for the cubs] caused a benevolent disposition [regarding the] great [mountain] top. 56. He bent ...
... you will be able to help/to be aided, [you, the beings] of the mountain, of the earth, of the sky, [and] of the forest. 57. ...
... away. With joyful, serene, [and] good mind ...
... Then the earth quaked like a boat on water. ...
... 59. The Śuddhavāsa gods, [being] concerned due to the quaking of the earth, gathered [around] the [mountain] top ...
... 60. Up until these passed years indeed as Kāśyapa ...
... this earth quakes six times. 61. These (fem.pl.) [omens??] concerning me indeed ...
... shall become a great teacher. For what reason the earth quakes now (there is no) doubt ...
... (look at/you saw) (??) this prince, [the] Mahāsattva ('great being') falling from the mountain; then ...
... among men to the prince with energy; the two gods stood on the top in the lap of the mountain. ...

comments.comment: The manuscript is certainly a copy from an older one in (more) archaic script and archaic TB due to many inaccurate virāma and fremdzeichen spellings: metrically guaranteed yästä in a 5 and b 2 for yäst\. spelling wän\ with non-fremdzeichen ‹na› in b 4 (and b 5) but neither virāma spelling nor subscription of ‹na› in metrically guaranteed ken in the same line b 4.
As already noted by Sieg/Siegling, the manuscript spells ‹ṣc› for ‹śc›.
Sanskrit: .6ff.; Chinese
This mansucript is basically written in the common archaic script type, but it already shows standard-shaped signs beside the old ones (e.g., open-shaped 〈ma〉 beside closed-shaped); cf. .
Note that the ai-vowel of ‹nai› in b 4 seems to have been secondarily turned into the more archaic elongated shape.
The second smallest fragment under the glass frame with the press mark does not belong here.

The smallest piece has to be turned, it makes an immediate joint with the left fragment in line a 1 and a 7, respectively. The two large fragments immediately join together in lines a 3, a 4, a 5, and a 6, and b 4, b 5, b 6, and b 7, respectively. One piece of the manuscript still known to Sieg/Siegling located between the two fragments in lines a 6-7 and b b 1-3 seems to be lost now.

The small piece joint to line a 6= b 3 of the right fragment on the photograph is wrongly placed. I suggest that it belongs to line a 1 (= b 7) and contains part of the ‹ne› and upper part of ‹stai› of the form enestai. In the current glass frame of the original manuscript, this piece has been moved further to the right side.

The reading saly[u] is quite certain: although the lower part is damaged, the remains cannot be anything else than a vowel ‹u›, as ha been suggested by Sieg/Siegling in . We most likely have to do with a PPt of or 'to throw off (a burden)' being parallel to Sanskrit ava dhū- 'to shake off', see .6: gārhasthyam asvāsthyam ivāvadhūya, kaṃ cid vanaprastham alaṃcakāra "Den Stand eines Haushalters abgeschüttelt habend wie ein Unbehagen, schmückte er einen hochgelegenen Wald (i.e. mit seiner Präsenz)". The next form has been read lyak[eṃ] by and and interpreted as lyake "obstacle", but this reading is very unlikely in my opinion. A close inspection of the original manuscript on 2017-09-08 strongly suggests a reading lyarkā. The gloss "(Hoch)fläche" in or seems to be based on the same Sanskrit passage, but other attestations of suggest that the form rather means 'thicket' and refers to non-penetrable vegetation. At the end of the line, . tentatively suggests to restore to (wṣiya) enestai naumyeṣṣān= epa(nmane) or epa(ntane) "he dwelt secretly [~ in isolation?] in +/- dwellings of [spiritual] jewels". The remains of the last akṣara indeed speak in favour of ‹nta› but ‹nma› is, in my opinion, excluded. For enestai see again the Sanskrit parallel in .7 sa tatra niḥsaṅgatayā tayā ca, prajñāvadātena śamena caiva „Dort durch diese Isolation und durch Einsicht helle (oder reine) Ruhe (Gleichmut)“.

Schmidt's translation "Er rief freundschaftliche Gesinnung hervor [und] beugte sich zum großen Abgrund" in is syntactically excluded since there is a strophe boundary indicated by the spelled strophe number between yäst and rämāte which Schmidt simply ignored in his transcription of the passage. The fact that yäst \ has to be scanned yästä makes the metrical analysis even more likely since the end of a colon is precisely prone to preserve former word-final -ä. The final -ä of yäst has likewise to be restored against the spelling in line , as correctly pointed out by Sieg/Siegling in their commentary.
mettär for maittär is rather a misspelling than sign of monophthongization.

Sieg/Siegling in read ṣleṣṣi kenaṣṣi in a 6, ce[u] kaka[cc]oṣa ta[ka]r in a 7, wä[rs]a plew[e] ra ken)(\) [mai] in b 1, ken [m]amaiwarsa sklokacci and toṃ in b 3 without commentary. Since there is no trace of these akṣaras (put in brackets in the translation), it seems a little piece has been lost when the fragments were put into the current glass frame.
Maybe ni- has to be restored to a form borrowed from Skt. nimitta- 'omen' such as (alternans) pl. nimittanta or nimittanma.
At the end of the line one has to restore a form or derivative of sklok 'doubt'.

The name Mahāsattva conforms to the Sanskrit parallel (see .37) and Chinese parallel 摩訶薩埵 Mohesaduo, see Bunyio Nanjio: A Catalogue of Chinese Tranlation of the Buddhist Tripitaka. There is no obvious restoration for ·y·k·s; since a 2.pl. preterite or imperative is not likely, it may contain the name of the mountain.

line.tr: Das sittliche Verhalten [hat] das eigene Selbst [= einen] mit Zierden auf jede Weise geziert.
The moral conduct [has?] adorned [one's] own self [= oneself] in every manner.
death [is] well arrived. I am ready [and] do not fear [it].
As long as he has not driven off all kleśas, fear for the saṃsāra is still evoked by him.
Solange er nicht alle Kleśas vertrieben haben sollte, solange wird von ihm noch Furcht vor dem Saṃsāra hervorgerufen.
As long as he should not have expelled all kleśas, just as long fear of the saṃsāra will still be stirred up by him.

line.tr: Zu welchem Wunsch auch immer er reif macht, eben dieser Wunsch geht ihm ganz in Erfüllung.
To whatever wish he makes ripe, this very wish comes entirely true for him.
However, he had (no) possessions by which he might have accrued merit based on gift. (cf 192; 463)
If I borrow money from the distinguished [Priyadeva, my neighbour] and behave correctly towards the four great mahāśramaṇas, I will get out of this misery.
[Wenn] ich mich den vier Mahāśramaṇas gegenüber gebührend benehme, werde ich aus diesem Elend herauskommen.
[If] I behave duly towards the four Mahāśramaṇas, I will escape from this misery.
/// he began to make ready the food and drink.

prose.s:
... I said ... the saṃgha ....
/// tmāṣṣante träpi m· nto sāṅk weñāwa

In this way, women... fight... klaina taisa śalla
///
My male characteristic disappeared. eṅkwaññe ṣotri ne(ksa)teñ
For one tattari, in five hundred births, I (was) a woman. ṣe tattari piś känte cmelane klyiye ta(kāwa)
In the Keśik-tune: || k(e)śikne ||
I was the daughter of a merchant. śreṣṭhintse kācer ṣeym

In order to honor the Buddha Kauṇḍinya, I made a garland of lamps with great respect and faith to become a Buddha. kauṇḍinye poyśi yarkeś yā
mṣawa • dipamāl orocce gaurap takarṣkñesa poyśi nessiś ñiś :

I was a princess called Ratnacūḍā, the sister of the Buddha-lord. ratnacuḍa ñemttsa
miñcuṣka takāwa ṣer pudñä(kt)e(ntse) •

I made a garland of lamps for my brother with a pakaccāṃ. ratnaśikhiṃ protri dipamāl yāmṣawa śle p(aka)
ccāmpa :
An old monk previously (?) received a prophecy concerning me. ksaise ṣamāne ñi nauṣṣu su vyākarit kalpa •

The female life made me sick. krasāñ klaiññe ca
mel
I evoked strong faith in the Buddha, the refuge for women. poyśiṃne takarṣkñe maiyyānt ersamai : klaiññe cau āśrai

Then I became a man again. omteṃ wteṃtstse eṅkwe ta
(kāwa)
I left the house to (go to) the Buddha. latau ostmeṃ poyśiś
I learned all the three Piṭakas in full. aklyamai po solme tarya pṭikänta :

line.tr: Meinem Bruder Ratnaśikhin machte ich einen Lampenkranz samt einem Aufenthalt für die Regenzeit.
[For] my brother Ratnaśikhin I made a lamp wreath plus an abode for the wet season.
Es verdross mich die Geburt als Frau, [und] ich rief eine starke Gläubigkeit zum Allerkenner hervor (wegen(?)) dies(es) Verhaftetsein(s) im Weiblichen. Da wurde ich wieder ein Mann.
I was annoyed by [my] incarnation as a woman, [and] I evoked strong faith in the omniscient (because(?) of) this clinging to the female. Thereupon I became a man again.
Ich ging zum Alleswissenden aus dem Hause [und] lernte die drei Piṭakas ganz vollständig.
I went out of the house to the Omniscient [and] learned the three piṭakas all entirely.

line.tr: Den Allerkennerwunsch werde ich verwirklichen, der darin besteht, wem auch immer Gutes zu tun.
I will realize the wish of the Omniscient, which consists of doing good for whoever.
... den Wunsch nach der Allwisserschaft werde ich verwirklichen, der darin besteht, jedermann Gutes zu tun ...
... the wish for omniscience I will make come true, which consists in doing good to everyone ...

line.tr: Die Leute des Landes hörten: "Der König eben(?) hat sich ein Schwert machen lassen [wtl. hat sich gemacht] [bzw. hat das Schwert gebraucht]".
The people of the country heard [this]: "The king exactly(?) has had a sword made for him [lit. has made a sword for himself] [OR: has used the sword]".
We will now also make the swords of each of ours sharp.
Auch wir wollen uns jetzt - ein jeder für sich - scharfe [wtl. harte] Schwerter machen [bzw. machen lassen].
We, too, will now make for ourselves - each for himself - sharp [lit. hard] swords [or: have them made].

line.tr: Wenn (hier ein Wesen) ein mit (Korn)schnaps getränktes(?) Korn in den Mund nimmt [wtl. sich in den Mund legt] [und] es unzerkaut ganz hinunterschluckt, [so] erkennt er dessen Geschmack nicht.
If (a being here) puts a corn soaked in (corn) liquor into [his] mouth [and] swallows it unchewed [and] whole, [then] he does not recognise its taste.

If a being here puts a tanamoda seed into its mouth and swallows it as a whole without having chewed, then it does not notice the taste. Likewise, if someone who has learned the law does not sit down in meditation, the teaching is for him like a tanamoda seed swallowed as a whole.

If this earth were without island and full of water all over, and there were a turtle without eyes that lived there for a long time, and there were also a yoke in this water with only one hole, light and not steady, and in a hundred years this turtle lifted its head and pulled it in quickly only once, and then its head would be pulled up in that hole – …

line.n: a5 a6 a7 b1 b2 b3
line.tr: [Gesetzt], es wäre insellos diese Erde [und] allerorten voll von Wasser, es wäre eine augenlose Schildkröte ..., und es wäre ein Joch in diesem Wasser mit [nur] einer Öffnung ..., alle hundert Jahre nur erhöbe die Schildkröte den Kopf und zöge [ihn] gleich wieder ein [und] ihr Kopf erhöbe sich [wtl. zöge sich hoch] in die[se] Öffnung [bzw. würde in die[se] Öffnung hochgezogen]: Schwerer [noch] als dies [ist es] für die Lebewesen, aus dem Tierstande unter Menschen [wieder]geboren zu werden.

[Suppose that] this earth was without islands [and] full of water everywhere, [that] there were an eye-less turtle ..., and [that] there was a yoke in this water with [only] one opening ..., [that] every hundred years only, the turtle lifted [her] head and retracted [it] immediately again [and that] her head raised itself [lit. pulled itself up] into [this] opening [OR: was pulled up into this opening]: more difficult [even] than this [it is] for beings to be [re]born among the humans again from the state of animals.

line.tr: Die Sonne/Sonnengott der Allerkennerschaft ist aufgegangen/hat sich erhoben.
The sun(god) of omniscience has arisen.
Le dieu soleil de l'omniscience apparut dans les régions des habitants du Magadha.

Those who have been blinded for a long time by the stare of foolishness, (I will make them see?) … through the añjana make-up of wisdom and the … of knowledge … Those who are miserable … and have been staining themselves so long, I will wash off their kleśa dirt with the pure water of the law.

Could this be a form of tukṣi?
Taiṣṣi = 太史

translation.line: Śīlarakṣita asks Āryavarman in a very friendly manner: Śeṣadatta has to give the stringed coins in town. If [you have] the letter, sign [it] and send [it to me]! If Śeṣadatta
has sent [them] nevertheless, he should not sell [them]: the strings are my price. I have sent you a letter, [but] you haven’t sent an answer.
Śilarak(ṣ)ite asks Aryawarme with much friendliness. Sessatatte (is) in town.
If the coins for the joints (?) have to be given, write a letter down and send it. If Sessatatte still
has any (joints) left , he shall not sell them. The joints are my price. I sent you a letter but you
haven't sent an answer back. On day eight.
(This letter) is to be given to Aryawarme.

comments.comment: We would expect Śilarakṣite. This form probably does not reflect something sprachwirklich, but is just an orthographical error, since we wouuld expect the cluster 'kṣ' to be pronounced as 'ʈʂ', like in Gāndhārī (cf. , ).

Interpreting lypaṣ as a mistake for lypoṣ (=lipoṣ). This would be a much better fit semantically and syntactically than taking it to be a form of lu- 'send'. lip- can be used transitively, meaning 'be left for somone' (cf. PK LC 36 a4). Thus, Sessatatteṃ lipoṣ tākaṃ would be a perfectly good sentence, lu- on the other hand would give us trouble.
It is unclear what is meant by "joints" in this document.

line.tr: Hereafter, likewise there will be no one (d)earer to me than you. [My] affection for you, [my] love for you are together like breath
with life. Th(is) shall not change [all my] life long. Thus I was constantly thinking: "With the very beloved one
So dachte ich: "Mit der einen Geliebten werde ich gut [wtl. (zum) Guten] leben ein Leben lang ohne Trug [und] ohne Verstellung(?)."
Thus I thought: "With the one beloved I will live well [lit. (to the) good] all [my] life without lie [and] without pretence(?)."
I will live (for) good lifelong, without deceit, without ..."
God Karma for one knew [that] this is my thought. Thus he evoked excitation.

Gott Karman allein wusste solches mein Denken. Deshalb rief er Zwietracht hervor [oder: rief bei sich Neid hervor] [und] entriss mir das dir gehörige Herz. Er führte dich fort, trennte mich ab [und] ließ mich an allen Leiden teilhaben. Die Freude an dir nahm er mir fort.

God Karman only knew this my thinking. Therefore he evoked discord [or: evoked envy in himself] [and] wrested from me the heart belonging to you. He led you away, separated me [and] let me partake of all sufferings. The joy in you he took away from me.
He pulled out my heart which belongs to you. He led you far away and separated me [from you].
He made me take part in all sufferings and depriv(ed me) of the joy provided by you.
... my life, my spir(it), my heart day by day ...

comments.comment: German translation after : Früher war mir (kein) Mensch genanntes Wesen lieber als du, auch später ist mir keins lieber als du. [2c] Die Liebe zu dir, das Gefallen an dir ist Atem zusammen mit dem Leben. Dieses soll sich lebenslänglich nicht ändern. [2d] So dachte ich: Mit der einen Geliebten werde ich gut leben lebenslänglich ohne Trug [und] ohne Gehabe (?). [3a] Der Gott Karman allein wußte solches mein Denken. Deshalb rief er Zwietracht hervor [und] entriß mir das dir gehörige Herz. [3b] Er führte dich fort, trennte mich ab [und] ließ mich teilhaben an allen Leiden. Die Freude an dir nahm er (mir) fort.

French translation after : ... mille ans ... [2c] D'être vivant portant le nom d'humain, il n'en fut pas auparavant de plus cher pour moi que toi, et il n'en sera pas non plus dans l'avenir de plus cher que toi pour moi. [2d] L'affection pour toi, l'amitié pour toi constitue le souffle associé à la vie tout ensemble. Ceci ne doit pas changer la vie durant. [3a] Ainsi je ne cessais de penser: Avec une unique amante je vivrai pour le bonheur la vie durant, sans duperie ni tromperie. [3b] Le die Acte seul a su cette pensée mienne. C'est pourquoi il a suscité la querelle, il m'a arraché le cœur tien. [3c] Il t'a emmenée au loin, il m'a entraîné á part, il m'a fait prendre part à toutes les souffrances; il m'a enlevé la consolation que tu étais. [3d] ... la vie, l'esprit, le cœur miens, jour après jour ...

English translation after –28: ... for a thousand years however, Thou wilt tell the story (?) Thy ... I announce, [2b] Heretofore there was no human being dearer to me than thee, likewise hereafter there will be no one dearer to me than thee. [2c] Thy love! Thy affection! [My] jubilant song rises up! Along with life [itself], this should not come to an end for [my] whole life. [2d] Thus I was thinking: “I will live with one lover well [for the whole of my] life, without deceit, without ...” [3a] The Karma-god alone recognized this, my thought. Thus he provoked a quarrel; it ripped out my heart [that belonged] to thee; [3b] it led thee afar, it tore me apart, it turned me into a partaker of all sorrows; he took away the consolation [I had] in thee. [3c] ... my life, spirit, and heart day-by-day ...
Verso side covered with paperboard.

n. 9 corrects pikala to pik{w}ala, but the loss of the labial element of the labiovelar could be a feature of colloquial/late TB, see . The form ask(a)sk(au) could be a colloquial/late form of aksaskau and not a spelling error, cf. colloquial Engl. aks for ask. Colloquial/late noṣ śomo for nauṣ śaumo, for the change au > o see .

(ya)ltse is emended by n. 8. watäṃ may also be read as wat, i.e. wa_t\•, cf. n. 10 and . The latter also emends [w]e(ṃ)t no ciṣṣe – – ñ(iś caina)nts p[o] after watäṃ, of which ciṣṣe and po seem plausible. ask(a)sk(au) is emended by n. 12 and corrected to aksaskau (see Linguistic commentary). (mā) ñ(i ci)sa emended by n. 13.
Colloquial/late ārtañye for ārttalñe; for the change lñe > ñye see . Colloquial (?) kaltta(r)r for kaltär.
Colloquial/late śolämpa for śaulämpa and śol for śaul; for the change au > o see .

Colloquial/late karttse(ś) for kartseśc; for the change śc > ś see . Depending on the reading (see Philologically commentary) the last word of this line has been translated as German ohne Gehabe in the reading snai-tāte by and as French sans tromperie in the reading snai-tā(r)śai by . The reading snai-tāte (, and ) was never explained regarding its morphological derivation, whereas the reading snai-nāne (n. 21) is connected with "to appear" by , cf. also s.v., without any further explanation. . proposes a relationship with tarśauna [TA tārśoṃ] "deception". However, tarśauna would be expected to have a singular tārśi*, cf. nom./obl. sg. , nom./obl. sg. . Obl. sg. tārśai, which seems to be attested in , could be consolidated with a nom. sg. tarśiye. In the latter case the derived adjective tārśī(cce) in b5 would be problematic since a derivative of a noun in nom. sg. -iye, obl. sg. -ai would have the oblique as its derivational basis, cf. "fear, worry, danger" : "pertaining to fear, worry, danger".

The last word in this line has been read as snai-tāte by , and . n. 21 suggests snai-nāne as a possible reading as well, which is given in . also gives snai-t/nāte. KT Schmidt apud n. 12 and read this word as snai-tā(r)śai. Since there are too many possibilities and the issue cannot be settled (yet) we do not commit to a specific variant (for now).
Colloquial/late palskañe for palskalñe, for the change lñe > ñye see .
Colloquial/late araś for arañc, for the change ñc > ṃś > ś see .
In the phrase wāya ci lauke the ci has been added by another hand according to n. 2.
lykautka-ñ misspelled for klykautka-ñ and läklentas for läklentants.
Colloquial/late kom for kauṃ, for the change au > o see .

comments.comment: That this fragment has a direct parallel in , and was already seen by and . b7 karavīräṣṣe lasto: argues that lasto means ‘root bark', since it is usually root and root bark that is used in Ayurvedic medicine from the poisonous karavīra- shrub (Nerium Indicum, White Oleander). However, the Sanskrit parallel to the derivative shows that the form must mean ‘stalk'; note that all parts of karavīra- (including flower, stem, and leaves) may be used to for skin diseases and wound healing.
The original manuscript is missing.

line.tr: ... [supernatural] knowledge . (To) King Aśoka ...
... [it is] good in diseases pertaining to ...
... Costus speciousus ...
... has to be ... [and] has to be made into the eyes. On this bond a spell has to be cast. ...
Sanskrit Now [about the fatty salve called] mahāvaidehik: I will tell the salve for all
[diseases] concerning the eyes; in [theses] diseases [it is] good. [The formula contains]: Piper nigrum, Piper longum, ginger, heart-heaved moonseed, aneth; seed
of the two [Indian Sarsaparilla] of both kinds; vetiver; sandalwood, junipe [or: Wild Himalayan cherry] (root/bark), [the triphalā formula consisting of] Yellow myrobalan, Bastard myrobalan, [and]
Indian gooseberry; Berberis aristata; Desmodium Gangeticum; Uraria lagopoides; Indian nightshade; Solanum xanthocarpum, caltrop, [root] of Boerhavia diffusa
Polygonatum cirrhifolium; Polygonatum verticillatum; Roscoea procera, Lilium polyphyllum; Microstylis wallichii, Microstylis muscifera, Mucuna prurita;
root of Pavonia odorata (?), ..., Vanda roxburghii, root of Nardostachys Jatamansi (?), root of lotus; Pinus (webbiana)
(Rubia cordifolia, grape, blue water-lily,) root (of Sida spinosa). These remedie(s) ...

comments.comment: The text has several late/colloquial spellings. The palatalized ñ in eśañene° (lines and ) is part of a tendency for late palatalization of n in several contexts, e.g., before i (see ). If the spelling ṣalpe for ṣalype is not a mere error, it may then be interpreted as a hypercorrect form. Like in other late manuscripts, there are also some wrong vowels (śkwiśko for śkwaśko in line ). Note further the wrong agreement of the masculine adj. in -ṣṣe with the fem. tāno in and of the oblique feminine adj. in -ṣṣai with the fem.nom. witsako in .
Sanskrit/Khotanese Jīvapustaka IOL Khot 91/3
The edition is based on , who also gives a normalized version of the corrupt text found in the Jīvapustaka; the Khotanese parallel has been edited and translated by .

Written on the verso side of a Chinese scroll containing Aṣṭādasasāhasrikā Prajñāpāramitā (Taisho 224 = 8, 465c, 11–25). Tocharian text identification and joint of THT 500 and THT 501 according to . According to the restoration of the leaf by the BBAW, the third fragment THT 502 further joins THT 500 on the top. The script type is basically the classical one, although more clumsy than in regular literary manuscripts.
Since the mere oblique form lānt ought to be spelled with virāma, the most likely restoration is an allative lānt(aśc).

These six plants are part of the aṣṭavarga formula, see ; however, ṛddhi- 'Habenaria edgeworthii' and vṛddhi- 'Habenaria intermedia D.Don' seem substituted by ātmagupti 'Mucuna prurita' and the following plant.

palāṣṣai wtsako is another substitution for ṛddhi- 'Habenaria edgeworthii' or vṛddhi- 'Habenaria intermedia D.Don'. In the Sanskrit version one has bāla or bālā, which can refer to several plants, but not to the one found in the Khotanese version, i.e. bela 'Aegle marmelos, Beal tree' (= Skt. bilva- = TB ; see . As Maue points out, Skt. balā 'Sida cordifolia' = Khot. sacha-bāva listed later in the parallel formula can hardly refer to the same plant as well, so Maue himself interprets Skt. bāla/ā in this passage as 'Pavonia ordorata Willd.'; note that its Khotanese equivalent is bilva. While sub enmetre certainly correctly notes that "there is potential for some confusion in translation here", I do not follow his suggestion that enmetre belongs to the same phrase "the enmetre of the pāla-root" (interpreted as "bark", i.e. "the root-bark of pāla") because this is morphologically improbable (even if the agreement between palāṣṣai and wtsiko is wrong). To be sure, since there has no doubt been some confusion as to which ingredient is correct as eigth component of the aṣṭavarga formula, I would not exclude the possibility that enmetre is simply an added ingredient even thought it cannot be found in the Jīvapustaka parallel. Note that further in the line the two versions do slightly differ.

The parallel for pepar* are Skt. nalada- and Khot. svarnagūttaryaṃ būśanai; nalada or naladā refers to the musk-root plant [Nardostachys Jatamansi] (thus the interpretation of . fn. 47) or to a variety of vetiver grass [Vetiveria zizanioides = Andropogon muricatus Retz.] (thus the interpretation of s.v. nalat).

As points out, both versions differ: Skt. padmakesara- and Khot. padmakyesärä refer to the filament (and not to the root) of the padma-plant [Nelumbo nucifera] (and not of the utpala-plant [Nymphaea stellata]; to be sure, etymologically TB uppāl is derived from Skt. utpala- "Blue Water-lily" [Nymphaea stellata] (which is actually listed later, in the unattested part of the Jīvapustaka), but it can refer to padma-plant also in other Tocharian passages.

Restoration tālis (pattär) according to ; the parallel has Skt. tālispattra and Khot. ttālīspattra. Skt. tālīśapattra- refers to the Indian Silver Fir [Pinus webbiana Wall.] (not to the Indian plum = Skt. tālīśa-, as per ). Note that tālis is written with virāma; a calque is also possible.

16-17 syllables are missing at the beginning of the line; accordingly, (w)itsako could very well refer to the last ingredient of the formula, Skt. balā (for nāgabalā 'Sida spinosa', Khot. sacha-bāva 'root of Sida cordifolia', as per . Restoring (bal\) seems possible to me.
-na is certainly the end of a plural adjective modifying tekanma ‘diseases'.
-källe is a gerund from a root ending in -k; note that a restoration -(ṅ)källe or -(r)källe is also possible.
For ce krāntsa nasait yama(ṣle) cf. BHS grantha-dharaṇī 'D. belonging to binding'; see .

The akṣaras hāvairyocaṇ of the chapter title mahāvairyocaṇi have been deleted by the scribe with several small vertikal strokes, the correct title (ma)hāvaidyehik follows, as restored by Sieg/Siegling.

points out that TB pissau 'aneth' does not conform to the Sanskrit/Khotanese version where we have Skt. madhuka- 'liquorice'. According to Maue, the Tocharian scribe may have confused this word with Skt. madhurikā- which can refer both to 'fennel' and 'aneth'.

According to the Sanskrit and Khotanese parallel, the seed in question is that of the two sorts of Skt. śārivā ‘Indian Sarsaparilla [Hemidesmus indicus]', see with fn.s 27 and 28. Even though Skt. śārivā is attested otherwise as TB , this form cannot be restored here despite the relatively certain reading of r[p]. Nevertheless, it is quite certain that the same plant is meant since the dual śārivā is translated twice: by the adverb and by a dual ending -ñc, onto which the -ṣṣe-adjective is built (cf. the type lakṣānäñc ‘two lakṣaṇas'). As dual of śārip one would expect śāripäñc. As for yāstaci, the Sanskrit formula has padmaka- 'Wild Himalayan cherry', the Khotanese one pauṣṭarä 'juniper'; notes that Skt. padmaka- is often replaced by juniper species outside India; in any case, since no ingredient of the formula is missing in the Tocharian text, it is likely that one has to restore an adjective like yāstaci(ṣṣe/a) and a plant term such as tāno ‘seed' in the lacuna. Note that in Ayurvedic medicine both the seeds and the bark of the cherry tree are used.
gandhakāri for the Sanskrit plant kaṇṭakārī (also attested in TB as ) shows a wrong etymological connection with Skt. gandha- 'scent'; cf. .

eśpeṣṣe looks like an adjective; since the Khotanese version explicitly refers to the root of this plant, one may think of restoring witsako, even though this is a feminine; see with fn. 39. Wrong gender agreement is also attested in line b8.

line.tr: Du hast diese elende Welt überschritten [hinter dir gelassen].
You have gone beyond this miserable world [have left it behind you]
Aber vom (Alleswissenden) getadelt, hält er sich selbst unbekü(mmert) zurück.
But, reproached by the (Omniscient), he restrains himself, unconcer(nedly).
whoever is helping in good things.
Here the imāne says: «I don't know where (the prince is) now …»

line.tr: ... the doing of (thi)ngs, [23a] the mind [is] the best, the mind comes first. ... [23b] ...
... (Thereupon the suffering) follows him in the rebirths, [24a] the wheel of the deed, the cutting one rise(s up). [24b] ...
... (But which is the de)ed which has been done and at the same time accumulated? [25a] It is this deed (which has been done) here due (to) the thought of ...
... [25d] But which is the deed which has not been done and not accumulated? [26a] [It is this deed] which has been done unintention(ally). [26b] ...
... [26d] || In [the tune] bahudantāk || Some beings having been hap(py here previously indeed) ... [1a] ...
... I will tell the way. Listen attentively! [1b] Here so(me beings ... they seize possession. [1c] ...
… I will tell the … way, listen with one mind! (cf 17)
... (But) afterwards they are full of remorse. [1d] But these b(eings ... are born in a rich house) ... [2a] ...
they obtain the (pos)sessions and everything pleasant. [2b] ... [2c] ...
... first happy, he feels suffering afterwards. [2d] But (which is the deed by which the beings after having been full of suffering first, afterwards become happy?) [3a] ...
... they (begin) to speak loudly, but they hold on [to it = the gift] even under pain, [3b] while giving the gift ...
... they do (not) feel remorse, they become joyful. [3d] ... [4a]
... (when they beco)me great, by that time they grow in possession [and] they (become) rich. [4b] ...
... (wenn) sie groß (werden), dann [wtl. zu der Zeit] nehmen sie an Besitz zu [und] (werden) reich.
... (when) they (become) big, at that time they increase in possession [and] (become) rich.
... [4c] That is the deed through which beings (after having been) suffering first (become happy afterwards.) [4d] ...

... (But what is the deed through which beings, if they are hap)py first indeed, become happy afterwards? [5a] Some bein(gs while giving a gift hold on to it being joyful, ... the giving of gift) ... [5b] ...
(But what is the deed through which beings), if they are happy first, become happy afterwards [too]? (cf 20)

... and (afterw)ards they rejoice because of it [and] they do not become remorseful. [5c] (Stainle)ss [and] (pure [is] this gift, so pure to obtain a fruit [from it], and the beings rejoice) because of it.) [5d] ...
... among humans they are reborn in a rich house (provided) with possession. [6a]

line.tr: The [types of] salvations can be attained in the wide land of Āryamarga [11b]; those who are the doors (= blockades?) of the vimokṣa are indifferent [11c]; they are able to dam the power of the saṃsāra river 11. Those who trust are able to (eradicate?) the kleśa trees, whose roots, lianas, branches and twigs [are] in the highest existence, with the axe of wisdom [12c], and they (are able) to turn away from the clinging to existence and glory (12). They are able to throw off the burden of the five skandhas [13a]. Those asking for food and drink can be satisfied [13b]. It is necessary to … [give up?] saying «I» [13c]. Here the peṣte (= fetter?) of the kleśas is (cut off?) for all 13. The heat of exaltation [is] then here … [14a], the high mountain of exaltation is then easy to climb [14b], mercy for the hell-beings, animals and pretas can be obtained [14c], the path of Agradharma …
Die (um Essen [und] Trinken) Bittenden können nur hier gesättigt werden.
The ones begging (for food [and] drink) can only here be satisfied.
le pardon destiné aux êtres infernaux, aux animaux et aux revenants ne peut être obtenu qu'ici en vérité.

line.tr: Auf einer großen Leichenstätte, wo man (noch) beständig die Toten hinwirft, dort macht er [scil. der Śmāśānika Mönch der mittleren Richtung] sich eine Mönchszelle.
On a large charnel ground, where [people] (still) always throw the dead, there he [i.e. the Śmāśānika monk of the middle way] makes for himself a monk's cell.

Where on a big cemetery they may still steadily throw down the dead, there indeed he makes his monk cell, and there he stays in. There he makes himself (?) dead [people] and bones, according to his [own] wish.
Wo früher eine Leichenstätte war, dort macht er [scil. der Śmāśānika-Mönch der gemäßigten Richtung] sich eine Mönchszelle.
Where there used to be a charnel ground earlier, there he [i.e. the Śmāśānika monk of the moderate way] makes for himself a monk's cell.
Where formerly a cemetery [lit. a former cemetery] may have been, there indeed he makes his monk cell, and there he stays in. In this way he sets himself on human bones and skeletons all the time.

And in order to comfort the pāṃsukūlika-monk [or the pāṃsukūlika-monks], the Buddha, the teacher, came with Ananda to the charnel-ground.
Mit [seiner] lotusfarbenen, zarten Hand nahm er [scil. der Buddha] das über die gestorbene Frau gedeckte Tuch [fort].
With [his] lotus-coloured, tender had, he [i.e. the Buddha] took [away] the cloth [that had been] spread over the woman [who had] died.

line.tr: ... sie zogen von den Bäumen Früchte herab, berochen die Blumen [d.h. sie bemühten sich, von einer Geruchsempfindung betroffen zu werden], [und] sammelten sich ...
... they pulled fruit from the trees, smelled the flowers [i.e. they strove to be affected by the sensation of smell], [and] gathered ...
... die Angehörigen, die nach ihrem Söhnchen riefen, die da etwa nach ihren lieben Frauen (riefen(?)) ...
... the relatives, that called out for their little son, they who (called(?)) their dear wives ...
... in dem Wunsch, doch ... zu sein, sammelten wir Juwelen.
... wishing ... to be ..., we gathered jewels.

comments.comment: The leaf has no pre-drawn lines which makes it difficult to read the more due, the more since it has eleven lines in a crammed, small script type, which is somewhat clumsy. Very remarkable is the absence of fremdzeichen and the use of 〈v〉 for 〈w〉 and 〈ṃ〉 for all kinds of nasal. Accordingly, it may be a writing exercise, which may also explain the unusual numbering and punctuation.

line.tr: ... The king says: "(I am) not capable to make turn the firm resolution ...
... in order to (pay) honorable homage in the Vicitrapuṣpa [= having many-colored flowers] garden, be(decked) with flowers [and] garlands ...
... we ... If they will cut down lianas [and] tear off flowers, this will be an offence by them. From the country (they will be banned) ...
«we …» If they, however, chop lianas and scatter flowers, this will be an offence of theirs, and (they will be driven) off the land (?).
... All went out. After the passing of seven days the bedecked Vicitrapuṣpa garden ...
... the four learnèd princes Ulkāmukha, Katakarṇi, Hastinyāsa, [and] Nupūra ...
... Ulkāmukha says: || In [the tune] maittär || "Flutes resound, and the ... animals trumpet ...
... But which [is] this difference ... the clay ...
... they [= the four princes] tore off blue lotus [flowers]. Th(en) or: (After having heard/seen) that ...
the ... say: Stop there! Keep to the lord's order! ...
… say: «[Go] back!, act according to the command of the lord.» The princes …
... [the king] ordered them [= the princes] to be bound. Ulkāmukha says: "Now our own life is at risk. Not (can we expect mercy?) from [our] dear father ...
We, his own life, cannot be abandoned by [our] dear father!
... The executioners bo(und) the legs of the princes tightly resembling bits of waiki ...
... [the princes] were banned (from the country). Having seen that, a great lamenting voice was heard ...
Dies gesehen habend, wurde eine große Klagestimme gehört.
Having seen this, a great voice of lament was heard.
... (they came) to the cementery of ...vana. The princes say. || In [the tune] haridāsñe || We remember all ...
... we were (driven out?) by a lie. This ... of [our] father's, the king's ...

comments.comment: For the Tibetan parallel, see .

proposes a passive reading and a 2.sg. predicate: "(You are) not capable of being made turn", in which case the following ought to be "by firm resolution". I think that the king rather speaks about the firm resolution of himself regarding the decision of being succeeded by his youngest son instead of the four elder brothers mentioned below. In order to bring about this incorrect succession, the four elder princes are in the following tricked into getting banned from the country.
This is still part of the king's speech regarding the ban on plucking flowers in the garden.

The name of the garden is both times spelled without virāma; since in terms borrowed from Sanskrit a word-final vowel is quite often respresented by -ä even in prose texts (cf. ), it is unnecessary to restore a virāma.
-k(·)mträ belongs to a 1.pl. middle Prs/Sub form.
Note the colloquial spellings ṣuk for ṣutk and konaṃts for kaunaṃts.

In the Tibetan version of the story the princes are named Ulkāmukha, Karakarṇa, Hastināyaka, and Nūpura, as per Sieg/Siegling, with ref. to ; the Sanskrit name of the third brother is transposed by Hasti-niyaṃsa by .

According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 4x12 (5/7) syllables, but then we get a caesura inside the vowel sandhi in a6; this problem is not solved by assuming a 7/5 variation, because the passage has eight syllables if k_use indeed starts pāda d. Note that the same tune has 4x14 syllables in another text.
ñc is no doubt part of a masc. nom.pl. form.

In the Tibetan parallel, the princes are at first condemned to death and then pardoned and banished on the words of the king's minsters; the same ministers who came up with the plan of getting rid of the princes in the first place.
-vaṃ is the end of a Sanskrit place name in -vana "grove".
Because of the meter, restoration to a middle form klāske(mträ) (as per Sieg/Siegling) is likely.
According to Sieg/Siegling, the meter has 4x14 (7/7) syllables.

Sieg/Siegling proposed the restoration (śānmya)mte, followed, e.g., by : "we were (bound) by a lie"; but unless we have a word play between the unknown waiki (b5) and waike 'lie' (b8), a more likely restoration is (lyutstsa)mte "we were (driven out) by a lie". The rest of this fragmentary line is mostly unclear. nrai ‘hell' seems to be a separable form, to which -°lyai may be part of an attributive gerundive.

line.tr: How will the antarakalpa of illness come here? … then because of that illness [the] people die.
How will the antarakalpa of hunger come here? Then because of that hunger the three continents starve within seven days …
"(Wie kommt dann der Antara)kalpa des Hungers?" [Antwort:] "Die drei Kontinente verhungern dann durch den Hunger (innerhalb von) sieben Tagen."
"(How, then, does the Antara)kalpa of hunger (arrive)?" [Answer:] "The three continents then will starve through the hunger (within) seven days."
How will the … of the śastrakalpa come, then? … it will enter … day …
How will these beings be seen by each other? Terrible mind …
Wie werden die Wesen voneinander(?) gesehen? oder: Wie zeigen sich [d.h. verhalten sich(?)] die Wesen zueinander(?) ?
How are the beings seen by each other(?) ? OR: How do the beings show themselves [i.e. behave(?)] towards each other(?) ?
Es entsteht [wtl. erhebt sich] das Verlangen sich gegenseitig zu töten.
The desire to kill each other arises.
... zum (Töt)en gebrauchte er [sein] (Schwert) ...
... for (kill)ing he used [his] (sword) ...

line.tr: No matter how many Śuddhavāsa gods rise here, [each] obtains the happiness of the highest truth of the eternal nirvāṇa.
… the happiness of joy comes about in his body: he is not able to tell the joy of the fulfilling of the dear [lit. great] wish, to teach it or to let it know in a metaphor.
... of zeal in decrease ...
Who has the jñānasaṃbhāra of a hundred kalpas here, …
If his definite shape and form are not gone or lost, the Āryamarga [the noble path] is at once lit up for him without teacher and without teaching.
… he witnesses the 37 laws and attains the rank of a pratyeka Buddha and second he becomes worthy of receiving gifts …

To whom, however, compassion and wisdom arise, and who does not turn back from the effort for countless ages, and does not make the consciousness of hindrance … and takes …, and does not think «I cannot», even oṣ or honey does not delight his heart if he takes the sorrows of the beings of the five births in his vajra-like heart. (cf 476)
Auch ... oder Honig wird nicht [sein] Herz erfreuen, wenn er die Leiden der Fünfgeburten[wesen] in [sein] Herz nimmt [bzw. in [seinem] Herzen trägt].
Neither ... nor honey will delight [his] heart, if he takes the suffering of the [beings of the] five incarnations into [his] heart [or: carries ... in [his] heart].

line.tr: Ich, Räknāśka, sage selbst keine Grobheit [wtl. Hartes, Rauhes]; (nicht) befehle ich (einem anderen), eine Grobheit zu sagen; nicht mache ich gemeinsame (Sache) mit einem , der eine Grobheit sagt; nicht freue ich mich darüber [und] nicht lobe ich es.
I, Räknāśka, myself do not speak roughly; I (do not) command (another) to speak roughly; I do not act in (collusion) with one that speaks roughly; I am not pleased by it [and] I do not praise it.

Ich, Räknāśka, bin (selbst nicht) übelgesinnt; nicht befehle ich einem anderen, übelgesinnt zu sein; nicht mache ich gemeinsame Sache (mit einem) Übelgesinnten; nicht freue ich mich darüber [und] nicht lobe ich es.
I, Räknāśka, myself am not evil-minded; I do not command another to be evil-minded; I do not act in collusion (with an) evil-minded one; I am not pleased by it [and] I do not praise it.

line.tr: … they said before, or they say [now, or] will say after this.
Das Spr(echen des) Gesetz(es) aber wird von (allen) Buddhas (das Vorzüglichste) genannt.
Spe(aking the) Law, however, is by (all) Buddhas called (the most excellent).
Die auf Name [und] Maß bedachten Gelehrten haben ihm (Na)men [bei]gelegt.
The savants, intent on name [and] measure, have assigned (na)mes to him.

line.tr: ... || This twelfth art has been finished writing. || ||
These arts Dharmacandra has ordered to write. May through [his] wish for the Buddha worth the dangers of this birth disappear for him!
May the monastic virtues grow for him! May I in [this] birth, in this turning saṃsāra, no longer be mālle, may I have sharp senses!
May I through this good deed come together with Maitreya! May I be writing the three piṭakas!
Who may learn this art, may they all become Buddhas! || || These arts Toṅkitsā has given as a gift.

comments.comment: The leaf is almost complete; only a small strip at the right is lost. The recto contains the end of the dvādaśākṣarī including the closing formula in Tocharian A; the fact that the leaf number is found on the recto confirms that this was the last leaf of the manuscript. The verso is filled with pious wishes in another hand, in Tocharian B, but with many mistakes. The verso ends with a phrase in Tocharian A again, in yet another hand. As is leaf number 9, this should be leaf number 11. A leaf number seems to be found in the left margin of the recto, but it is illegible.

: With || säs śäkwepint amok piktsi papyutäk • || the dvādaśākṣarī text ends. śäkwepint 'twelfth' may refer to the text type of the dvādaśākṣarī instead of the actual number of sections, since this text seems to have only 6 sections. Otherwise, the twelve sections may have been subdivided into two larger sections of each 6 subsections.

säs śäkwepint amok piktsi papyutäk: The phrase literally means 'This twelve art has come about [through/ in] writing' (cf. , who translates "Das Schreiben dieser zwölften [Schreib]kunst ist beendet." [wtl. "Diese zwölfte Kunst ist zustande gekommen, geschrieben zu werden.").
|| ||: After these two double daṇḍas, the rest of the line is empty.
paññäktaññe: for expected paññäktäññe, pañäktäññe.

ce amokänta: if ce modifies amokänta, the correct form would have been toṃ or toyna. Therefore, proposes to read ce as k_uce in the sense 'because'. However, a demonstrative would seem to be expected and in view of all the mistakes in this text it may well have been meant to be used so.
came_l\ṣṣena: the remarkable _l\ in the middle of this word may be due to a form cmeläṣṣana (); the expected form is cmelṣana.
mālle: suggests 'dull'.

śilyme: a writing error for śmilye, in turn probably somehow a late form of vn śmalñe 'coming'. In any case, the correct order would be maitreyempa eṣe śilyme tākoym, cf. b3 aknātsaimpa ṣe śmalyñe mā ñī tāko_ī 'may there be no coming together with a fool for me!'. Note in addition the expected 3sg. verb in the latter example, as against the peculiar 1sg. in our text.
piṅkemane tākoym: this construction is peculiar. If not a calque, it might simply be a mistake.
paññäkte: for paññäkti, pañäkti.
se: for k_use.

: • ||: read : 1 ||, but the preceding lines are hardly metrical. If we base ourselves on the punctuation marks and leave out the first sentence, which is 47 syllables, the remaining four lines are 14, 20, 12 and 15 syllables respectively. Even if these were meant to imitate a 4-line poem, they cannot be analysed as such.

comments.comment: The original now has the press mark THT 1506.

There is only one Tocharian line on the verso side. On the blank space one can see single akṣaras written by a different hand, no doubt a writing excercise. The strange thing is that these single akṣaras have a far older ductus, as already correctly seen by Sieg/Siegling in . According to the charts in , they can be dated into the Gupta period, i.e. into the 3rd/4th century. The Tocharian text is certainly much younger.
śetk(o) is the only restoration leading to a yet attested word, though its meaning is unclear.
läksaiñene shows the colloquial sound change a > ai before palatal consonant (see .).
ṣyār(··) is unclear; since an initial ṣy is unusual, I would not exclude a separation ṣ yār(··).
–nta(ṃ)ts is a gen.pl. form.
